DOC.HEAD: Brother Called Before Grand Jury Investigating Stuart Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Matthew Stuart, who exposed his late brother's plot to kill his pregnant wife, was called Friday before a grand jury investigating the slaying. Stuart was seen leaving the office used by the grand jury, but his attorney, Nancy Gertner, refused to say if he had testified. The case drew widespread attention when it broke dramatically the night of Oct. 23: A frantic Charles Stuart called police on his car phone to say his pregnant wife, Carol, had been shot by a robber. Police found the middle-class couple in their car in an inner city neighborhood near a hospital where they had attended a birthing class. Mrs. Stuart was fatally wounded, and Stuart himself had a serious gunshot wound. The baby, delivered prematurely, died 17 days later. For days nobody doubted Stuart's story that the family had been attacked by a black mugger. Matthew Stuart provided a dramatic turnaround in the case Jan. 3, when he told authorities his brother had arranged for him to be at the murder scene. He also told investigators he helped dispose of a gun, which turned out to be the murder weapon. Charles Stuart committed suicide Jan. 4 after his brother implicated him in the crime. Yet Matthew Stuart's revelations also raised questions about his role in the plot. He has insisted he had no prior knowledge that Mrs. Stuart would be killed, and he said he did not see her body in the couple's car when Charles Stuart passed him the handbag that contained the gun. Since Stuart's suicide, a Suffolk County grand jury has convened periodically to piece together details of the plot. Prosecutors have not said whether charges might be filed. Matthew Stuart arrived at the Suffolk County district attorney's office Friday morning. He was seen with his two sisters, but Gertner indicated they were only accompanying him to the courthouse. Both sisters already have appeared before the grand jury. ``I can't tell you what's happening,'' Gertner said. ``Everything before the grand jury has been impounded. All the motions that have been filed are impounded.''

DOC.HEAD: Tips for Beating the Blahs After Time Switch
DOC.TEXT: Monday morning could bring on a special case of the groggy blahs after the switch to daylight saving time this weekend, but some quick action can help ease the problem, a researcher says. ``This is one weekend you shouldn't sleep in,'' said Dr. Charles Czeisler, director of the Center for Circadian and Sleep Disorders Medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. Instead, the trick is to accustom the body as fast as possible to the time change, he said Friday. The shift, which occurs with the loss of an hour at 2 a.m. Sunday, delivers a one-two punch to the body. It usually robs an hour of sleep, since most people have trouble falling asleep an hour earlier than their normal bedtimes. And it forces the body to readjust its daily internal rhythms, including one that affects alertness and performance, Czeisler said. One study found that traffic accidents jump 10 percent in the week following the switch to daylight saving time, he said. Sleep expert Merrill Mitler of the Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation in La Jolla, Calif., said the one-hour change is generally tolerated well by the body, and adjusted to within a day or so. The body copes more easily with the return to standard time in the fall, because turning the clock back an hour is less of a challenge. Here is Czeisler's prescription for making Monday morning as painless as possible: _ Don't stay up late tonight. _ Get up at your normal time, according to the clock, on Sunday. _ After getting up Sunday, take a walk outdoors for a half hour to 45 minutes before breakfast. The idea is to expose yourself to bright outdoor light. That will help re-set your body's clock, which is in your brain. _ If you want to make up some sleep lost earlier in the week, take a nap around 3 p.m. or 4 p.m. today and Sunday. _ Don't eat any heavy meals late today or Sunday, because that will make it harder to fall asleep. Similarly, avoid caffeine after 6 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: Nevada Hit With Worst Cricket Infestation Since '30s
DOC.TEXT: Millions of crop-eating, leaf-chomping crickets that can grow as big as a small mouse have invaded rural Nevada in the worst infestation of the insects since the 1930s, agricultural officials said. ``We've probably got 700,000 acres of the state infested now; They're starting to hatch and the ground is just black with them in some places,'' Dick Rowe, deputy director of the plant industry division of the Nevada Agriculture Department, said Friday. ``Right now they're little devils, but pretty soon if they're not stopped they're going to be big mothers.'' Rowe has counted about 100 Mormon crickets per square foot in the worst infested areas, compared with one or two in a normal year. The insects got their name from a similar infestation reported in Utah in the 1800s. Sea gulls from Salt Lake City reportedly flew over the infested land, eating the crickets to save the Mormon-populated area from total destruction, he said. ``I don't know if it's true or not,'' he said. ``But it takes a pretty good size bird to eat them when they're mature. Most of them are about the size of your thumb and they got hard spurs on the back of their legs so they get stuck in the craw of birds and kill them.'' The crickets, which make chirping sounds, spit brown juice and bite humans if disturbed, ``eat everything in sight including each other,'' Rowe said. Unable to fly, they march in bands across the land and strip crops clean, eat leaves and bark off trees and gobble up any organic material. Common crops across the infested parts of Nevada include alfalfa, alfalfa seed, potatoes, meadow hay and small grain. State and federal agriculture agencies are developing a plan for controlling the infestation in northeastern and north-central Nevada. Chemical spraying and baiting the area with poisoned food is being considered and a control plan is expected to be adopted next week, according to Rowe and George Nash, head of the federal Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service plant disease and quarantine operation based in Reno. But Nash estimated it would cost $15 per acre for control measures with farmers and ranchers paying half the cost on private lands and the government picking up the entire tab on public property. Rowe said three or four dry springs in a row and recent warm weather have been perfect for the crickets. The crickets stop in their tracks when the temperature drops and starve if they don't continue their hungry march, he said. Jeff Knight, also with the state agriculture department, said the crickets lay eggs in the summer and fall that incubate during the winter and hatch in the spring. The one-generation insects normally live through September, he said. ``It's frightening once they get larger and start moving,'' Knight said. ``I've seen some the size of a house mouse, about 2 inches in body length and three-quarters of an inch wide. When they bite they're big enough to break the skin.''

DOC.HEAD: Justices Put Flag Burning Case on Fast Track
DOC.TEXT: Protecting the American flag and the rights of political dissenters could be hot election issues this fall in view of the Supreme Court's willingness to swiftly confront the flag-burning controversy. The justices announced Friday they will decide by early summer whether Congress violated free-speech rights when it passed a law last year making it a crime to burn the flag. If the justices agree with two federal judges and strike down the statute, President Bush and Republican leaders will push to amend the Constitution and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., says he will not stand in their way. Foley has said that within 30 days of a high-court ruling invalidating the federal law, the House would vote on a constitutional amendment. Such an amendment would say a ban on flag burning does not violate free speech. It would require approval by two-thirds of the members of the House and Senate and then ratification by 38 state legislatures for inclusion in the Constitution. The Supreme Court on Friday granted an administration request to put the flag-burning issue on a fast track that will allow it to announce a decision by July in cases from the District of Columbia and Seattle. Federal judges struck down the law in both cases. The justices said they will hear arguments in the cases May 14, marking the first time in nine years that a hearing will be conducted that late in a court term. The court heard arguments June 24, 1981, when it studied the legality of the agreement that ended the Iran hostage crisis. On only two other occasions in recent times has the court held such special sessions _ before allowing publication in 1971 of the Pentagon papers on the war in Vietnam and before ordering then-President Nixon in 1974 to surrender Watergate-scandal tape recordings. Arthur Kropp, president of the civil liberties group People for the American Way, decried the court's timing. ``Depending on the outcome, we can expect that last year's favorite political football, a constitutional amendment, will be back to kick off a whole new generation of 30-second attack ads,'' Kropp said. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., hailed the court action. ``Flag burners have been having a field day at Old Glory's expense,'' he said. ``The court's decision to put this issue on a fast track is great news for the flag, the American people and those of us in Congress who want Old Glory to have the protection it deserves.'' The justices, voting 5-4 last June, struck down a Texas law barring desecration or destruction of the flag. The court said burning the American flag as a form of political protest is protected by the Constitution's free-speech guarantees. The ruling touched off a political firestorm and led to enactment of the federal law, which carries a maximum one-year jail sentence. The Texas law barred flag desecration that seriously offends others, but the federal law bans flag burning regardless of its impact on anyone. Democratic leaders in Congress say that difference makes the federal law constitutional. The Justice Department has urged the high court to uphold the federal law despite the department's misgivings and statements by Bush that a constitutional amendment to protect the flag is preferable. The president allowed the law to be enacted Oct. 28 without his signature, saying he doubts it is constitutional. David Cole, a lawyer representing protesters who burned flags, said he was disappointed that the justices will decide the issue before the fall elections. Such speedy review ``is unfortunate, given the importance of the issue,'' he said. The controversy echoes themes from the 1988 presidential campaign in which Bush stressed patriotic values and attacked his Democratic opponent, Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, for vetoing state legislation to require that public school teachers lead their classes in the Pledge of Allegiance.

DOC.HEAD: President Messages Soviet Leader on Lithuania
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he doesn't expect Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev to reply to his confidental message on Lithuania, but just wanted ``to be sure the Soviets understand our position'' on the rebellious republic. Bush said Friday that he had sent the message to Gorbachev on the crisis to be ``sure there's no disconnect because of misinformation.'' ``Our views on the question of self-determination ... are well-known around the world, but I do not want to risk misunderstanding by failing to communicate,'' he told reporters during a picture-taking session at the White House. Later, while playing golf at the Marine Corps base in nearby Quantico, Va., the president was asked if he had heard anything back from Gorbachev. ``What I said doesn't, I don't think, require any answer,'' he replied. However, the Soviet president's latest views will no doubt be relayed to Bush during Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's visit to Washington next week. Bush said that his Thursday night message to Gorbachev _ given to the Soviet embassy here, which in turn relayed it to Moscow _ was in keeping with his policy of trying to ``stay in close touch with world leaders.'' ``I want to be sure the Soviets understand our position and understand that we're not trying to make things difficult for Lithuania or the Soviet Union or anybody else,'' he said. The president would not say exactly what he told the Soviet leader, telling reporters: ``If I told you what I told him it wouldn't be confidential.'' On Capitol Hill, Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., issued a strong warning to Gorbachev that contrasted with the administration's low-key diplomacy. If the Soviets use force against Lithuanian citizens, Dole said, ``The Soviets will be in real trouble here _ no trade agreements, no trade preferences and no more of the kind of relations the Kremlin is desperately seeking from Washington. It would be a severe blow to U.S.-Soviet relations.'' However, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the United States was continuing to call for a resolution of the dispute through dialogue and independence. ``We support Lithuanians in their desire to achieve self-determination. The real issue is how do we best get there,'' Baker said. The United States has never recognized the forced incorporation of Lithuania, or the other Baltic states of Estonia and Latvia, into the Soviet Union in 1940. At the same time, it has not extended formal diplomatic recognition to Lithuania in the aftermath of Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence, which Moscow considers illegal. Over the past week, the administration has strongly warned against the use of Soviet force to thwart Lithuanian independence and issued appeals for restraint on both sides. Bush's message was his first written contact with Gorbachev since tensions began escalating with Lithuania's March 11 declaration to secede from the Soviet Union. ``I want to be sure that the Soviets understand our position and understand that we're not trying to make things difficult for Lithuania or the Soviet Union or anybody else,'' the president said. A senior administration official, meantime, said Gorbachev appears to be under ``considerable domestic pressure'' because of the Lithuanian crisis. ``It isn't in anybody's interest to have this thing blow up,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. In a related development, the Pentagon said Friday that Gen. Carl Vuono, the Army chief of staff, has postponed a week-long trip to the Soviet Union that was scheduled to begin next week. ``It just was felt that it isn't a good time to go,'' said spokeswoman Maj. Kathy Wood. She said the four-star general had been slated to leave Saturday for Helsinki, Finland, and travel to Moscow on Monday. Visits to Kiev and Leningrad were also on the schedule.

DOC.HEAD: British Stunt Team to Perform in Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: The Royal Air Force stunt-flying team will make its first trip to the Soviet Union in June. The team, known as the Red Arrows, will perform in Kiev June 23-24 as part of a monthlong British festival and trade fair, the Royal Air Force announced Friday. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher will visit the festival, but no specific date has been announced, a spokesman said. ``This is part of the important process of developing our contacts with the Soviet Union,'' said a Royal Air Force spokesman. ``It is hoped that it will be followed by further such visits to Eastern Europe in due course.'' Officials are considering opportunities for the team of nine bright-red British Aerospace Hawk jets to perform elsewhere in the Soviet Union during the visit, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Kentucky School Bill Turns State Into Laboratory of Reform
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Kentucky, a state hardly type-cast as a hotbed of school reform, suddenly finds itself in the forefront of national educational change, thrust into that unaccustomed role by a sweeping court order. Last June, the state Supreme Court declared Kentucky's system of public schooling inequitable and unconstitutional. It ordered the legislature to come up with an entirely new system of school governance and finance. On Thursday, the legislature passed a 900-page bill aimed at smoothing out the inequities between rich and poor local school districts through a $1.26 billion package of state tax increases. Gov. Wallace Wilkinson is expected to sign the measure, perhaps today. The result: The state will establish a minimum spending level of $2,900 for each of Kentucky's 570,000 students. Under the current system, spending varies from $1,800 to $4,200 a year per student, depending on each district's wealth or poverty. ``We're going to do innovative things in Kentucky for once,'' said state Rep. Greg Stumbo, the Democratic majority floor leader. ``We're not going to be a follower any more. We're going to be a leader.'' While undoubtedly important to Kentuckians, the school finance changes mandated by the bill are not what is most eye-catching to those concerned with national school reform. Kentucky, after all, is just one of 11 states where courts in recent years have ordered overhauls of inequitable school finance systems. (The other states: New Jersey, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming, Arkansas and Montana.) What's really radical is how Kentucky's new system will change the state's relationships with local districts _ and eventually, perhaps, those in other states as well. ``Other (reform) attempts started in the nation have only dealt with funding. None have been as massive as Kentucky's was and none have been as influential as Kentucky's will be,'' predicted David Allen, president of the the Kentucky Education Association, the state's largest teacher group. Under the new system, the state Department of Education would set broad goals that all local districts would have to fulfill. Those would include development of critical thinking skills, the ability to apply concepts from math, the sciences, the arts, humanities and social studies, and ensuring that students become sufficient and responsible members of a family, work group or community. Districts, in turn, would gain unprecedented control over curriculum and other day-to-day operations. And the state would require at least one school per district to adopt ``site-based management.'' Those schools would form committees consisting of the principal and teacher and parent representatives empowered to make decisions on curriculum and other matters. ``The legacy of this act will be how it changes local and state relationships,'' said Kent McGuire, a school finance expert for the Education Commission of the States based in Denver. To ensure that local districts were meeting Kentucky's education goals, the state would manage a system of rewards including cash for improving schools, and punishments for failing ones _ including shutting down bad schools and firing teachers. The idea of giving schools and local districts more power to govern themselves as long as they meet state-set goals is very much in line with what leading reformers have been urging lately. But Kentucky's plan still leaves unsolved a great unanswered question educators everywhere are grappling with: how to fairly measure student and school progress. Details are still being worked out, but the bill would have the state measure school improvement using, among other things, attendance and dropout rates, and student test scores. Some worry that Kentucky could rely too heavily on standardized test scores for rewarding or punishing schools. That, they say, would lead teachers to ``teach to the test.'' ``It would be unfortunate if the system of state rewards and punishments were to turn solely on performance on standardized multiple choice examinations, because that would, in my opinion, pervert the educational process,'' said Arthur Wise of the Rand Corp. in Washington who has written extensively on school finance issues. ``My own research reveals that when you turn the screws on, teachers will do what is necessary to make sure that their children and therefore, they, look good,'' said Wise.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Lee Mitgang has covered education for the AP since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Newman: Deli Owner Made No Significant Contribution to Food Companies
DOC.TEXT: Paul Newman testified Friday he never considered giving stock in his food companies to Julius Gold because the delicatessen owner did not make any meaningful contributions to help launch the companies. ``Mr. Gold had not made a significant contribution in the past, and there was no indication he would make a significant contribution in the future,'' Newman said at his trial in Bridgeport Superior Court. Gold is suing Newman and his charity food companies, claiming he was promised 8 percent of the stock for his assistance in launching the firms eight years ago. Gold says he made introductions, attended meetings and performed other services to help form Salad King Inc. and Newman's Own Inc. Newman says Gold's only contribution was selling some of the dressing in his deli when Salad King was launched in 1982. And while the actor once considered giving some stock to four friends who helped the companies, Newman said he held on to the stock to assure the profits go to charity. ``I was always concerned that somebody else could gain control of the enterprise and exploit it,'' the Academy Award-winning actor said. Newman's Westport-based food companies make salad dressing, spaghetti sauce, popcorn and lemonade. Newman launched the venture in 1982 with friend and novelist A.E. Hotchner as a lark to sell the dressing they had been making in Newman's Westport home. Since then, the companies have made $28 million in profits, all of which have gone to charity. Newman has also used the funds to found The Hole In The Wall Gang Camp, a camp in Ashford, Conn., for children with life-threatening diseases. Newman's testimony continued Friday under cross-examination by Gold's attorney, Richard Albrecht, who has tried to show his client is the only person who contributed to the companies but never got anything for his efforts. Albrecht asked Newman if he got power from donating company profits to charity. ``I don't know if I get power. I get satisfaction out of that,'' Newman said. ``If you're talking about getting Red China into the United Nations, I don't have that power.'' ``There are different uses of power,'' he said later under direct examination by his lawyer, W. Patrick Ryan. ``If you are fortunate enough to have a company like this, you can either take that money and stick it in your pocket, or you can go out and give it to people who are less fortunate _ or with the camp, to children with life-threatening diseases who may not live past the age of 11 or 12.'' Newman's testimony over Thursday and Friday lasted more than three hours. The trial itself should wrap up sometime next week.

DOC.HEAD: Nominee Faces Senate Floor Fight
DOC.TEXT: With disclosure of past drug use a possible complication, President Bush's nominee to regulate the nation's savings and loans faces a confirmation fight on the Senate floor next week. By an 11-10 vote Friday, T. Timothy Ryan Jr. barely won the endorsement of the Senate Banking Committee to become director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. The drug issue did not arise in the committee meeting. But hours later, after an NBC News report, the administration confirmed that the 44-year-old attorney told FBI background investigators that he used marijuana and cocaine on a few occasions in the early 1970s. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said the administration knew of Ryan's admission and that the Senate committee had voted ``in full knowledge of these same facts.'' He said Ryan still had the administration's confidence. NBC said some senators were privately troubled by Ryan's past drug use, although none raised the issue publicly. Two Democrats joined the committee's nine Republicans in backing Ryan. Ten Democrats opposed him, complaining he had no experience in banking. ``Sorting through the aftermath of the savings and loan collapse will (be) the single most demanding and difficult financial job in our country. So obviously we want someone of a towering size and capacity to tackle that assignment,'' said the panel's chairman, Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., who opposed the nomination. Nevertheless, Riegle, D-Mich., said he hoped the full Senate could act swiftly on the nomination _ perhaps on Wednesday, the day after senators are expected to complete a clean air bill. The administration has been under pressure to appoint a thrift director since March 21, when a federal judge ruled the agency lacked constitutional authority to seize troubled institutions. The U.S. Court of Appeals has delayed the ruling until April 11 and the administration wants a Senate-confirmed thrift director in office before then. Ryan, an attorney who specializes in pension and employee benefit law, would replace M. Danny Wall, who resigned under fire for his handling of the collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. Following the NBC report, Ryan issued a statement saying: ``Prior to my nomination I disclosed both on my FBI form and verbally to the White House, Treasury and the FBI that early in the 1970s I smoked marijuana on a few occasions and tried cocaine once, perhaps twice. ``I regret this mistake. I do not regret having voluntarily disclosed this information,'' he said. Treasury Secretary Brady said in his own statement, ``The incidents were limited and a long time ago. We knew about this issue because the nominee voluntarily disclosed this information. We believe Mr. Ryan is well qualified and his nomination deserves the Senate's full support.'' Democrats said Ryan's inexperience in the S&L field would force him to rely on guidance from the Treasury Department rather than exercise independent judgment. They complained he had no opinion on such basic issues as financial standards for S&Ls and whether the thrift industry has a future. The administration countered by portraying Ryan as an experienced manager and tough enforcer who as solicitor of the Labor Department from 1981 to 1983 supervised 600 attorneys and helped clean up corruption in the Teamsters union's Central States Pension Fund. Sen. Jake Garn of Utah, the senior Republican on the committee, conceded that Ryan lacked experience but argued that conflict-of-interest rules and post-employment restrictions have grown so tight that the administration had a very difficult time finding a candidate with more relevant qualifications. ``We may reach a point where Mother Teresa is the only person we can confirm to any position in the federal government,'' Garn said. Riegle had predicted Thursday evening that his panel would reject Ryan, but several members said Brady made impassioned pleas on the nominee's behalf. Democratic Sens. Terry Sanford of North Carolina and Richard Shelby of Alabama ended up joining Republicans in support of the nomination. Sanford told reporters Ryan was a personal friend whom he knew through the American Council of Young Political Leaders. Shelby, who said he was prepared to vote against Ryan as late as Thursday night, said Friday that he thought the full Senate should have a chance to vote, adding, ``The job needs to be filled.'' In addition to his Labor Department service, Ryan has extensive political experience. He served in the presidential campaigns of Richard Nixon in 1972, Gerald Ford in 1976 and George Bush in 1988. He was a legal counsel to Ronald Reagan's 1980 transition team.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Government Imposes Censorship on Reporters
DOC.TEXT: The government has ordered journalists to submit for review all reports on fighting between its forces and rebels in eastern Nimba County. State radio said the government gave the order Friday because of ``inaccurate and incorrect'' news reports that created ``fear and anxiety.'' The reports must be submitted to the Ministry of Information. Anti-government rebels invaded this West African nation from neighboring Ivory Coast in December. They now have reportedly pushed out of Nimba County toward the capital, Monrovia, about 120 miles to the southwest. Western diplomats say hundreds of people, including many civilians, have been killed by government troops sent to crush the uprising. More than 150,000 people have fled the fighting, mostly by crossing into Guinea or Ivory Coast.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Accuses 35 Countries of Erecting Unfair Trade Barriers
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, firing a new salvo in a stepped-up campaign to reduce America's huge trade deficit, is accusing 35 nations of erecting unfair barriers that block sales of U.S. exports. A list released Friday focused on countries running large trade surpluses with the United States, led by Japan, whose $49 billion surplus accounted for nearly half of the $109 billion trade imbalance last year. The Japanese took up 19 pages in the 214-page report, with the alleged infractions running the gamut from prohibitions against the sale of American rice to barriers against U.S.-made semiconductors. Other countries with a long list of alleged barriers were Taiwan, Canada, West Germany, South Korea and China. All have large trade surpluses with the United States. Barriers erected by smaller trading partners were targeted as well, ranging from soybean taxes in Argentina to restrictive agricultural quotas in Yugoslavia. The 1990 edition of the trade barriers report, prepared by U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, is the first step in drawing up a ``hit list'' of priority countries the administration will target for intensive negotiations aimed at getting the offending barriers eliminated. The administration, by law, is required to issue its priority list by April 30. A year ago, 34 nations were cited in the initial trade barriers report. From that list, three countries _ Japan, Brazil and India _ ended up on the priority list as targets for possible retaliation. While officials are hopeful that negotiations with Japan and Brazil will succeed in eliminating barriers, talks so far with India have made no progress. In the case of Japan, negotiators are working against a June 16 deadline for opening markets to U.S. exports of space satellites, supercomputers and wood products. Negotiators announced a breakthrough a week ago in the supercomputer talks and worked through the day Friday seeking agreement in the area of satellite sales. However, members of Congress said even if Japan does make progress in the areas targeted last year, other Japanese barriers should be cited this year. ``Until the long list of barriers that U.S. business faces in Japan is cut down substantially, the United States must keep up the pressure on Japan to open its market,'' said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., chairman of the Senate trade subcommittee. Joshua Bolten, general counsel in the trade representative's office, refused to speculate on what countries might be put on this year's priority list. However, other officials said they expected the administration to again significantly pare down the number of countries picked for intensive negotiations. The requirement for a target list of countries, known as the ``Super 301'' provision, was the most controversial and feared section of the 1988 Omnibus Trade Act. All of the countries named Friday for their trade barriers had been included in last year's initial assessment as well, with the exception of Israel. Israel was cited this year for, among other things, restrictive licensing practices used to keep American goods out of the country. The countries included in the new report are: Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, China, Colombia, Egypt, West Germany, Finland, France, Greece, India, Indonesia, Israel, Italy, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Nigeria, Norway, Pakistan, the Philippines, Portugal, South Korea, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Taiwan, Thailand, Turkey, the United Kingdom, Venezuela and Yugoslavia. Two trading blocs were also cited: the 12-nation European Community and the Gulf Cooperation Council, which includes Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. In addition to the talks on specific barriers to trade, the United States and Japan are conducting separate negotiations to address economic shortcomings in both nations that contribute to the trade imbalance. Those talks, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, will resume in Washington on Monday. The Japanese are pushing for stronger efforts on the part of the United States to reduce its budget deficit and restrain consumer spending. American negotiators want an end to various exclusionary business practices that favor Japanese companies at the expense of foreign competitors.

DOC.HEAD: Paintings Accepted For Taxes
DOC.TEXT: British officials have accepted a 17th century Dutch painting to satisfy tax liabilities of $4.5 million, Arts Minister Richard Luce says. The Jan Van der Heyden landscape, ``View of the Westerkerk,'' will be exhibited at the National Gallery at Trafalgar Square in London, Luce said Friday. British news reports said the agreement involved the $152 million estate of Dorothy de Rothschild, who died in December 1988 at the age of 93. She was the head of the Rothschild charities in Israel. The Westerkerk is the church in Amsterdam, where the painter Rembrandt is buried. The painting hung in the church's meeting room for 200 years until the Rothschild family purchased it in the late 1800s. ``It was Mrs. de Rothschild's express wish that the picture should come to the National Gallery,'' said a spokeswoman at the museum. Luce said another work, ``Richmond Near London,'' painted by Frenchman Jean-Baptiste Camille Corot in 1862, was accepted in lieu of tax liabilities of $593,000 on Mrs. de Rothschild's estate. No decision has been made about where that painting will hang, Luce said.

DOC.HEAD: Crossing Guard Accused of Shooting at Student
DOC.TEXT: A school crossing guard who allegedly shot twice at a student was charged with attempted murder and ordered to undergo psychiatric tests, police said. The student was unharmed. James F. Murphy, 40, shot at Clinton Drake III, 14, from about six feet away on Friday but missed, then fired again but his .25-caliber semiautomatic pistol jammed, police said. ``He was laughing and shaking,'' Drake said. ``He was laughing like he was happy. I was thinking, `Is he going to kill me or is he fooling with me? ``Then he pointed the gun at my chest and fired and missed,'' Drake said. ``I saw the smoke and the shell pop out the side. Then he pulled the trigger again.'' Police said they recovered a pistol and 50 rounds of ammunition when they arrested Murphy in a convenience store parking lot shortly after the incident. Police Chief Michael Chitwood said police were investigating a possible racial motive. Drake, a student in the Portland Rehabilitation Education Program, is black. Murphy is white. Drake said that on Thursday, Murphy yelled a racial insult at him. When Drake met Murphy again Friday, Drake told him to avoid racial slurs. Murphy was arraigned in Superior Court on an attempted murder charge and ordered held in jail pending psychiatric evaluation.

DOC.HEAD: US Talking To Soviets Over Repeal of Zionism-Racism Amendment
DOC.TEXT: U.S. representatives have met with mid-level Soviet officials four times in a so-far unsuccessful effort to get the Kremlin's help in repealing a 1975 United Nations resolution that equates racism and Zionism, a State Department official says. ``Several discussions that we have held with the Soviets at the U.N., in Moscow and here in Washington on the issue of `Zionism is racism' unfortunately have failed to produce agreement for a concerted approach toward repealing the resolution,'' John R. Bolton, assistant secretary of state for international organization affairs, said Friday. Bolton said the dialogue would continue, adding that ``the Soviets have assured us that the resolution represents a concept that is no longer acceptable, according to the new political thinking in the Soviet Union.'' He testified before the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Near Eastern and South Asian affairs, which is considering a joint resolution calling on all the U.N. member countries to repeal General Assembly Resolution 3379. Zionism, the movement to re-establish and support a Jewish national state in the biblical homeland of Israel, is opposed by Israel's Arab neighbors and their allies. Meanwhile, the United States is talking with U.N. member nations, and would like to take action on the issue when the General Assembly reconvenes in the fall, Bolton said. However, he said, it won't take the matter to the floor unless repeal is assured. The United States has been consulting with countries that originally voted for Resolution 3379 ``but which have subsequently acquired new governments and new thinking,'' Bolton told the subcommittee. ``Once again, our consultations are far from over, but we have seen substantial evidence of shifts of opinion,'' he said, citing indications from Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Mexico. The United States is also talking with countries that abstained or were absent for the 1975 vote or which joined the United Nations later, Bolton said. Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., the subcommittee chairman, asked Bolton to produce a list of those countries that voted for Resolution 3379 and which also receive direct U.S. aid. ``Have we ever told one country _ just one country _ that you're getting American money but you're not going to get any more unless you change your mind?'' Moynihan asked. Bolton said he did not know. Meanwhile, a resolution reaffirming the U.S. Congress' support for a unified Jerusalem unanimously passed the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Friday. That resolution, introduced by Rep. Eliot Engel, D-N.Y., follows recent remarks by President Bush that the United States opposes new settlements of Soviet Jews in East Jerusalem.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: ``Predator II'' movie director Stephen Hopkins says he's sorry for yanking an earplug from musician-actor Ruben Blades and ordering him back to work during a live television interview. Startled ``Good Morning America'' host Joan Lunden said the incident Thursday morning was the first time an interview had ended so rudely in her 10 years on the show. Lunden was interviewing Blades when Hopkins walked onto the set and told an embarrassed Blades it was time to begin shooting. Hopkins stood in front of the ABC-TV camera and ordered Blades back to the set. Hopkins and Blades came back on ``Good Morning America'' on Friday, and Hopkins apologized. ``This is the face behind the monster,'' Hopkins said. ``I was waiting for him and waiting for him until I went out to get him. Sometimes I get a bit carried away. ``Unfortunately, I interrupted your interview and I apologize for that. And I kind of humiliated Ruben, too, on national television, which is kind of a dumb thing to do.'' Blades said he was asked later why he didn't slap the director. ``Why would I have made a situation which was already awkward more difficult?'' said the salsa music star. ``I'm a musician for 15 years. I've played through riots and everything you can imagine. ``I figured let someone be professional here.''

Former President Carter said he is unsure whether he has done more in his recent humanitarian activities than he did while in the White House. But he is sure of this: ``I will never run for office again under any circumstances.'' Carter told the Atlanta Press Club on Friday that as a private citizen he can do things he could not do as president, such as meeting with revolutionary leaders. As representative of the United States he would be barred from talking to forces trying to oust an established government. He cited the Panama Canal treaties, the Camp David accord between Israel and Egypt and normalization of relations with China as among his top presidential achievements. But he also noted his efforts through the Carter Center to rid Africa of the debilitating Guinea worm, which afflicts 10 million people a year. ``If in 1996 we find that where there were 10 million cases of Guinea worm there are none, I would say the Guinea worm is more important,'' he said.

Zsa Zsa Gabor thinks she has completed her sentence of 120 community service hours for slapping a cop, but a judge is skeptical. Municipal Judge Charles Rubin on Friday ordered the director of a homeless shelter for women to produce documents ``describing in full all of Ms. Gabor's services.'' The judge's letter was prompted by one from Vera Davis, executive director of the Low Income Elderly United-Community Assistance Program. Davis stated Gabor had ``fully'' completed her service at the shelter. But Gabor, in a newspaper report published Monday, said she had put in only 50 hours at the shelter and would complete the remainder by sponsoring a June 8 benefit auction for the center. Not good enough, said Deputy District Attorney Elden Fox. ``I'm going to make her work at the shelter for 120 hours,'' Fox said. ``The implication to me is that Judge Rubin wanted that, too.'' If Davis cannot provide the documentation, Fox said, she may have to testify under oath. Gabor's mouthy outbursts during her cop-slapping trial last year prompted stern recriminations from the judge. She was convicted on three criminal counts for her run-in with Beverly Hills policeman Paul Kramer. He testified that Gabor swore, spit and slapped him during a routine traffic stop.

An armed woman who allegedly harassed actress Sharon Gless for years surrendered peacefully at the star's home after a seven-hour standoff with police in which she threatened to kill herself. Joni Leigh Penn, 30, was quickly handcuffed and led to a police car outside Miss Gless' Studio City home Friday after she had put down a loaded .22-caliber semiautomatic rifle, said police Capt. Dan Watson. Ms. Penn, who in the past had threatened to kill the star of ``Cagney and Lacey'' TV series, was taken to the North Hollywood police station, where Watson said she would be booked for investigation of armed burglary, a felony. ``She surrendered voluntarily. She was tired. She was just kind of worn down,'' said Watson, who described Ms. Penn as an obsessed fan of Miss Gless. Miss Gless was not home during the incident. ``This has been going on for several years now, and I think has to be dealt with by the authorities,'' Miss Gless later said in a statement. Watson said Ms. Penn was also a suspect in an attempted burglary at the Gless home Monday night. Miss Gless obtained a court order in November 1988 requiring Ms. Penn to keep away from her. It appeared that until this week Ms. Penn had complied with the order, Watson said.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Calls for Reducing Federal Judges' Workloads
DOC.TEXT: A committee created by Congress is ending its 15-month study of the federal courts by recommending major reductions in the workloads of federal judges. In a 203-page report to be sent Monday to President Bush, Congress and Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, the panel included these recommendations: _Shift more drug cases from federal to state courts, and give state court systems the money needed to cope with the increased number of prosecutions resulting from the shift. _Transfer many of the disputes over Social Security benefits from the courts to administrative procedures and encourage similar out-of-court resolution of job-bias claims. _Create ``an office of judicial impact assessment'' within the federal court system to advise Congress about proposed laws and to point out ``drafting defects that might breed unnecessary litigation.'' _Repeal mandatory minimum sentencing provisions now in effect for numerous federal crimes, and have the U.S. Sentencing Commission redraft guidelines that would not be binding on federal judges. The committee said more federal judges are needed, but not above the number of new judgeships already requested. It also said that the federal court workload is at a much more critical level in appellate, rather than trial, courts. The report said Congress and the president should fill judicial vacancies and approve requested additions quickly. But it added, ``The committee does not regard additional judgeships as a long-term solution.'' Discussing the judicial fallout from the Bush administration's war on drugs, the report said, ``Minor drug cases find their way into federal court because Congress has provided funds for federal and not for state prosecutions. ``Some of the funds that Congress has approved for drug enforcement should be used to provide assistance for drug enforcement at the critical state and local level,'' it added. The committee opposed creation of a proposed national appeals court that would serve as a buffer between the 12 regional federal appeals courts and the Supreme Court. But the report recommended that Congress authorize an unusual five-year experiment as an alternative. It would allow the Supreme Court to resolve conflicting rulings among two federal appeals courts by ordering a third appeals court to tackle the same issue and render a nationally binding decision. The third court's ruling would be final unless the Supreme Court granted a rehearing. The committee's report is a response to what committee members called ``mounting public and professional concern with the federal courts' congestion, delay, expense and expansion.'' The 15-member committee was led by Joseph F. Weis Jr., a federal appeals court judge from Pittsburgh. It included other judges, lawyers and law professors.

DOC.HEAD: Gunshots Fired at Helicopter, Injure Passenger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The helicopter ...', with 3 grafs to CORRECT name to Ganienkeh Mohawk Territory sted Indian Territory, UPDATE with roadblocks at reservation entrances. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `Bill McDermott ...'
DOC.TEXT: Gunfire from the ground hit a military helicopter on a medical flight Friday, wounding a doctor and prompting the pilot to make an emergency landing. The Vermont Army National Guard helicopter was fired on three times at about 11:30 a.m. while on a flight from Burlington, Vt., to Massena, N.Y., to pick up a patient, said Lt. Lloyd Goodrow, Air National Guard spokesman. The helicopter was flying over the Ganienkeh Mohawk Territory in the town of Altona when the shots were fired, said state police Maj. Robert Leu. The Mohawk tribe doesn't recognize federal or state jurisdiction on the land. By late Friday, at least 20 state troopers and an undetermined number of guards from the New York state Department of Corrections had set up roadblocks to seal off the four entrances to the Indian territory, said Trooper Richard Garcia, a state police spokesman. He said no vehicles would be allowed to enter or leave the territory throughout the weekend. Bill McDermott, Assistant Special Agent in Charge of the FBI office in Albany, said it was ``too early to say'' who fired the shots or why. Passengers heard bullets punching through the UH-1 chopper and the pilots landed next to a highway when a warning light indicated a drop in oil pressure, authorities said. ``I didn't hear a gunshot per se, but I heard, obviously, bullets going through metal,'' said nurse Elma Rickards, who was sitting next to the man who was injured, Dr. James Van Kirk. ``And then the doctor that was sitting to my right said, `Oh my gosh, my arm is numb.' '' Rickards, still wearing blood-stained clothes at an evening news conference at the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont, said she immediately began attending to the doctor. Van Kirk, 27, a second-year resident, was taken to Champlain Valley Physicians Hospital an Plattsburgh, in northern New York state across Lake Champlain from Burlington. He was in stable condition with wounds in the neck and shoulder, said Bart Hayes, emergency department manager at the hospital. Three bullets apparently struck the helicopter, two penetrating the fuselage and one hitting the tail rotor, authorities said. A crew member spoke of seeing someone on the porch of a house firing at the craft, Rickards reported. Rickards and Van Kirk were being taken to pick up a patient from Massena Memorial Hospital, 55 miles west of Plattsburgh, Banks said. Also aboard were three military crew members. Wet snow and rain had forced the pilot to abort the mission, and the helicopter was en route to the Plattsburgh area.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Republic of Estonia Votes for Independence
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Estonia has formally declared its intention of seeking independence from the Soviet Union, but it took a more conciliatory approach than Lithuania and set no timetable for the break with Moscow. Soviet annexation of independent Estonia in 1940 ``did not end the existence of the Estonian Republic,'' Estonian lawmakers said Friday in a resolution. ``The Estonian Republic is still occupied today.'' The vote in Estonia's Supreme Soviet was 75-0 with three abstentions. The move put Estonia on the path toward a possible confrontation with the Kremlin, but not as directly as Lithuania. The Lithuanians declared outright independence on March 11, and they have been locked in a tense standoff with the Kremlin since. Estonian legislators set no independence date. They agreed to establish full independence only at the end of an undefined transition period. During the transition, Estonia would work out its own future government structure and settle differences with Moscow. The three Baltic republics of Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia have been under Moscow's control since they were crushed by Soviet forces 50 years ago on the eve of World War II. Like Lithuania and Latvia, Estonia gained independence from the ruins of the Russian Empire at the end of World War I, but it was annexed by Josef Stalin in 1940. The official Soviet news agency Tass said Estonia ``proclaimed the beginning of restoration of the Estonian republic, announcing a transitional period which will be completed with the formation of the Estonian republic's constitutional agencies of state power.'' Independent deputy Mart Laar said the session was broadcast live on television and radio. He said streets of the capital, Tallinn, were nearly deserted because everyone was indoors following the proceedings. Laar said in a telephone interview that deputies in the 105-member legislature who represent mainly Russian-speaking districts boycotted the vote but did not walk out of the hall. He did not know how many deputies refrained from voting, but about a quarter of the Supreme Soviet is made up of Russians, Ukrainians and other non-Estonians who generally oppose independence. The legislature was elected March 18 in competitive voting that gave pro-independence forces a strong hand in this small republic of 1.6 million people on the Gulf of Finland. Estonia's Communist Party declared its independence from the main Soviet Communist Party on Sunday. It said the split would be formalized in October. Laar said many deputies support declaring independence from Moscow at about the same time. He said the length of the transition period will be set and new leaders for the republic will be elected when the Supreme Soviet resumes work Monday. Estonia initially took the lead in the Baltic autonomy drive by declaring its right to veto Soviet laws in November 1988. Since then, however, it has been overtaken by Lithuania's more radical approach. Estonian activists say they want to organize Estonia's economic system and government before independence. They also say they must move slower than Lithuania because they do not have such a large ethnic majority in Estonia. Lithuanians make up 80 percent of their republic, but only 60 percent of Estonia's people are ethnic Estonians. Latvia, wedged between Estonia and Lithuania, is only about 50 percent ethnic Latvian. It is moving more slowly than its two neighbors.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Publisher Wins Final Vindication
DOC.TEXT: History and the passage of more than 40 years have finally left Jeno Szebedinzsky, late in his life, a winner. Since the late 1940s, Szebedinszky has been an exile, settling into an adopted country while stubbornly carrying a torch for his native Hungary. During all those years, first in Pittsburgh and recently in Indiana, Szebedinszky published a small Hungarian language newspaper that struggled to preserve Hungarian culture among his fellow emigrants and battle the authoritarian regime that ruled his homeland. ``I love America. I want to be, and maybe I am, a good American,'' he said in the basement where he punches the text of his eight-page paper into a video display terminal. ``But my home, my mother home, is Hungary. That lives in our souls.'' The sudden collapse of authoritarian regimes across Eastern Europe surprised Szebedinszky as much as anyone. Now with the Iron Curtain corroded by acid anger of citizens demanding political and economic reform, Szebedinszky feels vindicated in his loyalty. Through the early 1950s, he dreamed of returning to Hungary to publish his newspaper. The revolt of 1956 brought a few summer days of promise before Soviet tanks in the streets of Budapest crushed the uprising. His hopes of an early end to exile were dashed But his vigor and determination as a publisher were not. He proudly tells of wearing out three linotype machines publishing in Pittsburgh, being part of an energetic Hungarian-language press that included some 50 newspapers across the country, many published daily. ``We were working against the communists,'' he said. The work has not rewarded his finances. The paper's circulation, never large, has slipped to about 2,000 readers who pay 85 cents per copy. An issue may carry less than a half page of paid advertising. ``I am a very bad businessman,'' he admitted. And he finds himself among a shrinking corps of Hungarian stalwarts who have resisted the profits of assimilation into American culture. Although he still speaks of returning to Hungary, he acknowledged that many others who once lived as exiles have no such interest. They live now wholly as Americans, with family and fortunes firmly rooted in land no longer so new. After the death of his wife, Amalia, two years ago, Szebedinszky gave up his Pittsburgh home and moved to South Bend, where his son, Janos, works as an executive for a book publishing firm. ``I've got nothing anymore,'' he said without a hint of self-pity. ``Just this,'' he said, waving at his small publishing setup. ``And this one,'' he said, glancing at Janos. ``My job is not hard,'' Szebedinszky said. ``I never work. I enjoy doing it.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief Meeting With Salvadoran Gov't, Rebels in Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of El Salvador's government and its leftist rebels will meet for peace talks Wednesday with U.N. chief Javier Perez de Cuellar, U.N. and Salvadoran officials say. The rightist Salvadoran government confirmed the announcement of the talks, set for Geneva. In making the announcement Friday, U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani gave no details concerning representatives, the agenda, the format or length of the meetings. Negotiations between the U.S.-backed conservative government and rebels broke off in November after a union headquarters was bombed and the guerrillas launched an offensive in San Salvador, the capital. U.N. officials cited a Central American peace plan, the free elections in Nicaragua in February and plans to disarm the Nicaraguan Contra rebels as events that have created a positive atmosphere for ending the decade-old civil war. In Caracas, Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez and Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani declared Friday that ``peace is just around the corner'' in the war, in which more than 71,000 people, mostly civilians, have been killed. Cristiani and rebel representatives have met separately with Perez de Cuellar in the past two weeks. In San Salvador, the government expressed ``its hope that, through the dialogue to be renewed under the auspices of Perez de Cuellar, the country's pacification, which is the most sincere desire of the government and people, may be achieved.'' Government spokesman Mauricio Sandoval told a news conference: ``It should be clear that the dialogue itself is between the government and the (rebels), without mediation and without the intervention of elements foreign to the country's situation.'' It is the latest peace initiative by Perez de Cueller, a Peruvian, to bring together two warring sides in a regional conflict. His other efforts have included Afghanistan, the Iran-Iraq war and Cyprus.

DOC.HEAD: Jury to Get Iran-Contra Case Monday
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS lead to clarify jury's action
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: A jury will begin deliberating next week whether John Poindexter did his best to give Congress the facts in the Iran-Contra affair or engaged in what the prosecution called ``a rampage of destruction'' to cover up the scandal. In closing arguments Friday that followed three weeks of testimony, prosecutor Dan Webb ridiculed the defense case and criticized former President Reagan's bias in favor of his one-time national security adviser. Poindexter destroyed a presidential document because it would have exposed his alleged lies to Congress, said Webb. In November 1986, he said, the document was the one piece of paper that ``puts the lie'' to Reagan's assertion then that there had been no trade of weapons to Iran for American hostages in Lebanon. ``You don't lie to the American public,'' Webb said of Reagan's speech. The presidential document ratified CIA assistance to a Nov. 25, 1985, shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Poindexter destroyed it hours after telling Congress the president hadn't approved the shipment. But defense attorney Richard Beckler said the document, known as a finding, was incomplete and incorrect. ``The only one of those findings that counted'' was a later one that spelled out U.S. efforts to make contact with moderate political elements in Iran, he said. Beckler said Poindexter was the first Reagan administration official to disclose the missile shipment to Congress and did ``his ever-loving best to give as much information as he could tell'' to lawmakers. This was ``not some grimy little conspiracy'' involving Poindexter, the lawyer insisted. Poindexter ``was working for the president of the United States.'' Webb said Poindexter tore up the finding on Nov. 21, 1986, amid a ``rampage of destruction'' carried out by his aide, Oliver North, and North's secretary, Fawn Hall. Poindexter's subordinates shredded computer messages and altered documents. The ``rampage'' was carried out by North and Hall at the direction of former national security adviser Robert McFarlane, ``but not Admiral Poindexter,'' who didn't know about it, said Beckler. The alterations hid North's military assistance to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. A day or so before he resigned, Webb said, Poindexter destroyed 5,000 messages in his computer after North called him and said Attorney General Edwin Meese III had confronted him. North had admitted the diversion to Meese and Congress was inquiring about the Iran initiative. Beckler said it was routine practice for departing employees of the National Security Council to delete computer messages. Webb said the evidence the defense put on was ``largely irrelevant,'' with Reagan, who gave a videotaped deposition played at the trial, being made to recite his contacts with foreign leaders to help the Contras. The prosecutor said the former president was biased in favor of Poindexter and said he became ``a little bit angry'' when he saw Reagan wink at his ex-national security adviser on the tape. ``I would have expected more of a former president,'' said Webb. Webb said North had been generally instructed by Poindexter to lie to the House intelligence committee by denying he was giving military advice to the Contras. North testified that Poindexter sent him to the meeting but said it was his own decision to lie. North ``deceived, he obstructed, he did everything he could to make certain Congress didn't find out what he was doing,'' said Webb. Poindexter sent North a note five days later saying, ``Well done.'' ``He is congratulating him, thanking him for having lied to Congress,''' said the prosecutor. ``He can't send North to Congress to lie, congratulate him when he gets done lying and escape legal responsibility for what he has done,'' Webb said of Poindexter. Poindexter is charged with conspiracy and two counts each of obstructing Congress and making false statements to Congress. The jury will receive the case after hearing instructions Monday from U.S. District Judge Harold Greene.

DOC.HEAD: Cause, Extent of Damage to Libyan Chemical Weapons Plant Questioned
DOC.TEXT: The State Department is not ruling out the possibility that Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi may have set fire to a chemical weapons plant two weeks ago, according to published reports. ``I can't rule that out,'' spokesman Richard Boucher said Friday. He said it's possible Libya still may be able to produce chemical weapons at the plant 60 miles southwest of Tripoli. ``Important uncertainties remain regarding both the cause and extent of the damage at Rabta,'' said Boucher. ``Therefore no definitive conclusions have been reached.'' U.S. officials have received intelligence reports indicating that the fire might have been set by Gadhafi's agents to make it appear that their chemical weapons program had been put out of action, The New York Times and The Washington Post reported in today's editions. One report said truckloads of tires were brought to the plant and ignited on Gadhafi's orders, the newspapers reported. Boucher called for the dismantling of Rabta, without regard to how that was achieved. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, at a meeting of the Association of American Publishers here Friday, also said the plant was still there. ``It still has, presumably, some residual capabilities. How much it was damaged, obviously, we don't know yet. That's something that we'll look at very carefully,'' Cheney said during a question-and-answer session. Before the March 14 fire, U.S. intelligence analysts had concluded the plant was producing poison gas and nerve gas agents, as well as canisters to carry the deadly weapons to their targets. The day after the blaze, the White House and State Department said the plant appeared to be out of operation. ``We don't know the origins of the fire,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``We don't know if it was sabotage. ... Somebody could have knocked over a kerosene lamp or something.'' Gadhafi blamed the fire on West Germany, while the Libyan news agency, reporting two deaths in the blaze, suggested a U.S.-Israeli plot. U.S. officials declined to say whether the new assessment reflected a closer look at the facility, presumably by satellites, or whether Libya, with or without outside assistance, was able to manage some reconstruction. ``The U.S. government is reviewing all available evidence,'' Boucher said. ``Important uncertainties remain regarding both the cause and the extent of damage at Rabta. Therefore no definitive conclusions have been reached.'' He then added dramatically: ``The possibility remains that Libya can still produce chemical warfare agents.'' About two dozen countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, are known to have the capability to produce chemical weapons. None causes more concern to the U.S. government than Libya. Gadhafi has been accused of sponsoring terrorist attacks against U.S. and Israeli citizens and facilities. In retaliation, the United States bombed Tripoli and Benghazi in April 1986. However, President Bush and other U.S. officials denied any involvement in the Rabta fire, which occurred a week after the White House called for ``vigorous efforts'' to halt operations at the plant. CIA Director William Webster once described the plant as the world's largest chemical weapons factory. Gadhafi, however, has contended it produced pharmaceuticals.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Drops Reviews of Export Items With `Minimal Security Risk'
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon says it is dropping its export license review process for certain items deemed to have ``minimal security risk'' that may be headed to the Soviet Union or Eastern Europe. The reviews involve certain types of computers, medical equipment such as CAT scanners and equipment for cancer treatments, and other industrial items such as machine tools and telecommunications equipment, the Defense Department said in a statement Friday. The Pentagon said it was delegating its review authority in these areas to the Commerce Department. The change in procedure will not remove requirements for export licenses for the items, but shifts the review process to the Commerce Department, said an official familiar with the decision. That means the Commerce Department may issue the export licences without referring the export application to the Defense Department for review. The Pentagon has suggested that the change be implemented immediately, the statement said. The reviews are required for export items considered ``dual-use,'' meaning they could have both civilian and military applications. The move ``is based on our experience with items that we have approved after going through the review process,'' said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ``It eliminates bureaucracy.'' The Pentagon will continue to review licenses for items considered to have higher security applications, such as supercomputers. It will no longer review the export license requests for such computers as the IBM 3031, 4331 and 4341 series, considered on the low end of mainframe computer systems. However, export licenses for such computers as IBM's 4381 and 4370 series will continue to be reviewed by the Pentagon because they are on the higher end of mid-range computers, officials said. The authorization has also been shifted to Commerce for review of licenses for the temporary export of products that might be shown at exhibits and trade shows in Eastern Europe or the Soviet Union, the statement said. The change ``is intended to assist our exporting community and improve the competitive position of U.S. industry in international trade by expediting the licensing process in areas that involve minimal security risk,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Chernobyl Disaster Victims Go on Hunger Strike
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 victims of radiation in the Chernobyl nuclear accident have started a hunger strike to protest inadequate medical care, including shortages of drugs and hospital beds, the Tass news agency says. The news agency, quoting a report in the labor daily Trud, said about 120 people were fasting at the Institute of Medical Radiology. The institute is in the Ukrainian city of Kharkov, 400 miles southwest of Moscow. Another 280 radiation victims in nearby Izum threatened to join the strike if their demands were not met, Tass said. The news agency did not say when the strike began. Two political groups in the Ukraine, the Greens movement and a group calling itself Chernobyl, plan to picket the republic's nuclear power stations on the fourth anniversary of the disaster, according to the Interfax news agency, an affiliate of Radio Moscow. On April 26, 1986, a fire and explosion at the Chernobyl plant near Kiev in the Ukraine killed at least 31 people. Radioactive contamination affected millions of acres of land. Nearly 100,000 people were relocated because of the poisoned environment. The weekly Moscow News reported in November the death toll had reached more than 250, including victims who were working at the plant during the disaster and those who helped in the cleanup. A spokesman for the government agency responsible for the cleanup confirmed the figure of 250 dead but said only the long-recognized official death toll of 31 could be attributed directly to the accident. In Kiev, the Presidium of the Ukraine Supreme Soviet has designated April 26 ``Chernobyl Tragedy Day,'' Tass said Friday. The legislative body earlier this month voted to phase the station out of operation over the coming years. On Thursday, 140 Soviet children who suffered radiation exposure after the Chernobyl explosion arrived in Havana for medical treatement and tests. The children, ranging in age from 4 to 15, were greeted by Cuban President Fidel Castro, the Cuban news agency Prensa Latina reported Friday. Castro pledged to help another 10,000 children who Soviet doctors estimate were exposed to radiation, the Mexican government news service Notimex reported. Tass said 120 people in Kharkov were on a hunger strike as of Wednesday. Their demands were not new. They were first presented to the Congress of People's Deputies at its inaugural session in May 1989, then were sent to the Soviet and Ukrainian governments, trade unions and health ministries, Tass said. A resolution adopted by the regional Trade Unions Council said radiation victims should be given priority medical treatment, as well as the necessary drugs and food, the news agency said. ``However, organizations in charge of implementing the resolution have ignored the legitimate interests of Chernobyl victims, despite receiving a notice of a possible hunger strike as early as February,'' Tass said. It quoted a strike committee member as saying the fast ``will continue until the protesters receive guarantees from the Soviet leadership, or until the arrival of a special government commission.'' Tass gave no additional details of the conditions in which the patients were kept, except to cite the shortages of hospital beds and drugs. Both problems are common in the Soviet Union, where top-quality health care is hard to find, but the government had pledged that Chernobyl victims would be given priority. The Supreme Soviet legislature in Moscow is due to discuss benefits for Chernobyl victims April 22, Tass said. It quoted Trud as urging the Supreme Soviet to move the discussion up because of the hunger strike.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion Rocks Canton Train Station, Killing 5 and Injuring 30
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with five reported killed; picks up 4th pvs, `A policeman...'
DOC.TEXT: An explosion rocked a crowded train station in the southern Chinese city of Canton, killing five people and injuring more than 30, newspapers reported today. The blast occurred about Friday about 80 feet from the west gate of the station, which was crowded with people following the arrival of a train from Shanghai, the newspapers said. The reports said the cause of the explosion was unknown. City and provincial security officials sealed off the area and immediately launched an investigation. Morning newspapers reported three dead, but the afternoon Chinese-language New Evening Post said the toll had risen to five. A policeman was among those killed, the Chinese-language Wen Wei Po newspaper reported. Two residents of the British colony of Hong Kong, about 90 miles southeast of Canton, sustained slight injuries. Many of those injured were travelers from Shanghai and the southern province of Hunan, as well as Canton residents who went to the station to meet passengers.

DOC.HEAD: AARP to Close Credit Union
DOC.TEXT: The American Association of Retired Persons says it is closing its 2-year-old credit union because of a lack of interest from its members. AARP, the nation's largest organization for older Americans, said Friday that all savings would be protected in the phase-out, which still must be approved by the credit union's 90,000 members. The credit union's board of directors voted Thursday to recommend that it be closed by June 30. AARP spokesman Bob DeFillippo said the credit union offered its members three services _ credit cards, certificates of deposits and savings accounts _ but only the credit card attracted much interest. Overall, the credit union had $150 million in assets, he said. Under the AARP's plan, Bank One in Columbus, Ohio, will issue an AARP-sponsored Visa credit card that will be available to all AARP members. People who now have credit cards from the credit union will automatically become card holders through Bank One and be able to continue to use their existing cards, AARP said. In addition, members will get a check for the amount in their savings accounts, and certificates of deposit will be transferred to Bank One.

A former Unisys Corp. employee under investigation in the Pentagon procurement scandal of the 1980s has pleaded guilty to a felony count of filing a false income tax return. Frederick J. Carville of New Hartford, N.Y., entered the plea in the Operation Ill Wind case before U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton in Alexandria, Va., on Friday. He faces a maximum sentence of three years in prison and a fine of up to $100,000. The plea resulted from negotiations between the U.S. attorney's office and Carville's attorney, said Michael Costello, who heads the Washington field office of the Defense Department's criminal investigative service. Operation Ill Wind concerned allegations that defense contractors and consultants bribed Pentagon officials to obtain inside information that would give them a competitive advantage in obtaining multimillion dollar contracts. The investigation began in the summer of 1986 but was not revealed until June 1988 when federal agents executed dozens of search warrants nationwide. Numerous companies and individuals have pleaded guilty or have been convicted in the probe. Carville, a Unisys marketing representative, was responsible for getting business for the company at the Rome Air Development Center at Rome, N.Y., a government facility that does electronics research, primarily for the Air Force.
DOC.HEAD: Ag Says Farmers to Boost Corn Plantings
DOC.TEXT: Farmers say they intend to boost corn plantings to 74.8 million acres this spring, up 4 percent from last year and the most since 1986, according to the Agriculture Department. Soybean plantings are expected to drop 2 percent to 59.4 million acres, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said Friday. Except for last year, 1990 soybean plantings still would be the largest since 1986. Total wheat plantings for the 1990 harvest, including winter wheat planted last fall and spring-planted varieties, were forecast at about 77.6 million acres, up 1 percent from last year. According to USDA records, the all-wheat acreage would be the largest since 79.2 million acres were planted for the 1989 harvest. The 1990 winter wheat crop was reported planted on 57.2 million acres, up 4 percent from a year ago. But durum wheat planted this spring was indicated at 3.35 million acres, down 12 percent. Other types of spring wheat were estimated at 17 million acres, down 4 percent from last year. Farmers have been encouraged by relatively strong corn and wheat prices, as well as an easing of acreage requirements under federal commodity programs. In the case of soybeans, however, record world oilseed production has reduced prices from last season. The 1990 planting figures were based on an annual March survey of approximately 75,000 farmers to help determine how much land may be used for crops this year.

DOC.HEAD: Clash in Boat People Detention Center Leaves 1 Dead
DOC.TEXT: About 100 Vietnamese boat people armed with homemade weapons clashed today at a detention center, and a government spokesman said one man was killed and three people injured. It was the second violent incident in as many days in the crowded camps that house about 55,000 Vietnamese who fled their Communist homeland by boat for this British colony. About 40 boat people at the Whitehead detention center started a fire in front of a dormitory after some of those inside would not let them enter, said the government spokesman, Ricky Chan. The people outside then broke in and fought with Vietnamese living inside. About 100 Vietnamese clashed before security forces brought the situation under control an hour later. One man, about 25, died of head injuries and three other Vietnamese were taken to a hospital in fair condition, Chan said. Thirty-one people were detained after the incident, which involved boat people from the northern Vietnamese port of Haiphong, but the cause of the fight was unclear, Ish Bhagat, a top official managing the detention centers, told local radio. On Friday night, about 100 Vietnamese battled at the Shek Kong detention center, injuring two boat people, who were taken to hospital in serious condition. Many of the boat people face repatriation against their will under a harsh policy adopted by Hong Kong in 1988. In December, a first group of 51 Vietnamese were forcibly returned to their homeland, leading to an increase in tension in the camps.

DOC.HEAD: Tanks of Diesel Fuel Drop into Lake Baikal
DOC.TEXT: A truck carrying 2,900 gallons of diesel fuel over Siberia's frozen Lake Baikal has sunk through a fissure in the ice and may pollute the lake that holds one-fifth of the world's fresh water, Tass reports. Leakage from the tanks _ which came to rest 150 feet below the surface and 350 feet from shore _ has been limited, the official Soviet news agency said Friday. The tanks are ``reliably plugged,'' and ``the small amount of fuel that has surfaced is being localized and pumped to the shore,'' the agency said. But Larisa Urbakhanova, head of the Irkutsk regional nature conservancy district, told Tass that the ``consequences of such a `bomb' are very unpredictable in Baikal.'' The lake, 2,500 miles east of Moscow and north of the Mongolian border, is 390 miles long, 50 miles across at its widest, and more than 4,800 feet deep at points. Scientists estimate it holds one-fifth of the world's supply of fresh water. Tass said the fuel truck moving over Baikal was part of a convoy carrying fuel supplies to a settlement on the lake's edge, but did not say exactly where it sank. Baikal's ice is thick enough in winter to drive on, but drivers must watch for cracks, Tass said. Truck drivers who treated the lake as they would a normal highway were to blame for the accident, Tass said. The two lead trucks in the conovy managed to maneuver their vehicles around the cracks, but the third plunged through the ice. The driver escaped, it said. Efforts to save Baikal from pollution have been one of the starting points of the Soviet ecology movement that has sprung up under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. There is little heavy industry near the lake, located far from the country's industrial center. Paper factories situated nearby have been told to stop dumping wastes into Baikal.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Says Abortion Bill Flawed by Outside Forces
LaserPhoto BD1
DOC.TEXT: Idaho's anti-abortion governor says he vetoed legislation that would have become the most restrictive abortion law in the nation because it was flawed by outside forces meddling in state affairs. ``We Idahoans are a fiercely independent group who will call it as we see it,'' Gov. Cecil Andrus said. ``I have done that.'' To out-of-state opponents of his Friday veto, he said: ``I would respectfully suggest you return to your own states and try and do it there.'' In the past three weeks, more than 21,000 telephone calls, letters and petitions have flowed into the governor's office. Calls from out of state outnumbered those from Idaho residents by 3-to-1.
