The lobbying peaked Thursday at more than 4,100 calls, with a ratio of 2-to-1 in favor of a veto. Anti-abortion groups wanted to use the Idaho measure to challenge the U.S. Supreme Court's commitment to legalized abortion as spelled out in the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision. The Democratic governor, who is running for a record fourth term, said he was not fazed by threats from abortion rights advocates of a boycott of Idaho potatoes, the state's No. 1 cash crop, if the bill became law. ``I believe, and I am confident the people of Idaho believe, that we can make our own judgments on this terribly important issue without outside pressure and outside influence or threats,'' Andrus said. The veto effectively killed the bill. The Legislature adjourned its regular session before Andrus announced the veto and can only be called back by the governor. Bill proponents conceded they lacked enough votes to gain a two-thirds majority needed to override the veto anyway. Andrus said the legislation failed to offer a woman and her family flexibility in the case of rape and incest. ``The bill is drawn so narrowly that it would punitively and without compassion further harm an Idaho woman who may find herself in the horrible, unthinkable position of confronting a pregnancy that resulted from rape or incest,'' Andrus said. He said legal scholars from both political parties found the bill did not have the ``remotest chance'' of surviving a court challenge that could cost the state as much $1.5 million. The legislation called for outlawing abortion except in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is under 18, severe fetal deformity, or a threat to the life or physical health of the woman. It was similar to bills rejected by other states as too restrictive. ``When all the rhetoric and emotion is set aside and the issues are examined in the cold glare of hard cases, these restrictions fail the test of reasonableness and compassion,'' Andrus said His decision was quickly cheered by abortion rights advocates who had feared his longstanding opposition to abortion except in cases of rape, incest and to save the life of the women would sway him to sign the bill. Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion Rights Action League, said Andrus took a bold step in view of his anti-abortion philosophy. She noted the move might have a political cost for him, adding: ``But we will be there to support him and the people of Idaho will support him because a majority of the people of Idaho disagreed with what the Legislature did.'' The National Right to Life Committee, which was instrumental in drafting the measure, had harsh words for Andrus. The organization's president, John Willke, said Andrus had bowed to ``the hollow threats and pressure tactics of pro-abortion extremists.'' Willke called it ridiculous for Andrus ``to continue to claim he is pro-life when he has vetoed a bill that would have saved thousands of lives.'' Andrus acknowledged he faced political fallout from his veto, especially since the front-runner for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, state Sen. Rachel Gilbert of Boise, voted for the bill. Two of the bill's chief architects, Rep. Gary Montgomery and Sen. Roger Madsen, both Republicans, said they would refine the bill and reintroduce it in the 1991 session. ``There are a tremendous amount of people in Idaho who are pro-life,'' Madsen said.

DOC.HEAD: Five Vietnamese Visit Vietnam Veterans Memorial
LaserPhoto WX12
DOC.TEXT: Five Vietnamese officials visited the Vietnam Veterans Memorial here as a gesture of reconciliation with the United States. They made a privately-sponsored pilgrimage Friday to the stark, black granite monument bearing the names of more than 58,000 U.S. war dead. The two nations have yet to normalize relations from the bitter conflict in the 1960s and 1970s. One of the sponsors of the visit told of plans to build a hospital at the site of the 1968 My Lai massacre, where American soldiers killed more than 175 unarmed men, women and children in an incident that led to the court martials of those accused. Cherie Clark of Denver, Colo., a former military nurse working to organize private U.S. relief programs for Vietnam, said she hopes the U.S. government will grant permission to collect and send contributions for the facility. The two-story hospital and clinic, which would have between 15 and 30 beds, would be called ``the American Hospital,'' she said. The Treasury Department has authorized collection of private funds for medical supplies for 11 orphanages in Vietnam sponsored by the network of U.S. relief organizations helping the Southeast Asian country, said Kirby Jones, a spokesman for Friends of Children of Various Nations, one of the groups. Normalization of government relations and lifting of a U.S. trade embargo against Vietnam have been delayed to await the withdrawal of Vietnamese forces from Cambodia, which occurred last year, and to gain Hanoi's support of a comprehensive peace settlement in Cambodia. Meanwhile, a flow of U.S. Vietnam veterans, including physicians, have been revisiting the country, many returning with descriptions of acute shortages and desperate need for medical and child-care facilities. The five Vietnamese arrived in Seattle on March 9 and have stayed in the homes of support groups in the Pacific Northwest, California, New Mexico, Colorado, Minnesota and Michigan. After spending the weekend in Washington and Baltimore, they were scheduled to visit Boston and New York before returning next Friday to Vietnam. They are Nguyen Van Chi, director of social welfare and war invalids at Ho Chi Minh City, former Saigon; Tran Thi Hieu Hanh and Vu Khoc Nhu of the foreign ministry in Hanoi; Tran Thi Thuong, director of the Mam Non No. 2 orphanage in Thu Duc; and Nguyen Thi Chau, deputy director of the children's committee of Ho Chi Minh City.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Flight Engineer Flew After Tested Positive for Cocaine Use
DOC.TEXT: An Eastern Airlines flight engineer fired this month after being charged with buying crack tested positive for cocaine use in July but kept flying for the strike-plagued airline, a company spokeswoman confirmed. The spokeswoman said the test results apparently went unnoticed because of a clerical error. Eastern fired Dain Schneemilch, 36, of Key Largo, Fla., on March 20 after he was charged with buying $20 worth of crack from a local police officer posing as a drug dealer in February. In a termination letter, the chief pilot of the airline's Miami crew base, Michael Vaughan, wrote Schneemilch that his Eastern drug test last July was positive for cocaine use, the Fort Worth Star-Telegram reported today. That test had been administered after Schneemilch decided to cross the picket line in the Air Line Pilots Association strike against Eastern, the newspaper reported. The strike began in March 1989. Schneemilch continued to fly as a flight engineer on Boeing 727s until mid-September, the Star-Telegram reported. On Sept. 18, Schneemilch was promoted to first officer, or co-pilot, on the same aircraft. He was in ground school training for his new assignment at the time of his arrest in February, Eastern spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak said. ``When he tested positive for cocaine use in July, it should have been noticed by someone on our staff, but it wasn't,'' Ms. Ceremsak said. ``It was a clerical error, a mistake.'' The carrier hired about 1,000 pilots between April and August of last year, Ms. Ceremsak said, as Eastern tried to rebuild itself from the pilots' and mechanics' strike. Also, about 700 striking pilots crossed the picket lines and returned to work during that time. ``We believe that's probably why it happened at that time,'' Ms. Ceremsak said. ``That's not meant as an excuse, just an explanation.'' She said Schneemilch never served as a first officer on any Eastern flight. She also said Schneemilch had passed a drug test administered as part of his annual physical exam only four days before the arrest. Since Schneemilch's arrest, Eastern has reviewed the drug tests of all of the pilots it hired last summer and found no other positive results were overlooked, Ms. Ceremsak said. The drug test he took last summer was not then required by the Federal Aviation Administration, she said. Random drug tests of airline employees began in December. Schneemilch has pleaded innocent to the crack-buying charge. The case is pending in Florida state court. His attorney, Timothy Thomes of Key Largo, told the Star-Telegram: ``While matters are pending, we would have no comment.''

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Indicts Gonzalez in Bronx Social Club Blaze
LaserPhoto NY13
DOC.TEXT: The man accused of killing 87 people by setting an illegal social club ablaze in a spurned lover's rage was indicted on 174 counts of murder. A state grand jury Friday indicted Julio Gonzalez, 36, on one count of second-degree murder and one count of murder in the commission of a felony for each person killed inside the Happy Land Social Club on Sunday. He also was indicted on two counts of arson and single counts of attempted murder and assault. Gonzalez was not present when the indictment was returned. He is being held under a 24-hour watch at Bellevue Hospital, where no other prisoners are permitted within 20 feet of him. He is due back in court April 12. The Red Cross was preparing a charter flight to carry more than 40 bodies back to Honduras today. Six victims were buried Friday. Gonzalez's court-appointed defense attorney, Richard W. Berne, told reporters at state Supreme Court in the New York City borough of the Bronx he would consider an insanity defense. That angered Violet Sambula, a friend of victim Gladys Gomez, 26. ``He's going to try to get away with it. It's just not fair,'' Sambula said at a wake for three victims Friday night. Bronx District Attorney Robert Johnson said Gonzalez conceivably could be convicted of two murder counts for each victim, but he said a jury ``probably would have to choose between the two.'' Gonzalez' sentence could face 25 years to life in prison if convicted on all counts and if the sentences run concurrently, Assistant District Attorney Eric Warner said. If a judge made the sentences run consecutively, he could receive a 2,000-year term. ``No case is open and shut,'' Warner said. ``We have a very good case. The evidence is strong.'' While the grand jury considered the charges, authorities released records indicating the social club's landlord was contacted by a fire lieutenant about eight months ago and told a vacate order was in effect against the building. Morris Jaffe, a partner in Little Peach Realty Corp., responded that the problem ``would be taken care of,'' according to a July 28, 1989, Fire Department document. Jaffe and Jay Weiss, husband of actress Kathleen Turner, are partners in the realty company. Jaffe was not in his office Friday morning to comment on the report. Also on Friday, two more multimillion-dollar negligence lawsuits were brought by families of fire victims against the social club; Alex DiLorenzo, identified as the building's owner; Little Peach; Weiss and Jaffe, and the City of New York. One lawsuit is seeking $100 million, the other $57 million. In addition to negligence, the lawsuits, filed in Manhattan's federal court, charge the city with ``an official policy of deliberate indifference to the constitutional rights'' of the deceased.

DOC.HEAD: Mechanical Failure, Bad Weather Blamed for Andes Copter Crash
DOC.TEXT: Bad weather and mechanical failure are suspected in the crash of a U.S. anti-drug helicopter in the Andes that injured the three Americans and two Peruvian policemen on board, the U.S. Embassy says. Leftist rebels and drug traffickers are active in the area in eastern Peru but were not believed to have been involved in Friday's crash of the Un-1 Huey helicopter, a U.S. Embassy spokesman said on condition of anonymity. The helicopter went down while flying with two others from Tingo Maria, 200 miles northeast of Lima to Mazamari, 175 miles east of Lima, and came to rest 12,000 feet up a mountain, the spokesman said. No reason was given for the crash, but the spokesman said without elaboration that bad weather and mechanical failure were suspected. Peruvian police have bases in Tingo Maria and Mazamari that are involved in the anti-narcotics program, supported by the U.S. government. The Americans worked for National Air Transport Inc., which has a State Department contract to provide support to Peruvian police and U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents in Peru. The names of the injured could not be released for security reasons, he said. The five were evacuated to a hospital in Tingo Maria, he said. The Embassy spokesman said the Americans _ a pilot, medic and mechanic _ suffered ``injuries and fractures,'' but said he did not know the seriousness of the injuries. The spokesman said a Peruvian police gunner riding in the helicopter appeared to be the most seriously injured. Ten Huey helicopters are on loan from the State Department. They are used by anti-drug agents and Peruvian police in raids on coca fields, processing laboratories and clandestine airstrips in Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley. The helicopters are piloted by contracted American civilians and Peruvian co-pilots. They operate out of the U.S.-built base at Santa Lucia, 250 miles northeast of Lima. Twenty to 40 U.S. drug agents are stationed at Santa Lucia to assist police. The base at Mazamari is a training camp where U.S. Green Berets instruct Peruvian police in jungle warfare. The Embassy says about 12 Green Berets are stationed at Mazamari. The Embassy spokesman would not comment on the purpose of Friday's flight.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Even whales are wary of the dentist. The College of Dental Surgeons of British Columbia kicked off dental health month Friday with an attempted demonstration of tooth-brushing on Hyak, a 7-ton killer whale at Vancouver Aquarium. Photographers gathered at the edge of the aquarium pool as trainer Doug Pemberton crouched with a 5-foot-long red toothbrush and a bucket of herring to get Hyak to open wide for a brushing. Hyak approached for a snack, took one look at the toothbrush and headed for the other side of the pool with a spurt from his blow hole. The black and white whale isn't shy about performing in regular shows, aquarium spokesman Stefani Hewlett said. But at age 24, Hyak is set in his ways. ``He's a very experienced animal in everything else, but the toothbrush is something new and he is highly suspicious of it, obviously, and he's giving it a very wide berth,'' Hewlett said. The responsibilities of dental health month fell to another of the aquarium's three orcas, 12-year-old Finna, after Hyak fizzled. Finna opened wide for a tooth brushing after a treat of herring.

Oscar was the hit of show-and-tell at Micah Rosenthal's school. The 6-year-old girl's mother, movie makeup woman Lynn Barber, won an Academy Award on Monday for her work in ``Driving Miss Daisy'' and let Micah bring the 13-inch statuette to Sarah Smith Elementary School on Friday. As television news cameras rolled, Micah proudly displayed the gold statue for her classmates. ``Micah,'' asked teacher Mary Pace, ``you want to tell the class what you have there?'' Micah hoisted the 8{ pound award. ``My mom, she got this Oscar on television. When she got off the plane, she held it here,'' Micah said, holding the statue at waist level. ``She couldn't hold it up this high, but I can,'' the girl said, lifting the Oscar over her head.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Drug Cartel Said to Offer Money for Killings
DOC.TEXT: The Medellin cocaine cartel will give its death squads $100,000 for each anti-narcotics police officer they kill and $4,000 for every other policeman slain in Bogota and Medellin, police have said. Cartel leader Pablo Escobar also sent grenades and assault rifles to Bogota, the capital, to renew its terrorist offensive against the government, said spokeswoman Cpl. Elsie Patino of the judicial police. The judicial police, the Peruvian equivalent of the FBI, discovered the cartel's plans for assassinating police through intercepted communications, Patino said. Escobar was heard ordering new attacks in retaliation for the government's renewed anti-drug offensive, she said. On Wednesday, after a two-month lull, the administration of President Virgilio Barco renewed extraditions of drug suspects to the United States. Fernando Gutierrez, 29, was sent to Phoenix to face drug-trafficking and money-laundering charges. He was the 15th Colombian extradited since August, and police are holding 17 more Colombians wanted by the United States. The government intensified its war against traffickers in August after drug runners killed a leading presidential candidate. Traffickers retaliated by killing more than 200 people in separate attacks. After the latest extradition, the cartel hinted in a statement Thursday it was planning new attacks. On Friday, troops pressed the government crackdown by taking over Envigado, six miles north of Medellin. According to the military, the town is virtually run by Escobar and is reported to be his center of operations. On Thursday, Barco declared martial law in Envigado. According to the presidential decree, the town's security forces will be dismantled. The commander of Medellin's army brigade, Gen. Harold Bedoya, said last month that Escobar controlled Envigado's municipal police force. Eighteen members of the force were arrested this month, and nine were formally accused of carrying out killings for Escobar. The National Security Council also dismantled a civilian police force organized by Medellin Mayor Juan Gomez Martinez and only national police were to be allowed to operate in the city of 2 million. Also Friday, Norberto Rodriguez, the brother-in law and cousin of President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, was freed Friday in Colombia, eight and a half months after being kidnapped from his northern Colombian farm, government sources in Caracas said. Rodriguez, 65, was kidnapped on July 14, from his farm about 25 miles from Cucuta. Rodriguez, once a Venezuelan consul in Cucuta had retired some years ago. Accounts of his kidnapping first said the abductors belonged to the People's Liberation Army, also known as the ELN, a Maoist-oriented guerrilla group. Later, the kidnappers were described as common criminals who asked for a ransom of $240.000. Perez said that as a matter of principle, he would not accept the kidnappers' conditions.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in East; Dry and Fair in West
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered across the Eastern seaboard today, while it was dry and fair in much of the West. Rain and drizzle also dampened parts of the southern Midwest from Kansas City to Indianapolis. Temperatures early today were in the 40s for much of the nation. The northern and western Rockies had fair weather, as did Los Angeles, and Portland and Medford, Ore. Other areas of the West were cloudy or had fog. It was raining in Atlanta, New York, Philadelphia and other parts of the East. Springlike weather spread across much of the nation Friday, but winter lingered in central New England. As much as three inches of snow accumulated in southwest Maine before precipitation turned to sleet and later rain. Snow also fell in Vermont, New Hampshire and along the New England coastline from southern Maine to Massachusetts. Snow was scattered Friday in New York, and fell in the highlands of south central Colorado to northeast Colorado, and from south central Nevada to central Arizona. The nation's high for Friday was 91 degrees at McAllen, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I would respectfully suggest you return to your own states and try and do it there.'' _ Idaho Gov. Cecil Andrus, who vetoed what whould have been the nation's most restrictive abortion law, speaking to out-of-staters who pressured him to sign the bill.

``This stuns me. How many times does this guy have to be turned down? This just keeps the wound open ... It keeps us waiting and waiting.'' _ William Stalder following a federal appeals judge's decision to stay the California execution of Robert Alton Harris, who was convicted of killing Stalder's nephew and another teen-ager in 1978.

``Our views on the question of self-determination ... are well-known around the world, but I do not want to risk misunderstanding by failing to communicate.'' _ President Bush on why he sent a message to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev explaining his views on Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: Supermarket Sues Government Over Law Restricting Large Stores
DOC.TEXT: The United States today picked up an unexpected ally _ a Japanese supermarket chain _ in its fight against a law that hinders large, more efficient stores from competing with mom-and-pop outlets. Life Stores Co. today said it filed a $6.3 million suit against the government, claiming restrictive government requirements have held up approval of one new supermarket for nine years. ``Our experience is just the tip of the iceberg. There are many other similar stores who have been facing the same problem,'' Toshiaki Namiki, a company spokesman. At issue is the Large-Scale Retail Store Law, a prime target of U.S. trade pressure. Under the law, local shopkeepers, many fearful of the competition that a larger and likely lower-priced supermarket or department store would bring, often can stop a competitor from moving into their area. In a news release, the chain's chairman, Nobutsugu Shimizu, said it was ``a shame to the country and its people to maintain such a law.'' Retailers in Shiki City, 15 miles north of Tokyo, are against the disputed supermarket because they fear their businesses will be damaged, said Eiten Sato, a spokesman for the Shiki Chamber of Commerce. Under the law, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry can require large retailers to obtain local approval if their store is likely to negatively affect local retailers. Without approval, large retailers cannot open new outlets. The store law is a focal point in U.S.-Japanese trade talks, which are to resume Monday in Washington. The United States says the law gives undue influence to Japanese manufacturers and prevents imported products from reaching store shelves. In contrast, Japanese retailers such as Mitsukoshi and Tokyu department stores and Yaohan supermarkets have already opened stores in the United States. In a test of trade barriers, the government agreed Tuesday to consider a request by U.S. toy retailer Toys R Us Inc. to open a 53,000-square-foot discount store in the country. U.S. officials says the loosening of Japan's market could ease a U.S. trade deficit with Japan that reached $49 billion last year. However, the trade and industry minister, Kabun Muto, said earlier this week that he has no intention of scrapping the law. Life Stores, an Osaka-based grocery store chain with 70 branches nationwide, is also requesting the immediate ban of the law. Store chairman Shimizu said he might drop the suit if the government agrees to scrap the law in the trade talks with U.S. officials. He said Life Stores' action came shortly before the U.S.-Japanese meeting because ``we thought it's now or never.'' ``Victims of the Large-Scale Store Law are none other than the consumers,'' Shimizu said.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Calls Off Negotiations, Cites Violence
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. cited continuing violence when it canceled a trip to the bargaining table next week in the monthlong strike by union bus drivers. A union leader accused the company of using smear tactics against the strikers by blaming them for the violence. The company says there have been 28 shooting attacks on buses, 70 bomb threats against buses or terminals and more than 100 other incidents since the strike started. The two sides had agreed to meet Monday with federal mediators in Tucson, Ariz., but the company called off the talks Friday, when it reported three more shootings and a bomb threat. P. Anthony Lannie, Greyhound's executive vice president, said the company would agree to meet April 9 ``if there is no other violence in the meantime.'' In a letter to Edward M. Strait, president of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, Lannie said: ``We cannot resume negotiations while the violence continues.'' Strait said the union has repeatedly condemned violence and should not be blamed by Greyhound. ``Clearly, this is a part of a smear campaign against the union and the Greyhound employees we represent,'' Strait said. The union, which represents 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 office and maintenance workers, walked out March 2 in a disagreement over wages and job security. The latest shooting occurred Friday night when a bus was hit between Pittsburgh and Harrisburg, Pa. Another bus was fired on Friday near Tulsa, Okla. No one was injured in the incidents, company officials said. On Thursday, a baggage handler in Kansas City, Mo., discovered three bullet holes in a bus that had traveled from Minneapolis, said company spokesman George Gravley. There were no injuries, he said. Also Friday, there was a bomb threat at the Chicago terminal. As in past threats, no bomb was found, the company said. Strait said Friday there also have been 60 incidents of ``violence perpetrated by unsafe and ill-trained replacement drivers against people on the picket lines.'' Elsewhere Friday, pro-labor rallies were held in about 20 cities in a show of solidarity with the Greyhound drivers. Greyhound has been operating on a reduced schedule since the strike began, using permanent replacements and crossovers. The company plans to expand service Sunday, aiming for 54.1 percent of pre-strike miles covered.

DOC.HEAD: Security Forces Kill Two Moslems
DOC.TEXT: Police today killed two Moslems, including a 12-year-old boy, in searches of homes today after Moslem militants fired on officers patrolling the city center, witnesses said. Elsewhere in the Kashmir Valley, the scene of a bloody Moslem campaign for secession from mainly Hindu India, border guards killed three militants near the frontier with Pakistan. In Srinagar, the center of the campaign, militants opened fired at a police patrol, then escaped into alleys. There were no police casualties. Policemen shot and killed the two Moslems in subsequent searches of nearby homes, witnesses said. Roshan Lal, a teacher, said a 12-year-old boy taking private lessons at his house was dragged from under a bed and shot at point-blank range. Lal said he and other members of his family ran to upper floors of his house when the firing started. The boy, Nazir Ahmed Sofi, hid under a bed and was discovered when the troops entered the house, said Lal, a Hindu. Another Moslem, Nissar Ahmed, was killed by police during the searches, other witnesses said on condition of anonymity. They gave no details. Meanwhile, Press Trust of India said border guards shot and killed three militants in the Kupwara district Friday. The victims were among Moslems who tried to slip across the border into Pakistan to buy weapons, the agency said. At least 25 Moslem militants were arrested in the operation, Press Trust said. The killings raise to 238 the number of people killed since the government launched a crackdown Jan. 20 on the separatist movement. India has long accused Pakistan of supplying weapons and training the miltants, charges Pakistan routinely denies. In Islamabad, Foreign Minister Sahabzada Yaqub Khan said Friday that Pakistan will not be provoked into another war with India over Kashmir. The Kashmir Valley has been disputed between the two nations since 1947, when India and Pakistan were born through the division of the British-ruled subcontinent along religious lines. India and Pakistan fought two wars over the valley, which remains divided by a U.N.-monitored cease-fire line. Kashmiri Moslem militants earlier campaigned for union with Pakistan but now say they want independence and the status of a neutral nation. Indian-held territory in the valley and the Hindu-dominated plains of Jammu to the south form the state of Jammu-Kashmir, the only Indian province with a Moslem majority. Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are 64 percent Moslem. Nationwide Moslems account for 12 percent of the country's 880 million people, while Hindus make up 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Party Launches Anti-Government Referendum Drive
DOC.TEXT: South Korea's largest opposition party today began a drive to collect 10 million signatures, aiming at forcing national elections to repudiate the newly bolstered governing party. In January, President Roh Tae-woo's conservative party merged with two moderate opposition groups, giving Roh's governing group an overwhelming parliamentary majority. The new coalition, the Democratic Liberal Party, excluded the leftist Party for Peace and Democracy, led by Kim Dae-jung, who has denounced the merger as ``a de facto coup d'etat.'' ``We must definitely succeed in the campaign and divulge a dirty political plot by the ruling group to hold on to power forever,'' Kim said. He said opposition legislators should have sought voters' consent before joining the governing party and the government. Even if Kim's campaign succeeds to sign up 10 million of South Korea's 43 million people, it has no binding force under law. And the government has already rejected the opposition demand to move up the next general elections, scheduled for early 1992. Kim said his party will also push for nationwide public rallies to appeal for new elections. The first rally was scheduled for the western industrial city of Buchon on Sunday, Kim said. The new governing party holds about 210 of the 299 seats in the National Assembly, enough to change the nation's constitution at will. The unicameral assembly had been controlled by the three opposition parties, led by Kim's party. Founders of the new governing party said they wanted to bring stability to the country's faction-ridden politics, in which the three opposition parties had been unable to settle their own feuds to pass legislation.

DOC.HEAD: Mass Transit System Headed for Shutdown
DOC.TEXT: Opposition to a bailout plan threatened to shut down the public transportation system in New York's second-largest city after tonight's runs, stranding 120,000 bus and subway riders. The potential shutdown also threatened chaos Monday for more than 9,700 public school students who use the transit system. Buffalo school officials said the students would have to find their own rides. Hospitals said they would encourage workers to form car pools and would look into renting private buses, if necessary. The board of Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority voted to shut down the system because only $89,000 was available for a system that costs $55 million annually to run. Mayor James D. Griffin proposed Friday to divert $9 million in anticipated Erie County sales-tax revenue to keep the system going. But county officials rejected the plan. County officials earlier turned down utility, property, mortgage and gasoline taxes as potential sources of transit funds. The mayor said the city, which faces a $30 million deficit, can't afford to give up its share of an expected increase in local sales-tax collections. ``Shutting down affects those people who don't appear to have any voice,'' Griffin said. ``If we close down this system, shame on all of us.'' Erie County Executive Dennis Gorski said the mayor's plan was not equitable. ``He leaves out the part where property and school taxes across Erie County will have to be raised to make up the difference,'' Gorski said. ``Any tampering with existing revenues means you steal from one pocket to fill another. It's a shell game.'' Riders said they were furious at the impending shutdown. ``I think that if the NFTA thinks that they can shut down the rapid transit on April Fool's Day, they're nuts,'' said Robert Orlando, who rode the subway to Thursday's Buffalo Sabres hockey game. But some suburbanites didn't want to subsidize the system. ``I've probably been on a bus twice in 23 years, and I feel bad for the people who have to rely on them,'' said Gloria Mitchell of suburban Hamburg. ``But I'd rather see them shut down than pay higher taxes for something we don't use. They should raise the bus fares. I don't feel we should pay for them.'' Meanwhile, the transit agency's executive director, Alfred H. Savage, accepted a $149,500-a-year post as head of the Chicago Transit Authority. Savage resigned from the NFTA on Thursday, saying he was fed up with the county's unwillingness to support public transit.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Leader Sets Conditions for Release of Hostages
DOC.TEXT: A Shiite Moslem leader was quoted today as saying that the kidnappers holding Western hostages in Lebanon will not release them unless the United States helps free Moslems imprisoned in Kuwait and Israel. ``I don't believe that those who held the hostages for a year or two or even five years will let them loose free of charge,'' Hussein Mousawi said in an interview broadcast by the Voice of Islam radio station in east Lebanon's ancient city of Baalbek. The interview was quoted today in Beirut's independent An-Nahar newspaper. Mousawi heads the pro-Syrian Islamic Amal wing of Hezbollah, or the Party of God, Iran's main Shiite ally in Lebanon. He contended that Hezbollah holds none of the 18 Westerners missing in Lebanon, including eight Americans. ``We are not concerned with the hostage issue. We do not have any hostage,'' he said. ``The hostages are held by security groups that maintain their individualities and take no orders from Hezbollah or Islamic Amal.'' Hezbollah is widely believed to be the umbrella for various Shiite hostage-holding factions, despite the party's public disclaimers. Mousawi said the demands made by the kidnappers were ``justified, irrespective of the plight of the hostages.'' He listed the release of 15 convicted terrorists imprisoned in Kuwait for bombing the U.S. and French embassies in Kuwait in 1983 and the release of Arab prisoners in Israeli jails. Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, the group that holds American hostages Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland, has long demanded freedom for he prisoners in Kuwait. Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest held of the Western hoatages. He was abducted March 16, 1985. Several other hostages have been held almost as long, including Sutherland, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, who was kidnapped in Lebanon on June 9, 1985. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, which holds kidnapped U.S. professors Alann Steen, Robert Polhill and Jesse Turner, has demanded 400 Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners be freed from Israeli jails. Israel has rejected the demand. ``The United States and all those concerned with the hostages' issue should consider the rights of these people and how to return some of them,'' Mousawi said. ``America influences Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Israel. Things are intermingled in the domain of global arrogance but all revolve within America's sphere of influence,'' he said. ``If they want their hostages freed, then they have to make some moves with the Israelis, the Kuwaitis, the Saudis and the Maronites. Maronites kidnapped brothers of ours, believers, Iranian diplomats. ``Every usurped right is to be recovered. We are not directly involved in this problem but this my personal analysis.'' Three Iranian diplomats and their Lebanese driver were seized by Maronite Christian militiamen in July 1982. All are believed to be dead.

DOC.HEAD: Halston Memorialized After AIDS-Related Cancer Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st and 5th graf to CORRECT spelling of Minnelli.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX6
DOC.TEXT: The man who designed clothing for Liza Minnelli, Jacqueline Kennedy and other glamorous women was remembered for his style and self-confidence by mourners who gathered for a memorial service. Halston, the fashion designer who once ruled high fashion with his simple, sophisticated designs, was remembered by about 125 friends and family members Friday, five days after his death from AIDS-related cancer. Robert Frowick recalled his brother's strong sense of identity and unique talent in fashion. ``He was always looking for beauty in his surroundings,'' Frowick said. Minnelli and model Berry Berenson were the best known of the mourners, who filed into the ornate Calvary Presbyterian Church. White tulips and lillies of the valley blanketed the altar and bouquets of flowers adorned the church's entry. Trumpeters from the San Francisco Opera performed some of the music, which ranged from Mozart and Bach to ``America the Beautiful'' and a composition by Halston's sister-in-law, Ann Frowick. The service was held two blocks from the hospital where the 57-year-old Halston, whose full name was Roy Halston Frowick, spent the last four months of his life fighting Kaposi's sarcoma. Halston kept it secret that he had tested positive for the HIV virus that causes AIDS. After he died peacefully in his sleep Monday, his family announced that he suffered from the deadly disease. They also said he had asked that a shiny jet-black Rolls-Royce Corniche he bought recently to tour the scenic California coastline be auctioned, with proceeds going to AIDS research. The car was parked at the curb outside the church during Friday's service. The Rev. James Emerson said a prayer for everyone with AIDS and cancer, and told mourners, ``May action match words in the world of the political.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Blockade Mohawk Territory After Helicopter Shooting
DOC.TEXT: State troopers and corrections officers today blockaded entrances to the Ganienkeh Mohawk Territory after gunfire they suspect came from the encampment struck a doctor aboard a military helicopter on a medical flight. The doctor was hospitalized in good condition. A Ganienkeh spokesman today denied Friday's shooting originated from the settlement. State and federal authorities were meeting with Mohawk representatives this morning to discuss the incident, Trooper Richard Garcia said. The Mohawk tribe doesn't recognize federal or state jurisdiction on the land. Busloads of people travel to the territory, about 150 miles north of Albany, every Friday evening to play high-stakes bingo, but the games were canceled Friday night. After Mohawks refused to let troopers enter the land to investigate the shooting, at least 20 troopers and an undetermined number of corrections officers blockaded the four roads leading to the territory, Garcia said. ``We've turned back everybody,'' said Trooper Fred Curns, who was at the scene. ``We'll turn back everybody until the powers that be decide it's safe to let them through.'' The Vermont Army National Guard helicopter was hit by three bullets fired from a rifle as it flew about 200 feet above the Indian territory, Garcia said. The settlement, which police say is home to about 40 people, is on 700 acres of state-owned parkland in the town of Altona. The aircraft, carrying three military personnel and two civilians, was on a medical flight from Burlington, Vt., to Massena, N.Y., to pick up a patient, said Lt. Lloyd Goodrow, Air National Guard spokesman. Dr. James Van Kirk of South Burlington, Vt., was struck in the right arm, Garcia said. Van Kirk, 27, the chief resident at Medical Center Hospital, was listed in good condition early today at the Burlington hospital. Two of the bullets penetrated the fuselage and one hit the tail rotor, authorities said. The helicopter landed safely in a field in the Mohawk territory. ``We believe the shot came off the territory,'' Garcia said. ``We can't determine who fired it without interviewing anyone. They won't let us interview anyone.'' Daryl Martin, a spokesman for the Ganienkeh, denied the shots originated from the settlement. ``There is no reason for us to provoke an incident like this. We feel we've been railroaded into this situation,'' Martin said. State and federal law enforcement officers have not been permitted to enter the territory since it was established in 1979. ``We set up our own barricades to protect our people. It was a natural thing for us to do,'' Martin said early today after Indian representatives met with state and federal authorities to try to resolve the issue. ``Our law is that no outside law enforcement are allowed. We feel they're pointing the finger at us,'' Martin said. ``They're threatening to do whatever they have to.'' One meeting among state officials, FBI agents and Mohawk representatives broke down late Friday, but talks resumed early today, Garcia said.

DOC.HEAD: Hekmatyar Replaced as Foreign Minister in Guerrilla Government
DOC.TEXT: Firebrand guerrilla leader Gulbuddin Hekmatyar has been replaced as foreign minister of the Afghan rebel's government-in- exile, the official news agency of the resistance said today. Sibghatullah Mojaddidi, president of the so-called interim government, said the post would be filled by Burhanuddin Rabbani, the Midia News Agency reported. Rabbani, the government-in-exile's minister of reconstruction, is leader of the more moderate Jamiat-i-Islami, the most politically and militarily organized group in the fractious seven-party resistance based in Pakistan. Rabbani's group is a bitter rival of the Hezb-i-Islami Party headed by Hekmatyar, and there have been widespread reports of fierce fighting between the two groups. The news agency said Hekmatyar quit as foreign minister last year. ``I had long ago decided to induct professor Rabbani to this post, but due to certain problems, the decision was implemented now,'' Mojaddidi told Midia. ``The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is very important and in view of this, he (Rabbani) has been appointed as foreign minister,'' the news agency said. Hekmatyar, 42, is known for his outspoken contempt of the West. But despite the rhetoric, he has received the bulk of the U.S. arms sent to the Moslem guerrillas during the nearly 12-year-old war against the Soviet-backed government of Afghanistan. He has been accused of killing other guerrillas and innocent Afghans. He also has been accused of theft, opportunism and collusion with Communists. Following the March 6 coup attempt in Afghanistan, the leaders of the other six parties quickly criticized Hekmatyar for publically supporting the mutiny led by Gen. Shah Nawaz Tanai, the former defense minister of Afghanistan who had vigorously opposed the Kabul government's offers to talk peace. Troops loyal to Afghan President Najib eventually crushed the attempted coup, and Tanai defected to Hekmatyar's guerrillas.

DOC.HEAD: For A Second Day, Police Fire On Pro-Democracy Protesters
DOC.TEXT: Police fired rifles today to disperse about 5,000 pro-democracy protesters, wounding at least three people, including a woman watching the demonstration from her house, witnesses said. The crowd had massed in the streets of the Katmandu suburb of Patan to protest the deaths of two demonstrators in a clash there Friday in which about 30 policemen and 11 protesters were injured. The witnesses, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said police also used tear gas and made some arrests during today's protest. But the witnesses did not know how many people were taken into custody. ``I warned authorities to stop police repression against the people,'' said Kesar Bahadur Bista, who represents Patan in the Rashtriya Panchayat, Nepal's partyless legislature. Siddhi Lal, a Patan leftist leader, said: ``The fascist Panchayat system used guns for stopping people's rights. So long as we don't get it (democracy), we will not forget it and we will carry the movement ahead.'' On Friday, the Himalayan kingdom's foreign minister quit over the crackdown on the movement for the restoration of multiparty democracy. It was the first indication of discord in the government over how the crisis is being handled. At least 14 people have been killed since Feb. 18, when King Birendra's government began cracking down on the spiraling movement. Hundreds of people, including doctors, lawyers, students and journalists, have been arrested. The government says Nepal already has a working democracy and accuses the agitators of trying to foist their brand of democracy. A two-year experiment with a Western-style democracy in Nepal ended in 1961 when King Mahendra, Birendra's father, dismissed the government of the now-banned Nepali Congress Party, accusing it of corruption and mismanagement. Shailendra Kumar Upadhyaya, who resigned as foreign minister on Friday, said in an interview today that he decided to do so after Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha refused to heed his call to hold talks with the agitators. ``I advised him not to take any attitude which would further deteriorate the situation,'' Upadhyaya said. ``But he did not listen to me ... under such circumstances, I found it immoral to remain in a Cabinet headed by such a short-sighted person.'' Upadhyaya, who served as Nepal's permanent representative to the United Nations from 1972 to 1978, also said he condemned violence by agitators. ``Violence cannot be condoned,'' the 60-year-old politician said. ``Once the dialogue starts, the violence will fizzle out.'' The government has shown itself unwilling to hold talks with the protesters, led by the Nepali Congress and a coalition of left-wing groups. King Birendra, in his only comments on the movement, said earlier this month that there would be no change in the composition of the legislature, a key demand of the protesters. One-fifth of the non-partisan assembly's 140 members are selected by the king. The rest are elected, but membership in political parties and political canvassing are banned.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Attack Campaign Meeting, One Dead, 12 Wounded
DOC.TEXT: Shining Path guerrillas opened fire on supporters of presidential candidate Mario Vargas Llosa today at his campaign headquarters in an Andean mining center, killing one person and wounding 12, police said. The three rebels attacked a crowd in La Oroya that had gathered at the building for a trip to Huancayo, 60 miles to the southeast, where Vargas Llosa was to address an afternoon rally. The Maoist-inspired Shining Path has launched dozens of attacks this week in an effort to sabotage the April 8 general elections. The guerrillas have threatened to kill anyone who votes. Vargas Llosa, an acclaimed novelist who heads the center-right Democratic Front coalition, is considered the front-runner. Police said the guerrillas, who escaped after today's 6 a.m. attack, killed a police guard and that the wounded included the Democratic Front candidate for a regional assembly, Julio Barrios, and an unidentified youth leader. La Oroya is 60 miles from Lima on the main highway to Huancayo. Two people were killed in Huancayo's main square Tuesday when a car bomb set off by Shining Path rebels exploded shortly before a campaign rally by socialist presidential candidate Alfonso Barrantes. The Shining Path began fighting Peru's elected governments in 1980. More than 18,000 people have died in the violence, according to government figures.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says 112 Rebels Killed in Sudan Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf, `The movement...' with 1 graf to CORRECT definition of animism. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers and their allied militiamen killed 112 rebels in fierce fighting in southern Sudan, the military command reported. A statement issued late Friday also said nine soldiers and militiamen were killed and 32 wounded in the fighting in southern Sudan's sprawling Bahr el-Ghazal region. It did not say when the battles took place. In addition to the 112 rebels killed, a ``large number'' were wounded, the statement said. The military also said the rebel unit's commander was captured. The militiamen are part of a newly formed popular defense force made up of civilian volunteers armed by the government to fight the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army. It was impossible to verify the government statement because the south has been closed to outsiders for years due to the rebellion. In a related development, the newspaper Al-Sudan Al-Hadith quoted a senior military officer as saying that 350 rebels surrendered to the army last week in the Upper Nile region, northeast of Bahr el-Ghazal. The Sudan People's Liberation Army began fighting the government in 1983. The movement, based in the largely Christian and animist South, demands more regional autonomy from the Moslem-dominated central government. Animists do not worship a single god but believe everything in nature has a soul.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Leader Harry Bridges Dies At 88
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES last graf, which is redundant. SUBS 7th graf to CORRECT style on real estate agent sted realtor.
DOC.TEXT: Harry Bridges, a crusty labor movement legend who organized waterfront unions on the West Coast and led San Francisco into a general strike in 1934, has died at age 88. Bridges died of emphysema at his home Friday. Bridges founded the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union in 1934 and was its president until 1977. ``He was one of the great figures of the American labor movement,'' said John Hennings, secretary-treasurer of the California Labor Federation. ``He organized the entire Pacific Coast, not just San Francisco, against the opposition of the shipowners,'' said Henning. He said Bridges ``created a lasting institution to carry on, not just a strike of the moment.'' Bridges also is credited with helping organize many of the sugar and pineapple plantation, cannery, and mill workers in Hawaii during the 1950s. Born the son of a prosperous real estate agent on July 28, 1901, in Melbourne, Australia, Bridges went to sea and in 1920 arrived in San Francisco. Two years later he became a longshoreman when conditions on the docks were considered the worst in the nation. On July 5, 1934, two dock workers were killed and 100 wounded when police charged a picket line. The California National Guard was called out, prompting a general strike 11 days later. The strike ended in three days with an agreement on a contract that established a union-operated rather than employer-run hiring hall. In a 1973 address to longshoremen in San Francisco, Bridges said: ``Experience has taught that the union worker has one weapon no one else has, and that is laying down his tools and quitting his job.'' Beginning in 1939, the federal government tried to kick Bridges out of the country for 16 years, charging the union leader was a Communist and had falsely denied being a party member when he applied for citizenship. He was once jailed for 20 days as a Communist conspirator. Bridges acknowledged receiving help from Communists in 1934, but always denied being a member of the Communist Party. The U.S. Supreme Court twice reversed orders for his deportation. Although Bridges and the ILWU had appeared to have mellowed since the 1934 general strike, the union exhibited renewed militancy in the summer and fall of 1971, when a strike shut West Coast ports for 100 days.

DOC.HEAD: Appellate Judge Blocks California Execution; State Appeals To Supreme Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with stay appealed to U.S. Supreme Court, assigned to Sandra Day O'Connor. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Harris was...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX3
DOC.TEXT: A conservative federal appeals judge has blocked a murderer's execution in the California gas chamber, leaving relatives of the killer's teen-age victims stunned and disappointed. The state immediately appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court. Tuesday's scheduled execution of Robert Alton Harris, which would have been the state's first in 23 years, was stayed Friday by Judge John Noonan of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The judge said more study of Harris' mental state may be needed. State Attorney General John Van de Kamp's emergency request to have the stay lifted was received at the Supreme Court this morning. It was referred to Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, who handles emergency matters from the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco. Harris was convicted of abducting two San Diego boys from a drive-in restaurant in 1978 and fatally shooting them so he could use their car in a bank holdup. Both victims, John Mayeski and Michael Baker, were 16. Their bodies were found on a hillside several hours after the bank robbery. The judge's decision came after the U.S. Supreme Court turned down four of Harris' previous appeals. ``I was devastated. I just couldn't believe it. I was in a state of shock,'' said Mayeski's mother, Kathryn Mayeski Sanders, after she heard of the decision. ``After 11 years, he's had every opportunity to plead his case. ``I used to think that the death penalty wasn't the greatest thing, but after going through this I don't think it's too bad,'' she added. ``I hope no one has to go through all that we have had to go through.'' Baker's father, San Diego police detective Steve Baker, arrested Harris after the bank robbery without knowing that his son lay dead nearby. The double murder was discovered after the elder Baker leveled a shotgun at Harris at the home of a friend to arrest him on the holdup. ``I'm very disappointed,'' Baker said. ``They've looked at this case through a microscope for 12 years and can't seem to make a decision. There's nothing I can do about it but take it as it comes.'' Noonan, appointed to the appeals court in 1985 by President Reagan and known mainly for his opposition to abortion, ordered that Harris be spared to allow arguments before a three-judge appeals panel on whether he should get an evidentiary hearing. That process usually takes several months. Noonan said U.S. District Judge William Enright, who turned down Harris' last-ditch appeal Wednesday, should have held a fact-finding hearing on new psychiatric evidence submitted by the defense. That evidence includes reports by psychologists who concluded that the psychiatric consultants who assisted Harris' trial lawyer acted incompetently by failing to test for brain damage or other serious mental disorders. Enright had rejected those conclusions without a hearing. He said the dispute amounted to a mere disagreement among experts, wasn't the state's fault, and wouldn't have affected the jury's decision in Harris' 1979 trial. ``It is reasonably arguable, and we cannot determine from this record, whether Harris received competent psychiatric assistance,'' Noonan said after a 50-minute hearing in a packed courtroom. ``We're pleased that Judge Noonan listened to our argument ... and was not stampeded by the wave of public attention generated here,'' said Michael McCabe, one of Harris' lawyers. Van de Kamp said Noonan's ruling ``creates a brand-new legal right for accused murderers like Robert Harris _ the right to challenge the competency of psychiatric experts years after the fact.'' Gov. George Deukmejian said that ``justice has once again been indefinitely delayed and denied by a single federal judge.'' ``It is unbelievable that this judge who reviewed this case for 14 months ... would now at this last hour require further judicial proceedings,'' the Republican governor said. Mayeski's uncle, William Stalder, said Harris has had his day in court and should be executed. ``This stuns me. How many times does this guy have to be turned down? This just keeps the wound open,'' he said. ``It keeps us waiting and waiting.''

DOC.HEAD: Official Calls for Patriotism Campaign in Chinese Schools
DOC.TEXT: China's schools will stress patriotism and the virtues of socialism in lessons marking the 150th anniversary of a successful foreign attack on China, a government official said today. Also today, a senior Chinese trade official appealed to the West to end trade restrictions imposed on China after troops brutally suppressed June's pro-democracy student demonstrations in Beijing, killing at least 500 people. The vice minister of the State Education Commission, Teng Teng, said students must be drilled in the principles of socialism as part of a new patriotism campaign ``so that that they can gradually realize why China must take the socialist road and why the Communist Party must lead the way.'' Last week, Premier Li Peng urged students to study China's struggle against Britain in the Opium War of 1840-42 ``to heighten their vigilance against the imperialistic strategy of peaceful evolution.'' ``Peaceful evolution'' refers to what China's current hard-line leaders describe as the West's attempt gradually to convert China to capitalism. The 1840-42 war started when the Qing Dynasty tried to stop British opium sales in China. Britain easily defeated the Chinese and in the 1842 Treaty of Nanking forced China to cede Hong Kong and open five ports to British trade. Teng said the lessons, which will be increased in elementary and middle schools, are necessary so that children will ``recognize the different channels used by the international hostile forces in their conspiracy to transform China into a vassal state.'' Ideological education has been stepped up in Chinese schools and campuses since the suppression of the student pro-democracy movement. Regarding trade, Foreign Economic Relations and Trade Vice Minister Li Lanqing criticized the economic sanctions imposed by the West after China used of force to end the movement. He also said that if Washington withdraws China's most-favored-nation trade status, the two nations' relations will be seriously damaged. China's most-favored-nation status comes up for renewal in June, and some members of Congress have called for eliminating it because of China's continued suppression of political dissent. Such a move would mean a significant rise in tariffs on Chinese products and could seriously affect China's exports to the United States, Beijing's third biggest trading partner after Hong Kong and Japan.

DOC.HEAD: With Its Muted Response, West Proves Gorbachev's Friend
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: By muting its response to the Soviet show of military force in Lithuania, the West gave President Mikhail S. Gorbachev proof of its commitment to his survival. Nearly three weeks into the Soviet confrontation with the breakaway republic, however, analysts say no one knows what might provoke some kind of Western retaliation. ``They've let Gorbachev go pretty far,'' Jonathan Isle, director of the Royal United Services Institute, a London-based research center, said in an interview. ``But all the nationalities of the Soviet Union now feel they also can go pretty far because Gorbachev cannot afford to be transformed overnight from a nice, cuddly figure to a Communist dictator.'' The United States and others in the West have urged Gorbachev not to use force in Lithuania, but on Friday President Bush said he had assured the Soviet president that ``we're not trying to make things difficult for Lithuania or the Soviet Union or anybody else.'' The Western stance has made many Lithuanians feel betrayed and has angered Western minorities like Welsh nationalists and Basques in Spain, who thrilled to the Baltic republic's declaration of independence March 11. ``The West keeps saying it never recognized the incorporation of Lithuania and the other Baltic republics into the Soviet Union'' in 1940, ``but we want some practical manifestations of support and we're very, very disappointed,'' said Alun Thomas, spokesman for Plaid Cymru, the Welsh nationalist party. To some critics, the cautious Western response evoked echoes of 1956 and 1968, when a very different Kremlin crushed an anti-Stalinist uprising in Hungary and liberal reforms in Czechoslovakia. A remark by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher reflected the sense of guilt about not helping Hungary and Czechoslovakia. ``We still feel unease that the Western world watched as the Prague Spring of 1968 was crushed by Soviet tanks,'' she told President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia when he visited London on March 21. Nonetheless, she saw no point, and considerable harm, in the West getting tough over Lithuania. She appealed for restraint in a 50-minute telephone conversation with Gorbachev a week after meeting Havel, but government sources said she made no demands and trusted him to honor pledges that troops would not open fire and there would be no Prague-style military crackdown. ``She always felt that if he said he would do something, then he would carry it out,'' a senior British official said, on condition of anonymity. He summed up the government attitude by saying of Gorbachev: ``He's riding a lot of tigers at once. Don't put intolerable pressure on the man.'' The New Statesman, a left-leaning weekly, said the apology to Czechoslovakia should be matched by a forthright statement of support for Lithuania. ``Gorbachev is still the man that Bush, Thatcher and the rest want to do business with, the man who can assure a stable and conservative European order ... yet this is the point between the rock and the hard place, when anyone who believes in democracy must speak out,'' it said in an editorial. From the right, the weekly Economist said using military force in Lithuania would be ``the beginning of the end'' for perestroika. ``Some people will argue that Mr. Gorbachev is embarked on too vital a reform to be subjected to sanctions if he crushes Lithuania,'' it commented. ``But if that is the course he chooses, he will be saying that he is not the man _ and he does not see the Soviet Union as the kind of place _ that the West had been led to expect.'' The Scots, Welsh and Basques sent messages of support to Lithuania. Along with nationalist and linguistically separate groups in Belgium and Germany, they have formed ``The European Freedom Alliance'' of 15 legislators in the 518-member European Parliament. They are pressing for a Europe-wide declaration of support for Lithuania, and feel the Lithuanian example has helped their own causes. ``It's marvelous to see the emergence of nations who have been subsumed by an empire just as Scotland has been subsumed by the British empire,'' said Margaret Ewing, a Scottish nationalist in the House of Commons. Outside the nationalist groups, few see the issue in such straightforward terms. Dominic Lieven, a political scientist at the London School of Economics, said Gorbachev never intended to let Lithuania leave the Soviet Union without negotiations, because of the precedent it would set. ``It would be a standing incentive for other republics to do the same, and for Gorbachev that would be a short road to disaster,'' he said in an interview. ``For the Western governments, there are different pressures. They know the complete disintegration of the Soviet Union would have an immensely destabilizing effect ... but, first, they also believe Gorbachev is their best bet.''

DOC.HEAD: Two South Koreans Missing After Boats Collide Off Nagasaki
DOC.TEXT: A South Korean fishing boat sank Saturday after being struck by a Panamanian-registered freighter off Nagasaki in western Japan, and two fishermen were reported missing, the coast guard said. The freighter, the 1,574-ton Crystal 1, rescued seven of the nine-member crew of the fishing boat, identified as the 90-ton class Yil Shin-ho, the Nagasaki detachment of the Maritime Safety Agency said. Two coast guard patrol boats conducted an overnight search in the area about 25 miles southwest of Osezaki in the southern Goto islands, officials said. Coast guard authorities were investigating the cause of the collision, in which the freighter rammed into the right side of the fishing boat during mild weather, the officials added. No further details were immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Watchdogs Say USDA Moving Slowly Toward 20th Century Before It Ends
Also moved in advance as b0791 of March 27.
DOC.TEXT: Congressional watchdogs continue to nip at the Agriculture Department in hopes the creaky old agency will modernize itself before the 20th century ends. But the structure and inertia of USDA are formidable. Attempts have been made for 45 years _ largely unsuccessful _ to streamline departmental field structure and management. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, has been studying USDA organization and departmental inhibitions for at least two years. A preliminary report was issued in December. Formal responses to GAO's analysis will be sought from departmental agencies and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter when the final report is ready later in the year. Meanwhile, the GAO has followed up its initial review with a supplemental report to Yeutter about the need for improved workforce planning in his department. Such planning should be mandatory, the GAO said. At its simplest, workforce planning means getting the right people in the right jobs, now and over the long haul. The object is to deliver government services to the public, efficiently and economically. The problems involve 36 agencies that carry out the department's policies and programs. In 1988, the GAO said, those functions cost taxpayers more than $44 billion and required the services of 110,000 full-time employees in more than 15,000 places around the world. ``USDA agencies are experiencing problems recruiting highly skilled workers, providing adequate training to employees, developing effective managers, and managing a culturally diverse workforce,'' the latest report said. ``These problems are longstanding, pervasive and will likely continue given present trends in USDA and in the federal government.'' The growing importance of food safety, water quality and biotechnology requires more scientists in USDA's workforce. Yet a shortage of scientists generally, as well as competition from the private sector, put USDA at a disadvantage. Moreover, the report said, agencies within USDA ``sometimes find themselves competing against each other for people from the same job occupations, a condition which is counterproductive from a departmental standpoint.'' Another inhibitor has been the lack of a departmental recruiting program. Each USDA agency goes its own way and generally does not refer unneeded applicants to other agencies. However, the report noted that the department's Office of Personnel has recently contracted to develop a videotape for recruiting new employees. ``As the agricultural economy becomes more consumer-driven than production-oriented, USDA needs employees with backgrounds in marketing management to supplement the skills of their other employees trained in the agricultural sciences,'' the report said. When the GAO looked at employee training, there were many indications of ``poorly or inadequately trained staff'' in a number of areas. Also, the report cited ``continuing problems in achieving and maintaining an ethnically diverse workforce'' of women and minorities. A major GAO complaint is that department agencies generally address only a single year's needs to patch up a problem when long-range remedies are in order. This has been apparent in the Farmers Home Administration and the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, for example. But the report said some USDA agencies ``are laying the groundwork for effective workforce planning.'' For example, the Forest Service uses a ``strategic human resource guide'' to forecast skill-mix changes and attrition through 1995. The forecasts are used in preparing annual job recruitment recommendations and for measuring progress toward employment goals. Another is the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, which is reorganizing its personnel function to include workforce planning. ``Although these tentative steps toward workforce planning are encouraging, without central direction and support the initiatives may be stifled, and those agencies without workforce planning may never develop it,'' the report said. GAO said department personnel leaders recognize the importance of workforce planning ``but have not taken a leadership role in developing ... guidance for agencies to follow nor have they instituted a mechanism for tracking and monitoring individual agency tracking systems.'' The report acknowledged that department personnel officials recently organized a task force to improve USDA's image as an employer and thereby ``enhancing its ability to recruit and retain quality employees.'' But the GAO also noted that the department's personnel office lacked the funds and people to operate the task force on its own, so individual agencies were asked to chip in. ``However, there still exists no departmental policy on workforce planning,'' the report said. ``Consistent workforce-planning standards and guidance are needed to encourage all agencies to initiate workforce planning and to reinforce agencies' efforts already undertaken,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Lift Curfew For First Time Since Invasion
DOC.TEXT: The government on Saturday lifted a curfew that has been in effect since the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion. Ricardo Arias Calderon, vice president and justice minister, said in a statement that the curfew was being lifted in Panama City and Colon effective Saturday night. During the invasion, the curfew was dusk to dawn nationwide. It was lifted in mid-March in cities outside the capital and Colon, on the Atlantic side of the Panama Canal, where it was reduced to 3 a.m. until dawn. The United States invaded to remove dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, who now faces drug charges in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Time Again to Spring Forward, Be Late
DOC.TEXT: Daylight saving time is back. The change, moving clocks ahead one hour, occurred at 2 a.m. Sunday. People who forgot likely found themselves an hour late for wherever they planned to be. Daylight time will remain in effect until Oct. 28 this year, when that hour of lost sleep will be returned.

DOC.HEAD: National Gallery Exhibits Garden of Artistic Delights
DOC.TEXT: Views of the western world's gardens, from Central Park in New York to a 700-year-old German picture of fruit-bearing palms in paradise, go on display Sunday as the greeting to spring from the National Gallery of Art. In between is a painting of the huge vegetable and flower garden around the house where Benjamin Franklin stayed as the first official representative of the United States in Paris. In the background is the Chateau Valentinois owned by Jacques de Chaumont, Franklin's host. Money for the show, called ``Gardens on Paper,'' came from Estee Lauder Inc., which makes perfumes and cosmetics. The 106 prints and drawings, all on paper or parchment, came largely from the gallery's own collection. They include work by Watteau, Fragonard, Piranesi, Whistler, Pisarro and Cassatt. The first pictures were done in the Middle Ages and are more symbolic than realistic, including images of the false paradise or garden of delights. ``In these delicious, perilous bowers, lovers succumb to the promptings of the flesh and indulge in the pleasures of carnal love, turning away from their pursuit of spiritual union with the Divine in the true paradise,'' the catalogue explains. The images of carnal love are also symbolic, however, and unlikely to contribute to the current debate about whether museums should show pictures that some viewers and members of Congress consider obscene. In a 15th century Flemish ``Book of Hours,'' Adam, Eve and the golden-haired snake are all nude but unrevealing. The catalogue was written by Virginia Tuttle Clayton, assistant curator of the gallery's Department of Prints and Drawings. Other sections of the show cover the Renaissance period and the 18th and 19th centuries. The one definitely 20th century work is the last, Maurice Prendergast's ``Central Park, 1900.'' It closes on July 22 and unlike many of the gallery's shows, will only be seen in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Child-Care Bill Would Cut Aid for Middle-Class Families
DOC.TEXT: A major child-care assistance bill passed by the House would take away the only government help that many middle-class and upper-income families get for child care. To provide funds for the $27 billion measure, which primarily benefits lower-income families, Democratic sponsors put limits on the dependent-care tax credit that is popular with many professionals and two-income households. More than 500,000 taxpayers took the dependent-care credit in 1986, the last year for which the Internal Revenue Service could provide figures. Congressional tax estimates figure roughly 900,000 would be affected in 1991. Families of all income levels are eligible for the credit designed to offset a portion of child care expenses: 20 percent to 30 percent, depending on income, of eligible expenses up to $4,800. But the House bill would reduce the credit for families with combined incomes over $70,000 a year and end it entirely at $90,000. Families at that level are regarded as upper income and affluent, and they had few defenders in the House debate. Some lawmakers did have reservations about eliminating the deduction. They said the issue is more complex than merely soaking the rich or targeting the yuppies. ``In many states, $70,000 translates into a familiy headed by two police officers or two teachers,'' said Rep. Pat Schroeder, D-Colo., who voted for the bill anyway. The heart of the child-care assistance bill, which passed Thursday after months of wrangling, is an expansion of the earned income tax credit, which goes to working families with children and incomes up to about $20,000. The House bill, which is under a threat of veto by President Bush, is headed for a conference committee to resolve differences with the Senate's version. The bill the Senate passed last year does not reduce the dependent-care credit. It is less costly than the House version and provides smaller tax credits to the poor. A sponsor of the House bill, Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., had little sympathy for those seeking to save the credit. The House bill includes money to establish a system of day care based in the public schools that would be available to all families for a price. Downey said that was a good tradeoff for middle class and more affluent families. ``You'll notice a lack of the wagging of tongues on this issue,'' Downey said. ``It was not a topic of debate. There was fulsome recognition of the reality that middle class people needed to be taken care of, and the way to do that was ... the after-school program.'' The revenue recovered by cutting the credit is relatively small. The Congressional Budget Office put the amount at $1.5 billion over five years. Sponsors came up with another $13 billion by extending the telephone excise tax, but even with that the bill would add to the federal deficit. Women's groups have been watching closely as Congress fashions the bill. With 64 percent of women working outside the home, child care is a business expense just as necessary as a salesman's car, said Nancy Duff Campbell, managing partner of the National Women's Law Center, a lobbying group. ``If you're going to take away work-related benefits, that's fine, but do it across the board, not just for dependents and child care _ do it for business lunches and luxury trips,'' she said. ``What we object to is singling out this benefit that's so important to women.'' The credit covers more than just child care. Also affected are the expenses of special care for other dependents, such as an infirm parent or disabled spouse or older child. And it affects currently untaxed employer benefits, she said. For people above the cutoff level, employer-offered child care programs at free or reduced cost will become a taxable benefit. Eliminating the credit has been attempted before. House Democrats included it in the 1988 welfare reform bill. But it was eliminated in the Senate, where Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., attacked the move as ``robbing Jill to pay Jane.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Death Row Inmate Among Seven Jail Escapees
DOC.TEXT: Seven prisoners, one of them just taken off death row, were still at large today after an evening breakout from the Yellowstone County jail. One prisoner, Cecil Thornell, 40, was captured at a residence in Billings, but further details were not immediately available, said police Sgt. Rich St. John. Jailers discovered the breakout at 9:45 p.m. Friday, Sheriff Mike Shafer said. The prisoners apparently scaled the 10-foot brick wall of a small recreation yard and cut through a chain-link screen that covered it, the sheriff said. Shafer said bolt cutters or a hacksaw would have been needed to cut the screen, and he said they may have had help. One escapee was Bernard Fitzpatrick, 47, who spent almost 14 years on death row until federal courts overturned his death sentence for the kidnap-murder of an 18-year-old grocery store clerk during a robbery in Hardin. Fitzpatrick last week pleaded guilty to kidnapping and murder in a plea bargain that will eliminate the death sentence, but insists he is innocent. Judge G. Todd Baugh set no sentencing date. Fitzpatrick had been brought to Billings from the state prison in Deer Lodge for the plea hearing. The other six jail escapees were all awaiting trial. Thornell was charged with robbing a gasoline station while on parole for armed robbery. The escapees also included Frank Belmarez, 22, of Billings, who is charged with homicide and aggravated assault in the stabbing death of his girlfriend outside a bar last October. The others were identified as Daniel Wilson, 27, of Laurel, charged with suspicion of drug possession and criminal endangerment; Tony Howland, 24, of Billings, charged with probation violation for felony theft and possession of a weapon by a prisoner; Kevin Devereaux, 26, of Poplar, a federal prisoner charged with burglary and distribution of a controlled substance; and Elwood Hall, 24, of Brockton, scheduled for trial on Monday on charges of aggravated sexual abuse.

DOC.HEAD: Kenyan Clergymen Sentenced to Six Years on Sedition Charge
DOC.TEXT: A clergyman convicted of sedition for entries he made in his desk diary has been sentenced to six years in prison as part of a government crackdown on what it calls ``rumormongers.'' The Rev. Lawford N. Imunde, a minister with the Presbyterian Church of East Africa, pleaded guilty to the charge Friday. Imunde was unrepresented at the hearing. ``These writings were scandalous, to say the least,'' prosecutor Bernard Chunga said. ``They belittled the government and clearly show contempt of the law.'' Chunga did not read the entries in court but gave copies to Chief Magistrate George Omondi Tunya. Imunde, a Kenyan, was arrested in a Nairobi suburb March 19. He was charged Wednesday, hours after a judge ordered police to explain why they had detained the clergyman. He was the first person charged since the crackdown began in mid-February following the murder of Foreign Minister Robert Ouko. More than 40 people have been detained for questioning without charge, but most have been released in a matter of hours. Several Kenyan politicians, including President Daniel arap Moi, have complained that unidentified individuals were attemping to discredit the government by spreading rumors that the state engineered Ouko's murder.

DOC.HEAD: IsraeliExperts Say Pre-Emptive Strike Against Iraq Unlikely
