DOC.TEXT: Israel is unlikely to stage a pre-emptive strike against Iraq despite revelations that the Arab nation may have an advanced nuclear weapons program, political analysts said Saturday. ``Iraq now has missiles, and they are telling us in so many words that they will be using them if we strike,'' said Amatzia Bar-Am, an Iraq specialist at Haifa University. ``I don't think Israel would be foolish enough to start this kind of cycle of violence.'' ``The situation in the Middle East has changed since 1981,'' he said, referring to Israel's bombing of an Iraqi nuclear reactor that Israel said could have been used to produce nuclear weapons. Iraq said the facility was to be used for peaceful purposes. U.S. newspaper reports, citing classified CIA material, have said Iraq has positioned missile launchers in the western part of the country, within range of Tel Aviv. The Israeli government has not commented following Wednesday's arrest in London of five people in an alleged plot to smuggle nuclear weapons triggers to Iraq. ``We have no comment on it. It's something that happened between England and Iraq,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Yossi Amihud said Saturday. Aides to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir have also refused to comment. Political observers said Israel's verbal restraint was a sign that it did not want to escalate tensions with Iraq, one of its most implacable enemies in the Middle East. Iraq, meanwhile, has accelerated its rhetoric. Responding to the arrests in Britain, Iraq's deputy foreign minister, Nizar Hamdoun, said ``the current British campaign is trying to provide the groundwork for an Israeli aggression against Iraq, reminding us of the year 1981.'' But Bar-Am said another strike was unfeasible. He noted that in 1981 the Osirak nuclear reactor near Baghdad provided a clear target for Israeli warplanes, but Iraq's current nuclear program is spread across the country. ``There is no easily identifiable target that you hit and then get rid of the whole nuclear option,'' he said. ``There doesn't seem to exist anywhere an atomic reactor.'' Israeli military analysts have estimated that Iraq is less than five years away from developing nuclear weapons and that it was making rapid strides in producing other unconventional weapons. ``They are making an effort, not only in the nuclear field, but also with regards to missiles, to chemical weapons and to biological weapons,'' said Zeev Eitan, a senior analyst with Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies, in an interview with Israel radio broadcast Saturday. Political analysts agreed with Bar-Am that hostilities between Israel and Iraq were unlikely in the near future because of mutual deterrence, but warned that a major crisis in the Middle East could set off a confrontation between the region's two mightiest military powers.

DOC.HEAD: Minimum Wage Increases Sunday for First Time Since 1981
DOC.TEXT: The nation's minimum wage increases for the first time in nearly a decade Sunday, but it won't lift millions of low-wage workers above the poverty level. The minimum wage, paid to about 3 million Americans, increases from $3.35 an hour to $3.80 and will go to $4.25 an hour next April 1. The new law also establishes a subminimum training wage for certain teen-age workers. Critics say the increase should have been greater. ``Right now, it's not at a level where people can pull themselves out of poverty,'' said Jo Ann Mort of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union. ``When people hear minimum wage, they think children working after school, and that's not the reality of it. The reality is that adults are trying to support families on this,'' Mort said. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., last week called the size of the increase a ``disgrace'' and said he would push Congress next year to bring the wage to ``a level that is fair to millions of workers who are being unfairly exploited now.'' Kennedy blamed the size of the increase on the Bush administration, which vetoed a proposal last year to raise the wage to $4.55 an hour. The increase was ``the best we could do against an anti-worker administration that refuses to do justice for America's working poor,'' said Kennedy, chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. The administration considers the increase an equitable boost that will result in fewer jobs being lost than under the $4.55 proposal, White House spokesman Stephen Hart said. Polls have shown a majority of Americans support a minimum wage of at least $5 an hour. The minimum wage was established in 1938 as part of the first Fair Labor Standards Act. During its first 40 years, Congress acted six times to keep the rate at about 50 percent of the average hourly earnings of all non-supervisory employees. The $3.35 rate, which equaled 48 percent of the national average earnings in 1981, fell to an all-time low of 35 percent of the nation's average earnings last year, according to the AFL-CIO. After Sunday's increase, full-time minimum-wage workers will still be $516 a year short of what the government figures it takes to support a family of two at the poverty level and $4,796 below the basic needs level for a family of four. The government placed the poverty level for a family of four at $12,700 in February. Still, the boost in the minimum wage may help millions of other low-paid workers. For instance, companies paying $4 or $4.50 an hour may decide to raise wages 45 cents to keep trained workers. There are more than 11 million Americans making less than $4.50 an hour and nearly 15 million making under $5 an hour, according to the Labor Department. Under the new law, workers ages 16 to 19 may be paid a subminimum training wage for their first three months in the work force and for an additional 90 days if the employer has a formal training program. The training wage will be $3.35 an hour when the minimum wage rises to $3.80 an hour and $3.62 an hour when the minimum wage reaches $4.25 next April. Migrant seasonal farmworkers are exempt from the subminimum and the entire subminimum provision expires in April 1993. The wage that employers are required to pay workers who receive tips will increase to 45 percent of the minimum wage, providing that tips bring workers' hourly pay to at least the minimum. The percentage, which was 40 percent before Sunday, goes to 50 percent a year from now. The level at which small businesses are exempt from the federal minimum wage increases from $362,500 in gross sales to $500,000. Hundreds of special exemptions exist, such as for some farm workers, including tobacco leaf harvesters, casual babysitters, newspaper delivery workers, amusement park employees, wreath makers, employees at small radio stations in cities with fewer than 25,000 residents and mollusk and crustacean harvesters.

DOC.HEAD: Key Provisions of Minimum Wage Increase
With AM-Minimum Wage Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are key provisions of the legislation Congress passed last year to increase the minimum wage to $4.25 an hour and establish a subminimum training wage for certain teen-age workers. The measure takes effect Sunday.
DOC.HEAD: THE RATE
DOC.TEXT: The minimum wage, $3.35 an hour since January 1981, increases to $3.80 an hour on Sunday and to $4.25 an hour on April 1, 1991. An estimated 4 million Americans work for the minimum wage.
DOC.HEAD: TRAINING WAGE
DOC.TEXT: Workers ages 16 to 19 may be paid a subminimum training wage for their first three months in the work force and for an additional 90 days if the employer has a formal training program. The training wage will be $3.35 an hour when the minimum wage rises to $3.80 an hour and $3.62 an hour when the minimum wage reaches $4.25 next April. Migrant seasonal farmworkers are exempt from the subminimum and the entire subminimum provision expires in April 1993.
DOC.HEAD: WAGE-POVERTY LEVEL
DOC.TEXT: After the increase, full-time minimum wage workers would still find themselves $516 a year short of what it takes to support one adult and one child at the poverty level, according to government figures. Minimum wage workers would be $4,796 below the basic needs level for a family of four.
DOC.HEAD: TIP CREDIT
DOC.TEXT: The wage employers are required to pay workers who receive tips will increase from 40 percent of the minimum wage to 45 percent of the minimum wage on April 1. The law requires that tips plus wages must equal the minimum hourly wage. The percentage goes to 50 percent a year from now.
DOC.HEAD: SMALL BUSINESS EXEMPTION
DOC.TEXT: The level at which small businesses are exempt from the federal minimum wage increases from $362,500 in gross annual sales to $500,000.
DOC.HEAD: OTHER EXEMPTIONS
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of special exemptions exist, such as for some farm workers, including tobacco leaf harvesters, casual babysitters, newspaper delivery workers, amusement park employees, wreath makers, employees at small radio stations in cities with fewer than 25,000 residents and mollusk and crustacean harvesters.

DOC.HEAD: Contents Of Storage Tanks At Nuclear Reservation Sometimes A Mystery
DOC.TEXT: There is a potentially explosive witches' brew cooking inside 177 nuclear waste storage tanks at the Hanford nuclear reservation. Surrounded by steel and concrete, buried under several feet of earth, and roasting at temperatures of 140 degrees, the radioactive slurry changes in ways that scientists cannot always predict. Scientists working for the U.S. Department of Energy concluded that hydrogen gas trapped beneath the hard crust of the waste in 20 of the tanks could explode, releasing up to 3 million curies of radiation from a single tank. The wastes are generated by nuclear weapons production. Hanford was created as part of the Manhattan Project to beat Nazi Germany to the atomic bomb during World War II. The Department of Energy, in a cost-cutting move, recently announced it is shutting down the only federal reactor still operating in the south-central Washington town. ``We've got good data on what went into those tanks,'' Don Wodrich, a scientist with contractor Westinghouse Hanford Co., said last week. ``But over the years, it blended together and mixed. Now it's more complicated.'' The insides of the tanks are far too lethal for human entry. All scientists can do is monitor the temperature and vapors escaping through filtered vents, and occasionally send a probe into the guck. But probes of the 20 suspect tanks have been stopped, because scientists fear a spark could trigger an explosion. The explosion potential was announced March 23, along with a unique admission that DOE really isn't sure how dangerous the situation is. The agency said it will take until June to come up with a solution plan. That has prompted criticism from Congress and a citizens' watchdog group, who contend the department knew about the danger years ago. The Energy Department have stated repeatedly that the explosion risk is low, although they will not have a safety analysis completed for two weeks. Spokesman Ken Morgan has said there is more danger to the public from a gasoline truck than from the tanks, and called the controversy the ``cold fusion'' of disasters, referring to the highly disputed claim that the nuclear process known as fusion can be created in an ordinary laboratory. That attitude infuriates Hanford critics. ``They don't fully accept their responsibility to protect public health and safety,'' said Jim Thomas of the Hanford Education Action League in Spokane. ``They should have been doing risk analysis on this stuff years ago.'' Energy Department officials insisted last week they became aware of the explosion potential only in February, even though they detected hydrogen in the wastes as early as 1983. Hanford Manager Mike Lawrence, in announcing the problem, said he had become aware of the danger only the day before. If that is the case, said Thomas, then Hanford apparently has major management problems. Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., said a study prepared for the Energy Department in June 1985 warned of potential problems with gases in some Hanford tanks. That report examined only the liquid and solid waste in the tanks, but said the gases should be addressed in another study. Wyden said the 1985 report ``seems to contradict this whole notion that the Energy Department didn't know anything about it.'' The 1985 hydrogen study was a companion to another study on whether ferrocyanide in some tanks could explode. The ferrocyanide report was leaked to reporters last October. Under criticism for its handling of that issue, the Energy Department decided to take a broader look at the explosion potential in all Hanford tanks, and scientists discovered the hydrogen problem in late February, scientist Wodrich said. The explosion threat is apparently not similar to the presumed cause of a nuclear waste storage tank explosion in the Soviet Union in 1957 that may have killed hundreds. Al Conklin of the state Office of Radiation Protection said the Soviet explosion involved a different mixture of chemicals and a lengthy breakdown of the tank's cooling system. The DOE is most concerned about one tank, called 101-SY, that contains 1 million gallons of mixed radioactive waste. Some wastes dumped into the tank in the 1970s contained organics, which are now decomposing and giving off hydrogen gas. The organics were used to separate radioactive strontium from other wastes before they were stored. The most dangerous gases are those trapped in air pockets under the hard crust. Scientists are unsure how much gas is beneath the waste, although they credit the gas with raising the waste level by up to 33 inches. Wodrich said DOE officials are confident the explosion risk is low because the hydrogen gas has apparently existed in the waste for years, and that new precautions are being taken to prevent an explosion. In a briefing for state regulators, Wodrich said tank 101-SY was completed in 1976 and is 75 feet in diameter and 35 feet tall. The double-walled tank contains about 32 feet of waste. The tank also contains 8,000 gallons of water inserted in 1984-1988, when DOE made an unsuccessful attempt to reduce the gas buildup by breaking through the crust. The crust develops from the drying of the wastes.

DOC.HEAD: Advance for use at 6:30 p.m. EST, March 31. Time set by source. ^Latin American Incomes Fell Again in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Incomes fell again in Latin America last year, deepeningt an overall decline for the decade of the 1980s, according to a report published Saturday by the Inter-American Development Bank. Production in the area grew by only 0.7 percent for the year. Since population grew by about 2.4 percent a year _ more than three times as fast _ the average person's income went down. Incomes declined by 8 percent over the 10 years, back to the level of 1978. ``The region's disappointing overall growth masks good performance in a number of countries,'' the report said. It added that many have acted to improve their performance in the 1990s. But it warned: ``Without sustained expansion in investment, output and employment, the deterioration in living conditions suffered by large segments of the region's population during the 1980s will continue in the decade ahead.'' The last two countries to emerge from dictatorship, Chile and Paraguay, turned in the best records. After a sharp decline in the first half of the 1980s, production in Chile perked up to an exceptional 8.5 percent last year. That growth rate, combined with a population increase smaller than most countries in the area, gave it by far the best increase in incomes. But according to the World Bank, the average Chilean received the equivalent of only $1,510 in 1988, the latest year for which figures are available. That is well below the level for the area. The average Brazilian earned $2,280, the average Mexican $1,820 and the average U.S. citizen $19,780. Production in seven out of 25 countries declined last year, with the biggest drop in Peru: 14 percent. Peru's record was due in part to a continuing leftist rebellion by ``Shining Path'' guerrillas. Brazil and Mexico, Latin America's most populous countries, managed 3 percent increases in production despite problems with debt and inflation. The bank itself, owned by 44 member countries, disbursed a record $2.5 billion in loans and spent a record $61 million on technical aid last year. It has loans outstanding on $122 billion worth of projects designed to raise living standards in the area. After a three-year slump, the amount of new loans approved rose in 1989 to $2.6 billion. The increases came after three years of negotiation by the United States and other contributing governments to get more power over the bank's lending. They can now delay a proposed loan for as long as a year. The bank has also begun a program of quickly-disbursed loans, conditioned on promises by the borrowing countries to change their policies and put themselves in better condition to repay.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's 21st Census Day is Here
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 12th graf pvs, bgng: Census forms, to CORRECT that forms mailed 10 days ago, sted last week. SUBS 14th graf, bgng: Although Sunday to DELETE extraneous date, April 1
DOC.TEXT: Americans are being asked to sit down, take out a pencil and count themselves on Sunday. It's the 21st time the United States has taken its own measure. And like a youngster standing against the wall, the result is bigger every time. ``Our goal for the 1990 census is to count every person resident in the United States,'' said Thomas Murrin, deputy secretary of Commerce. ``We are ready and confident....'' ``It's important to answer the census. It's safe to answer the census,'' said Census Director Barbara Everitt Bryant, stressing that information on individuals is kept confidential. The national count isn't just a case of idle curiosity on the part of the government. The Constitution requires a count every 10 years to reassign seats in the House of Representatives among the states. And other information collected is used to determine the need for many social programs and to decide which states, cities and towns most need federal money to help their residents in one way or another. ``In many respects the census is an index to our quality of life,'' said John G. Keane of Notre Dame University, former head of the Census Bureau. ``The census shows us anew where our nation hurts and needs help.'' ``Recite the national agenda and we realize how its resolution is directly or indirectly rooted in census data,'' he said. ``The aging population, births, deaths, education, household composition, housing quality, income and poverty, fertility, single parent families, occupations, population mobility, disability, the homeless are just a few examples of what the census covers,'' Keane said. Census forms were sent to about 85 million homes 10 days ago, and government workers will visit millions more where mailing lists were not available. Most people got the short form with just 14 questions. The long form, which went to one home in six, has much more detail, forming a sort of giant national survey. Although Sunday is officially designated as Census Day, many people completed their forms and sent them in ahead of time. That's just fine with the government. It's the folks who don't respond who are a problem. Far too many people ``approach the census as a ho-hum event. They should not, for the census is vital to our way of life and our quality of life,'' said Keane. A decade ago 75 percent of the people who received forms in the mail completed them and sent them back. The country is bigger and more complex today. The bureau is hoping to get back 70 percent this time. Sending workers out to find people who don't respond costs taxpayers $10 million for each 1 percent. Yet the bureau is determined to come as close as possible to counting everyone. ``We are prepared to chase and chase and chase again,'' said Bryant. But while the count is getting lots of attention right now, don't expect instant results. It's not like an election, where preliminary reports come out based on a few precincts or cities. The Census Bureau keeps all the data it collects strictly confidential until it can be compiled into detailed reports and then made public _ in such a way that no individuals can be identified from the material. The first result from the count won't be reported until Dec. 31, when the bureau as to tell the president how many people live in each state and how many members of the House of Representatives that state is entitled to. More detailed reports on individual states will be issued starting after the first of the year. The schedule isn't determined yet, depending on how well things go in individual states. Those reports will include such information as age, sex, race and household relationships, marital status, whether people are Hispanic or not and a variety of housing data.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Foreign Journalists Dwindles in Lithuania
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The number of Western journalists covering Lithuania's standoff with Moscow from the Baltic republic's capital has dropped sharply since the Soviet government ordered the area closed to most foreigners. More than 100 journalists based in Moscow and other European capitals followed events from the Lithuanian capital, but most were expected to be out of Vilnius on Sunday. Only a handful remained on Saturday. Despite the greater freedom of movement permitted under glasnost, Soviet authorities have routinely closed areas stricken by ethnic violence to foreign journalists. Some regions regarded as strategically or politically sensitive are closed at all times, others only temporarily. The order restricting journalists' access to Lithuania came as the Kremlin increased pressure on the rebellious republic and as Lithuanian leaders sought to use the Western media to protect them from a use of force to crush their effort to establish an independent state. Moscow-based foreign journalists must give the Soviet Foreign Ministry advance notice of any plans to travel outside the Soviet capital, including the dates and means of their travel and where they will stay outside Moscow. The Soviet government may refuse to permit the trip, temporarily closing areas to foreigners. The Foreign Ministry on March 23 stopped permitting most Moscow-based reporters from traveling to Lithuania and ordered a number of diplomats out of the republic. However, journalists already in Lithuania were permitted to stay. Four days later, Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskykh told a Moscow news briefing that ``foreigners have been asked to leave the borders of Lithuania and temporarily refrain from entering its territory.'' Most correspondents accredited by the Foreign Ministry began returning to Moscow, but The Associated Press and some other organizations kept their journalists in place until contacted directly by Foreign Ministry officials. On Friday, Foreign Ministry officials called news organizations with correspondents remaining in Vilnius and said they must leave by Sunday. The AP, which still had a reporter and two photographers covering the story, said it would comply with the ministry's instructions by the deadline.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Continues Balancing Act on Lithuania
With AM-Lithuania Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is rooting for both sides in the battle of wills between Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the breakaway republic of Lithuania. On the one hand, Bush defends the right of self-determination for Lithuania. On the other hand, he doesn't want to see Gorbachev weakened or driven from power as a result of Lithuania's push to secede from the Soviet Union. Despite U.S. warnings against using force, Gorbachev faces mounting pressures at home to take a hard line toward Lithuania, officials say. And there is a widespread belief in Washington that a crackdown would produce a severe backlash against Moscow. ``We have big equities in this,'' a senior administration official said. ``It isn't in anybody's interest to have this thing blow up,'' the official added. ``Nobody really wins from the blowup.'' Bush sent Gorbachev a letter Thursday night which White House officials said restated U.S. views on Lithuania and underscored hopes for a peaceful dialogue to resolve the dispute. ``I want to be sure that the Soviets understand our position and understand that we're not trying to make things difficult for Lithuania or the Soviet Union or anybody else,'' Bush said. Yet, the administration ordered a postponement of a visit to Moscow by Gen. Carl E. Vuono, the U.S. Army chief of staff. His host would have been the Soviet commander in Lithuania, and U.S. officials said that would have been inappropriate. A crackdown would spoil Lithuanian dreams of independence, give the Soviets a black eye in world opinion and disrupt the smooth path of superpower relations, U.S. officials say. The casualties could include hopes for a U.S.-Soviet nuclear weapons treaty, as well as agreements on chemical weapons and conventional forces in Europe, as well as a planned summit between Bush and Gorbachev. ``It is fair to say that if President Gorbachev resorts to force, then all bets are off,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., warned. ``The Soviets will be in real trouble here _ no trade agreements, no trade preferences and no more of the kind of relations the Kremlin is desperately seeking from Washington,'' Dole said. ``It would be a severe blow to U.S.-Soviet relations.'' White House officials agree with Dole's assessment, but have muted their criticisms and warnings. Their goal is not to push Gorbachev into a corner where it would be difficult for him to make concessions. ``Were it not for Gorbachev and the enlightened positions he's taken ... we wouldn't be talking about Lithuanian independence,'' the administration official said. The administration points to Gorbachev as the architect of reform in his country who tolerated democratic reforms throughout Eastern Europe. ``Sure, we have a preferred outcome for the Lithuanians,'' the official said. ``But we also have _ and the world has _ some pretty big equities in what's going on now. And so what we're trying to do is preserve those, as well.'' One theory circulating among high-level officials in the administration is that Gorbachev is trying to slow the Lithuanian process until he can get a bill through the Supreme Soviet spelling out terms for secession. ``It's pretty stiff,'' one official said of Gorbachev's bill. ``There are pretty high barriers to get across.'' In contrast to other foreign policy issues, Bush has been spared criticism from Congress about his guarded approach. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., said Congress is playing a supporting role in a classic ``good cop-bad cop'' routine. ``Our role is to demand (independence) today, even though it may not be possible for a month,'' D'Amato said. ``It is to be outspoken. I think we can be a useful tool (for Bush) and I don't mind lending ourselves for that purpose.'' Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., said Bush ``is obviously engaged in a very difficult balancing act. ``There is concern that Gorbachev not be pushed into a precipitous act, that time be gained whereby there can be a negotiation that will let Gorbachev save face and still bring about the independence and freedom of Lithuania,'' Wilson said. The administration is unsure what will happen in Lithuania. ``Our first objective is to try to prevent (a blowup), try to get things down, reduce tensions, stop ultimatums from being issued, preconditions, get people talking calmly and rationally,'' the senior official said. However, the official said, ``If Gorbachev is trying to keep Lithuania in, and the Lithuanians are trying to get out, they both can't win.'' Yet, the official added, there are possible avenues for compromise, such as giving Lithuania sovereignty but requiring it to defer to Moscow on foreign policy and defense issues. ``There are lots of different ways,'' the official concluded.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Gorbachev's Message to Lithuanian Lawmakers
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's message Saturday to the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet, as carried by the Tass news agency. The statement was read by announcers on Radio Moscow and Soviet television.

The incumbent Lithuanian leadership does not heed the voice of reason. It continues to ignore the decision of the third, extraordinary Congress of U.S.S.R. People's Deputies and is taking unilateral steps that run counter to the U.S.S.R. Constitution and that are openly challenging and insulting to the entire union. I want to declare yet again that this road is ruinous and will only lead to a dead end. I urge the deputies of the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet to understand this truth and their historical responsibility for the interests of the people of Lithuania _ Lithuanians and non-Lithuanians, for their security and well being, for the destiny of democracy in the whole of our country and of stability in the world. I propose that the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet immediately annul the illegal acts it has adopted. Such a step will open a possibility for discussing the entire range of problems on the solely acceptable basis _ within the framework of the U.S.S.R. constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Sales Tax Hike in Kansas City to Fund Anti-Drug Efforts
DOC.TEXT: The war on drugs picks up new recruits here Sunday, when each person who buys something in Jackson County begins chipping in to help authorities arrest, jail and treat abusers. The Kansas City metropolitan area, faced with one of the nation's worst drug problems, is raising taxes by an estimated $14 million a year to help authorities tackle a drug culture boosted by the infiltration of Los Angeles gangs. The one-quarter-cent rise in sales tax will generate nearly $100 million over its seven-year life from over-the-counter sales in Jackson County, which incorporates Kansas City and its suburbs. The nation's 29th largest metropolitan area ranks sixth in the availability of crack, and police believe that one-third or moer of last year's 141 killings were drug-related. ``I am not aware of any approach like it in the United States,'' said Larry Myers, administrator of the Jackson County Juvenile Court. ``I guarantee there are other communities watching to see what the outcome is.'' Voters in Jackson County authorized the tax in November. Since then, officials have been putting together plans to use the money. It will enable the county prosecutor to add about 25 prosecutors to his staff, and the Kansas City Police Department and the Jackson County Drug Enforcement Task Force to hire 30 more officers each. That will cost each department $1.5 million a year. The campaign focuses primarily on enforcement, but $2.5 million a year is earmarked for drug rehabilitation programs, $1 million for community crime prevention programs and $1.5 million for a deferral program that would allow first-time offenders to receive drug counseling and avoid criminal charges. ``I'm really excited about this because it's systemwide,'' Myers said. ``If it was only law enforcement, it'd be just stacking up kids and adults in the court system.'' Kansas City's drug problems have mushroomed in recent years, and police Chief Larry Joiner said enforcement officials estimate 35 percent to 40 percent of last year's 141 homicides were drug-related. Police say the problems have been aggravated in recent years by Los Angeles gangs spreading their drug-dealing to Midwest cities. Police in outlying suburban areas also welcome the additional funds. ``We don't have the numbers of crack houses and dope houses, or people soliciting off the street corners, like they do in Kansas City,'' said Howard Brown, chief of police in Blue Springs, an eastern Jackson County community of about 40,000. ``But we do have a drug problem, there's no doubt. It's not running rampant, but there are drugs available in the school system _ that's one thing we want to make drug-free.'' Brown will be able to hire three officers for his 45-member staff. Once they're trained, they will replace three seasoned officers who will be assigned to the expanded county drug task force, begun three years ago with a private donation and kept going through federal grants. The county task force has ``been operating on a shoestring,'' Brown said. ``We're pretty enthused now that we'll have enough people to really hit the streets and enough money to get involved in making more buys.'' But others foresee problems with the tax and the programs it will finance. Charles Megerman, the county corrections director, says he doesn't know what the drug program will mean for a jail already filled well beyond capacity. ``There are a whole host of options, from renting space to double-bunking to building a new jail,'' he said. And Jack Hackley, a real estate agent from suburban Oak Grove and a member of the county Economic Development Commission who spoke out against the new tax, said he might start a petition drive to repeal it. Hackley said the tax swept in on the strength of national hysteria over drugs, and thinks the extent of the drug problem has been grossly exaggerated. ``This is the biggest mistake the taxpayers have ever made,'' he said. ``It should be repealed immediately. For all that money, we could take every drug addict in Jackson County and ship them to the Betty Ford Clinic.''

DOC.HEAD: Premier Fires Intelligence Chief Over TV Jamming Row
DOC.TEXT: Premier Xenophon Zolotas on Saturday fired Greece's intelligence service chief because he was late in briefing him on allegations that his agency was jamming the broadcasts of an illegal TV station. Zolotas summoned the heads of the four ministries and National Information Service chief Dimitris Angelopoulos to an emergency meeting, the government spokesman said. The meeting was called after two intelligence agents were arrested Friday night and accused of jamming transmissions of the Channel 29 television station. Angelopoulos arrived at the meeting two hours late and was dismissed. ``Mr. Angelopoulos showed inexcusable negligence in the performance of his duties by not immediately briefing his superior, in this case the prime minister, who had sought him repeatedly and with every means at his disposal,'' government spokesman Prokopis Pavlopoulos said. The commercial Channel 29 television station, one of several operating without a license, aired footage of two men being arrested on Mount Hymettos near Athens. It accused them of using electronic equipment to jam broadcasts from the station's nearby antenna. The two men were released after the intelligence service assured police and judicial authorities that they were agents acting on official orders, the Public Order Ministry said in a statement. It did not eleborate. Zolotas ordered an inquiry into the incident by the Public Order, Justice and Transport and Communications ministries. The government urged political parties to maintain a calm climate before next week's general elections. The socialists, who are supported by Channel 29, accused the conservative New Democracy party of being behind the alleged jamming. The conservatives denied involvement and urged an official inquiry into the matter.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Officials See Favorable Prospects for Peace in El Salvador
DOC.TEXT: A variety of pressures on both sides in El Salvador's civil war have created the most favorable climate for a peaceful settlement since the conflict began a decade ago, according to U.S. officials. The new mood has been highlighted by the plans of Salvadoran government officials and leftist guerrilla representatives to hold peace talks with U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar next Wednesday in Geneva. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has said he is hopeful a peace settlement can be reached this year. The death toll in El Salvador since 1980 is believed to exceed 70,000. The electoral defeat of the Sandinista government in Nicaragua five weeks ago is seen as a costly blow to the rebels in light of the support they have received from that country for more than a decade. The U.S. officials, speaking only on condition they not be named, said the Sandinistas have sharply increased military deliveries to the rebels since the Feb. 25 elections. The Sandinista goal apparently is to help the rebels as much as possible before they leave office on April 25. Still, the rebels are not the same fighting force they were a year ago. Much of their strength was sapped in a November military uprising that failed to touch off the nationwide anti-government uprising which U.S. officials said the rebels had hoped for. Internationally, support for a negotiated settlement is strong. The Soviet Union, reflecting a changed attitude, issued an appeal last November during the rebel offensive for an ``immediate end to the bloodshed'' and for peace talks. The Soviet statement contrasted sharply with the expressions of strong support for the guerrillas by Cuban President Fidel Castro. The future of Cuban aid to the rebels is now in doubt with the defeat of the Sandinistas. Cuba routinely has used Nicaragua as a transit point for military deliveries to the FMLN rebels, U.S. officials have said. The government of Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani also is facing pressures to seek an accommodation. Peace would bring a needed lift to the Salvadoran economy, whose performance has been aggravated by falling prices of coffee, a major Salvadoran export. Salvadoran officials also are aware that there are limits to the generosity of the United States, which contributed more than $3 billion in aid during the 1980s. After reaching $301.4 million last year, the U.S. economic aid level for 1990 is $227.9 million, a drop of about 25 percent. The decline reflects U.S. weariness with the Salvadoran conflict and the increased demands on U.S. aid dollars, brought on by the addition of new recipient countries in Eastern Europe. Moreover, Sen. Chris Dodd, D-Conn., is leading a campaign to impose strict conditions on U.S. military aid _ totaling almost $100 million _ to El Salvador. His proposal, designed to promote a serious negotiating process, is expected to be a contentious issue in the Congress this spring. U.S. officials are worried that the Dodd proposal could weaken the Salvadoran government's negotiating hand. But they also stress that the rebels' bargaining position also is weak, regardless of the outcome of the Dodd proposal. The final form of a peace settlement is difficult to predict. At a minimum, the officials said it would probably have to require amnesty for rebel combatants and government security guarantees for them.

DOC.HEAD: Traffickers Threaten Stepped Up Bombings, Assassinations
DOC.TEXT: Stung by extraditions and military raids, drug traffickers threatened Saturday to explode six-ton dynamite bombs in Bogota and to target more judges, politicians, police and journalists for assassination. The threat from the Medellin cocaine cartel, in a communique, followed the government's extradition of a drug suspect to the United States last week _ its first in two months _ and its takeover of a town run by drug bosses. President Virgilio Barco said in a televised speech to the nation Friday night that his government would not ease up in its war on the traffickers. He was to leave Sunday for Paris, London and Brussels to press European leaders to work hard to stem cocaine consumption in their countries. The drug traffickers' message, sent by facsimile to the RCN radio network, demanded an immediate end to the military occupation of Envigado, the town seized last week, and the release of two men arrested in the takeover. The 80,000-resident municipality is a stronghold of the cocaine barons near their home base of Medellin. The message said a six-ton bomb would be detonated in the capital for each new trafficking suspect extradited and that a bomb of equal power would be set off in an unnamed Bogota upper class neighborhood unless the military ends its occupation of Envigado. On Dec. 6, a 1,200-pound bomb set off by the traffickers in Bogota killed 63 people and destroyed the headquarters of Colombia's national police. The traffickers declared a unilateral cease-fire on Jan. 17, appealing to the government to end extraditions in exchange for the traffickers allowing themselves to be tried in Colombian courts. The government then halted extraditions, but resumed them Wednesday when it sent Fernando Gutierrez, 29, to face trial in Arizona on drug trafficking and money laundering charges. He was the 15th such suspect extradited since Barco launched a crackdown on the traffickers Aug. 18. The communique was attributed to ``The Extraditables,'' the name adopted by the Medellin cartel after traffickers responded to Barco's crackdown with a campaign of bombings and assassinations that has claimed at least 210 lives. There was no way to verify the authenticity of the message. However, the Extraditables have used the same format and means of communication in the past. The country's National Security Council ordered the army and anti-terrorism units from the national police into Envigado, where 18 policemen accused of being on the traffickers' payroll had been arrested over the past two weeks. The message from the named the two men arrested in Envigado as Jose Cristanto Retavista Garzon and Fredy Lopez Ospina. Neither is a major trafficker, but the cartel has hundreds of middle-level traffickers and ``soldiers.'' The message reiterated previous claims that the police are arresting, torturing and killing ``friends'' of the traffickers, who are responsible for some 80 percent of the cocaine smuggled into the United States. ``We will execute judges, traitorous politicians, torturers and principal members of the Cano family,'' it said. Drug traffickers killed the paper's publisher, Guillermo Cano, with a burst of submachine gun fire as he left the newspaper's officies on Dec. 17, 1987. El Espectador had been crusading for government action against the traffickers. Cano's brother, sons and nephews continue to run the newspaper, which was partially destroyed by a truck bomb last year. A truck bomb set off by traffickers last year heavily damaged the newspaper, which had to go to the United States to look for financial aid to keep publishing. The threat by the traffickers to set off six-ton dynamite bombs is not likely to be dismissed by the government. Targets in the traffickers's terror campaign have included a Colombian airliner, which was blown apart by a bomb during a domestic flight, killed all 106 people aboard. Small bombs have gone off at churches, schools, supermarkets, banks and other businesses. For its part, the government has killed one of the Medellin cartel's leaders, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha. It also has seized traffickers' mansions, ranches, airplanes and yachts and troops searching dozens of the traffickers' ranches have found $43 million in cash and gold. The country's judges and leading politicians have been under heavy guard since Aug. 18, when traffickers gunned down leading presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan during a campaign rally. Last week, another presidential candidate, leftist Bernardo Jaramillo Ossa, was killed. In a communique, traffickers claimed responsibility and said the front-runner in the race, Cesar Gaviria of the governing Liberal Party, would be next. The elections are scheduled for May 26.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Postpones Talks With White Leaders, Says Climate Soured By Killings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with de Klerk comment; INSERTS 1 graf after xxx graf, `The Cabinet ...' with further de Klerk comment.
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress on Saturday postponed talks with the government on dismantling apartheid, saying that police shootings of black protesters have soured the negotiating climate. The move was considered a serious setback for efforts by the government of President F.W. de Klerk to open black-white discussions. De Klerk expressed regret over the violence, but urged the ANC to reconsider its postponement. Nelson Mandela, the ANC's deputy president, told tens of thousands of supporters that an April 11 meeting with the government was put on hold indefinitely because ``state violence against our people still continues.'' He cited excessive police force against protesters on Monday that left at least nine blacks dead and more than 400 injured in Sebokeng. Police said they opened fire after protesters stoned a police station in the township near Johannesburg and set fire to municipal buildings. ``If the government talks about negotiations on the one hand and massacres our people on the other hand, we cannot tolerate that,'' Mandela said at a packed sports stadium in the southern city of Bisho, capital of the nominally independent Ciskei homeland. ``The conditions for the (ANC's) armed struggle still prevail,'' he added. Mandela said he acted on instructions from exiled ANC leaders in Lusaka, Zambia, when he called de Klerk on Friday to tell him of the postponement. He did not say what it would take to reschedule the talks, which have been hailed as a groundbreaking effort to clear the way for extending political rights to the country's 28 million black majority. The Cabinet minister for black affairs, Constitutional Development Minister Gerrit Viljoen, said the white-led government was ``giving attention to the announcement's implications.'' He did not elaborate. De Klerk said he was awaiting a full report on the violence, but said the deaths should not be used to derail the proposed talks between black leaders and the government. Zach de Beer, co-leader of the anti-apartheid Democratic Party in the white chamber of Parliament, said ``the shooting at Sebokeng was a deplorable episode, (but) it can be no excuse for breaking off talks.'' ``One can only express the heartfelt hope that the ANC will think again, and quickly,'' de Beer added. ANC officials and other anti-apartheid leaders on Friday persuaded Mandela to back out of a planned appearance with political rival Mangosuthu Buthelezi, leader of the Zulu homeland. The two had agreed _ on Mandela's initiative _ to make a joint call for peace at a rally Monday in Natal Province, where fierce fighting between pro-ANC and pro-Buthelezi blacks has claimed at least 40 lives since Tuesday. Thousand of blacks caught up in the violence have fled their homes. Mandela, released from 27 years of imprisonment Feb. 11, is the effective head of the ANC while President Oliver Tambo recovers from a stroke in Sweden. But events of the past two days suggest he may not have the freedom to pursue his initiatives without the approval of younger, more militant ANC leaders. In Lusaka, the ANC said it would hold a meeting within five days to review developments in South Africa. The organization, the main black group fighting the government, accused security forces of siding with Buthelezi's relatively conservative Inkatha movement in the Natal province factional fighting. ``Whereas in the past the regime's police turned a blind eye to vigilante terror directed at the democratic movement, this week they have actually actively participated in the massacres,'' the ANC statement said. Mandela condemned the violence in Natal and elsewhere, but his appeals have had no impact. Several weeks ago he told blacks in Natal to throw their weapons ``into the sea.'' Since then, the faction fighting has only intensified. Supporters of the ANC and Buthelezi's more conservative Inkatha movement battled for political supremacy in Natal since 1986, and at least 4,000 blacks have been killed. Buthelezi expressed shock at Mandela's decision not to attend a rally Monday in the province. ``People are going to die while they (the ANC) delay,'' said Buthelezi, who like Mandela has made unheeded pleas for an end to the violence. The government has made clear that the ANC will be only one of several black groups that would be present for formal negotiations on a new constitution. De Klerk says he wants equal voting rights for all South Africans. But he opposes outright black majority rule and envisions a mechanism that will give the country's 5 million whites veto power on major policy decisions. The ANC wants a one-person, one-vote democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Capture Two of Seven Jail Breakers, Including Ex-Death Row Inmate
DOC.TEXT: Two jail escapees, one of whom was taken off death row only last week, were captured Saturday but four other escapees from the Yellowstone County jail were still at large, police said. Convicted murderer Bernard Fitzpatrick was among seven prisoners Friday night who scaled the 10-foot brick wall of a Yellowstone County jail's small recreation yard and cut through the chain-link screen that covered it. Fitzpatrick and federal prisoner Kevin Devereaux of Poplar were spotted by Billings residents around 9 a.m. and surrendered to police without resistance. ``No struggle, no shots fired, nobody hurt,'' said police Sgt. Rich St. John. Fitzpatrick, 47, spent almost 14 years on death row until federal courts overturned his death sentence for kidnapping and murdering an 18-year-old grocery store clerk during a robbery in Hardin in 1975. Fitzpatrick pleaded guilty last week to the kidnapping and murder, but continued to proclaim his innocence while accepting the plea bargain designed to thwart the death sentence. Judge G. Todd Baugh set no sentencing date. He had been brought to Billings from the state prison in Deer Lodge for the plea hearing. The other six jail escapees were all awaiting trial. Devereaux was in custody on federal charges of burglary and distribution of a controlled substance. Another escapee, Cecil Thornell, 40, was captured about 10:30 p.m. Friday, less than an hour after the escape was discovered, St. John said. He had been charged with robbing a gasoline station while on parole for armed robbery. The escapees still at large Saturday were Frank Belmarez, 22, of Billings, charged with homicide and aggravated assault in the stabbing death of his girlfriend outside a bar last October; Daniel Wilson, 27, of Laurel, charged with suspicion of drug possession and criminal endangerment; Tony Howland, 24, of Billings, charged with probation violation for felony theft and possession of a weapon by a prisoner; and Elwood Hall, 24, of Brockton, scheduled for trial on Monday on charges of aggravated sexual abuse.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Celebrate 100 Days of Freedom
LaserPhoto XBUC2
DOC.TEXT: Romanians on Saturday held a mass march to mark the 100th day since the bloody uprising that overthrew 45 years of Communist dictatorship. Thousands of flag-waving people, accompanied by soldiers in parade uniform, staged an officially sanctioned march through downtown Bucharest. They passed makeshift, candle-lit shrines along the streets and in squares marking spots where some of the fiercest fighting took place. The march started at a cathedral in front of Parliament, where services were held. President Ion Iliescu and Premier Petre Roman were there to join worshipers. After leaving the prayer services, some marchers walked to Heroes Cemetery at the outskirts of the capital, where several hundred people killed in the fierce street battles between pro-democracy demonstrators and security agents are buried. Another group rallied in front of the television building that was a focal point of much of the fighting. ``December 22 remains what it is ... the day on which the abolition of the dictatorship was proclaimed and when democracy was installed,'' said an editorial on the front page of Saturday's edition of the Tineretul Liber daily newspaper. Large-scale demonstrations against the regime of former dictator Nicolae Ceausescu first broke out in the western city of Timisoara on Dec. 16, but soon spread to other parts of the country. On Dec. 22, 1989, Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, fled the capital where street fighting had broken out between secret police loyal to his regime and the army, which sided with hundreds of thousands of demonstrators demanding an end to four decades of Communist rule. Ceausescu and his wife were quickly apprehended and later executed on Dec. 25. ``We must never again allow any egotistic individual ... thirsting for power to shunt the people aside and to make us enemies of each other,'' a commentary in the influential Adevarul newspaper declared. ``The martyrs ask us not only to think of them but also to learn from them.'' More than 60 parties, political associations and movements have been established since December. The country is currently led by a provisional government headed by the National Salvation Front. Saturday, three of Romania's leading opposition parties announced they were forming an alliance to compete with the Front in the upcoming May 20 national elections. Opposition parties have repeatedly condemned leaders of the Front for harboring pro-Commumist sentiments and for supporting a mixed economy with a preponderance of state-owned enterprises. Radu Campeanu, president of the centrist National Liberal Party, said the alliance would include his party as well as the Social Democrats and the National Peasants party. In its Saturday editorial Tineretul Liber said that ``the way to the ballot boxes should run next to the Heroes cemetry and everybody (at the coming) elections should pass through it.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS NASHVILLE-dated item on Bogguss to CORRECT spelling of Bogguss in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Country music singer Suzy Bogguss says she was bewildered at first by ``Roger & Me'' because she had been misinformed about the subject of the documentary-style movie. ``For the first 20 minutes of the movie,'' said Bogguss, ``I was trying to figure out how this had anything to do with Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert.'' ``Roger & Me'' is not about the two TV film critics, but the demise of a General Motors Corp. plant in Flint, Mich., and the Roger of the title refers to GM Chairman Roger Smith. A year ago, Bogguss was voted most promising female singer by the Academy of Country Music. Her hit records include ``I Don't Want to Set the World on Fire.''

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Immigrants' Dreams Shattered by Bronx Fire
DOC.TEXT: It was going to be different here. Here, in the United States, far from the poverty of their native Honduras, they would become part of the American Dream. In a strange and sometimes hostile city, they clung to their own kind _ especially when it came time to party. Often, they went to Happy Land, an illegal Bronx social club. There, a week ago, an arson fire consumed the dream and the lives of 87 people.

Pedro and Elida Alvarez decided in 1986 that life in Honduras no longer was tolerable. They would emigrate first to the United States, bringing their family with them as soon as they could. They traveled first to Los Angeles. ``But I didn't want to live there. I already had relatives here and I wanted to be near my family,'' Mrs. Alvarez said. They moved to New York, and by 1988, they had saved enough money to begin the process of reuniting their family. ``We all came here looking for a good job, to better ourselves, our future,'' Alvarez said. ``That's what we all thought. We'd come here and start a good life.'' Denny, who had dropped out of a teacher education program in Honduras, would come first. He would continue his studies here, Mrs. Alvarez hoped. But when he arrived in March 1988, Denny had other ideas. ``When he got here, he didn't want to study,'' Mrs. Alvarez said. ``I would tell him not to go out at night but he would go,'' Alvarez sadly remembered last week. ``As a son, he was a good son. But he would say he was young and he had his own life.'' Last October, something happened that horrified the Alvarez family. Denny got into a fight at Happy Land and was cut in the abdomen. Doctors stitched him up, and he spent three days in the hospital. In the aftermath of that incident, Denny's life became more tranquil. Three months ago, he married a Honduran woman he met here. He and Doralina were expecting a child in about three months. He recently quit his job at a filter company and went to work in a candy factory. On Saturday, he dropped by his parents' house and gave his mother a box of candy from his new job. He then drove his mother to a friend's house. From there, everyone thought Denny was headed for a private party in the Bronx. But instead, Denny went to Happy Land. ``He liked the ambience. It was there that he could be with his friends,'' said cousin Hector Martinez, who had stopped going to Happy Land. ``You see,'' said Martinez, ``Denny was always happy. He was very outgoing.''

They were the hope of the Gamoneda family. The two younger Gamoneda brothers, Marco and Lenny, were serious students, aware that education was the ticket to escape the poverty that had followed them from Honduras to the South Bronx. ``I don't just say this because they were my brothers, but these kids were perfect,'' an elder brother, Miguel, said as he prepared to fly with the bodies back to Honduras where they would be buried. ``They didn't smoke, they didn't drink. They never went out. And that night, they went just to see what it was like,'' Miguel said. The brothers had saved enough from their part-time jobs at a supermarket to buy a Nintendo computer game set. ``They'd stay up until 1 a.m. playing the Nintendo instead of going out. They would rather stay home,'' their older brother said. The boys' parents _ Francisco and Leticia _ came to the United States in 1983 and were able to bring their sons to New York two years later. ``The life here is clearly better and you live well,'' said Miguel, who works for the city of White Plains, just north of New York. Marco, 23, was attending Bronx Community College and Lenny, 17, went to Theodore Roosevelt High School. ``He was a shy student but he was very bright,'' said Arcadia Ruiz, one of Marco's instructors. Marco told her he wanted to be a automotive mechanic but later, as his studies progressed, he changed his mind, saying he would like to be an electrical engineer. ``Marco spoke English and he could also write it very well,'' Miguel said. ``He was going to be the first in the family to make it here.'' Lenny, meanwhile, had dreams of being a police officer, said Miguel. The brothers worked weekends at a neighborhood supermarket and usually got off work at about midnight. ``But that night, for some reason, they got off at about 8 p.m.,'' Miguel said. A friend called their home several times; party at Happy Land, the friend said. So they went.

For Marvin Doubleday, the American Dream soured very quickly. More than 1{ years ago, he decided the only way to better himself was to come to the United States. ``Mother was very sad. She didn't want him to come here,'' said brother Carlos Casco, 21. ``But Marvin knew he couldn't continue to live in Honduras. He couldn't get a job. He kept hearing that he could find work here, that there was a lot of money here. So he decided to come here.'' Doubleday, 22, was determined _ he would gain success before returning home to Honduras. He planned to work here a few years and save enough money to open a small store back home. ``He wanted to put enough money together and go back home and start a small business _ nothing big but something that was his,'' said a cousin, Ricardo Discua. ``People are dying of hunger back home, so you come here,'' said another cousin, Jorge Bautista, who has been here 12 years. Doubleday learned quickly that life here wasn't necessarily better. ``He didn't like all the drug dealers,'' Bautista said. ``He complained there were drug dealers everywhere. He also didn't like the city because of the crime, which keeps getting worse and worse.'' Moreover, Doubleday was not saving money. He earned about $200 a week pumping gas at a Bronx service station, and New York's high rents ate up his cash. He spoke almost no English, and his prospects were dim. A new plan emerged late last year _ his younger brother, Casco, would move here, doubling their earning power. When Casco and their mother came to visit, Doubleday's kid brother was surprised at how he lived. ``Don't misunderstand me. We lived in a very poor house back in our country. And he lived better than we did in Honduras but I thought he had a better life (in Honduras) ...,'' Casco said. ``It wasn't a bad apartment but I thought he lived better than he did.'' Still, the brothers decided they would ``both work real hard, earn enough money to put together a business and leave here by December. We would not stay beyond December.'' Their mother returned to Honduras in February and the brothers both worked at the Bronx gasoline station. They even found time to relax, going to Happy Land a couple of times in the past few weeks. Casco worked all day Saturday and didn't feel like going out. By the time he got home, Doubleday already had left. He and a friend called Casco, urging him to join them later at Happy Land. ``But I was very tired. I ate dinner and went to sleep,'' Casco said. The next morning Casco knew that their American dream had ended. ``And now, I will go back to my country and I will bury him,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Happy Land: A Week Later, Curious, Mourners Still Come to Site
With AM-Honduran Dreams, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The car slowed on the rain-slicked Bronx street as its occupants pointed and stared at the charred building that once housed the Happy Land Social Club. Others stopped off Friday night to add their contribution to a burgeoning memorial of flowers and funeral wreaths laid out on the sidewalk. Like a peculiar urban pilgrimage, the scene is repeated over and over as friends and neighbors, mourners and the merely curious come to see where 87 people died in last Sunday's fire at the illegal social club. Robert Robayo and his wife, Estella, somberly stood in the drizzle and stared blankly at charred coats that lay unclaimed behind the flowers. ``I can't believe they had so many people in there. It looks so small,'' Robayo said. ``They should never have had so many people in there.'' In the week since the disaster, the city has cracked down on illegal social clubs, beefing up enforcement by transferring more than 100 police officers from a special anti-drug squad. In raids Thursday night and Friday morning, police found 74 of 89 clubs they visited closed. They served 17 summonses and 36 notices for building and fire code infractions at 15 others. At least four illegal clubs in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan did not open this weekend because of the crackdown. The four clubs, said a source familiar with their operation who spoke on condition of anonymity, usually buy just enough liquor for the weekend but opted not to buy any liquor or to open this weekend. A woman stood outside what has become the city's best-known club, shaking her head as she recalled the numerous times she danced there. Safety never occurred to her. ``You're in there drinking. You're dancing. You're not thinking about that,'' said the woman, who would identify herself only as Celeste. ``But now, when I go to other clubs, I'm going to look and see if they have a rear exit.'' Were it not for the small group of firefighters and police officers assigned to protect the building, Happy Land might seem like just another charred building in the Bronx. The East Tremont section where the building sits is bleak, with littered, vacant lots next to deteriorated buildings. At the Virgin Islands American Bar on East Tremont, a block from Happy Land, several patrons said they had never previously heard of the club. ``I couldn't even tell if the place was open or not,'' said the bar's manager, who would identify herself only as Shirley. But a woman who visited the building insisted everyone in the area knew about Happy Land. ``How could you not know about it? It was like the only place you could go to around here and afford,'' said the woman, who would not give her name. ``Some are dropping off flowers. Others just stop and say a prayer,'' said Fire Marshal Larry Lynch of the steady stream of visitors. One onlooker asked if the neighborhood was returning to normal. ``Are you kidding? This place is never normal. This is the Bronx,'' answered a man who identified himself as Alberto. Alberto, who was walking around trying to sell two pairs of used trousers and slippers, stared across the street at the Happy Land building. ``Look, the drugs are still here. People are still scared to go out in the street. Some of these young kids are crazy and will stick you for nothing. No. Nothing's changed here. It's just gone from bad to worse.''

DOC.HEAD: Socialist Reformer Backs Out Of Run-Off Election
DOC.TEXT: Socialist reformer Imre Pozsgay has withdrawn from a run-off election after his defeat in first-round voting in his district, the state news agency MTI reported Saturday. But since Pozsgay won a seat in parliament through the regional list of his party in Bacs-Kiskun county, his pullout was mainly seen as a loss of prestige that may hurt his efforts to become president. In the Sopron district close to the Austrian border, Jozsef Szajer, a 28-year-old newcomer representing the League of Free Democrats, placed first with 29.1 percent of the votes, Laszlo Karpati of the Hungarian Democratic Forum got 19.85 percent and Pozsgay finished third with 17.97 percent. The March 25 balloting was Hungary's first free parliamentary elections in more than four decades under Communist rule. Pozsgay was a key reformer in the Socialist Party that emerged from the Communist Party last October.

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Voters to Decide Fate of Governor's `Vanna Vetoes'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Thompson's aides...' to CORRECT spelling of inadvertently.
DOC.TEXT: Voters decide this week whether to restrict Wisconsin's so-called ``Vanna White veto,'' which has allowed governors to rewrite legislation by striking letters, words, punctuation and numerals. Foes of the unlimited veto _ nicknamed for the letter-flipping hostess on the television game show ``Wheel of Fortune'' _ say it gives legislative power to the executive branch, violating the constitutional separation of powers. ``This dictatorial power is clearly repugnant to the American constitutional system,'' said Senate President Fred Risser. ``The intent of the Legislature can be altered or reversed with a flick of the pen.'' Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, a first-term Republican, defends his court-affirmed authority to selectively eliminate letters and is urging voters to retain it. ``I think the people like having a strong governor,'' Thompson said, adding he's the only person between the 132 lawmakers of a Democrat-controlled Legislature and their proposals for more spending and programs. Thompson's most famous ``Vanna veto'' was when he reworked a bill in 1988 that limited the time a juvenile could be held in detention to 48 hours. The governor boosted the limit to 10 days by crossing out ``48 hours'' and most of the bill's next four lines, leaving intact only the word ``day'' and four other strategically placed letters: ``t-e-n day-s.'' No attempt was made to override that veto, even though it drew strong objections from legislators. The governor said later he made a mistake in that case, at the request of a couple of Democratic legislators, and quipped: ``I followed the Democrats' advice and it got me in trouble.'' But he has stuck to the concept of creative vetoing. In another instance, Thompson used his pen to convert the Legislature's 1 percent reduction in welfare spending to 6 percent. Thompson's aides say he has corrected language that would not have withstood legal challenges and inserted needed language, such as definition of terms, that was omitted inadvertently by legislators. But the governor's record 290 partial vetoes in the 1987-89 state budget _ many of which changed appropriations bills by striking numbers and letters or merging words _ so angered Democrats that they sued Thompson. In 1988, they lost in the state Supreme Court, which cited the 1930 provision in the state constitution giving the governor the right to veto any appropriation bill ``in part.'' In its 4-3 ruling, the court interpreted ``in part'' to mean any part, including lines, paragraphs, numerals, letters and words. Their latest counterattack offers voters in Tuesday's spring election a constitutional amendment that would bar the governor from using his veto to strike letters and words to change the meaning of legislation. The governor could still strike numerals or entire sentences. In Wisconsin, a constitutional amendment must be passed by two consecutive sessions of the Legislature and then by voters in a statewide referendum. Rep. David Prosser, the GOP minority leader in the Assembly, tried unsuccessfully to sidetrack the amendment in the Legislature. He contends the governor needs the authority to correct legislative mistakes. Prosser claims the furor over the governor's use of the veto is overblown because the Legislature has the right to restore bills to their original form by overriding a veto with a two-thirds vote of both houses. Democrats control the Senate 19-14 and the Assembly 55-42, but often they cannot muster enough votes among Republicans to override Thompson. Still, no lawmaker has seriously suggested that the partial veto power be repealed, just tamed. The issue has created friction between the legislative and executive branches since the 1970s, when Gov. Patrick J. Lucey, a Democrat, cut a single digit from a $25 million appropriation, reducing it to $5 million. His successors gradually expanded the partial veto authority. Acting Gov. Martin J. Schreiber, a Democrat, reversed the intent of the Legislature on a $1 contribution by taxpayers for a campaign fund to simply checking off $1 of their taxes for the refund. Another Democrat, Gov. Anthony S. Earl, started the selective elimination of letters and digits from appropriations bills.

DOC.HEAD: Man Dies After Fulfilling Lifelong Dream of Seeing Niagara Falls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to restore man's hometown.
DOC.TEXT: A man who persuaded co-workers to take a side trip to Niagara Falls because it was his lifelong wish to visit here collapsed and died after fulfilling his dream, authorities said. Eugene Gergler, 68, of Cincinnati collapsed Friday night in the parking lot on Goat Island, between the American and Horseshoe Falls, and was pronounced dead at a hospital a short time later, said state park police Officer Patrick Moriarty. Gergler and three other electricians had been working in Erie, Pa., earlier Friday when he told them his lifelong dream was to see the falls, Moriarty said. So the four drove 120 miles to Niagara Falls. He said Gergler complained of feeling ill while taking pictures of the falls and went back to the group's truck, where his companions found him unconscious.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution: Poindexter Lied to Reagan, FBI Too
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors in the criminal trial of John Poindexter tried to make it appear the former national security adviser was immersed in a pattern of deception that kept even his own boss, Ronald Reagan, in the dark. But defense attorneys suggested that Poindexter himself was uninformed about onetime White House aide Oliver North's activities on behalf of the Contras and the sale of arms to Iran. They questioned the accuracy of an FBI agent's testimony and elicited testimony from witnesses who swore there was never any discussion of covering up. Poindexter, who didn't testify, is on trial in U.S. District Court in Washington on charges that he lied to members of Congress about his involvement in selling arms to Iran and funneling proceeds to help Nicaraguan rebels when Congress had banned such aid. The arms sales supposedly were intended to make it possible to release American hostages held in the Middle East, even though the official policy was not to negotiate with terrorists. District Judge Harold Greene was scheduled to instruct the jury Monday, after which deliberations will begin. During the trial, which began March 5, prosecutors contended Poindexter withheld the truth from Reagan about the diversion of arms sale money to the Contras. According to a defense witness who took notes at a meeting on Oct. 7, 1986, between Poindexter and Reagan, Poindexter told the president there was no U.S. government connection to a downed aircraft in Nicaragua. The plane, shot down two days before, carried crewman Eugene Hasenfus, who was part of North's resupply effort to the Contra rebels fighting the Nicaraguan government. Poindexter's lawyers brought up the meeting as part of the effort to show that North ran the operation without the knowledge of his immediate boss, Poindexter. But prosecutor Dan K. Webb suggested Poindexter knew Hasenfus was a pilot with the supply effort just as Poindexter was fully informed of the previous arms-for-hostages effort. North has already been convicted for his role in the affair. Poindexter is accused only of falsely telling Congress on Nov. 21, 1986, that he hadn't known until January of that year that U.S. Hawk missiles were airlifted to Iran late in the previous year. Prosecutors presented evidence of Poindexter's involvement in the November 1985 missile shipment, including: _Computer messages from North discussing the impending delivery of the Hawks. Poindexter's lawyers point out there is no evidence that he read the messages. _CIA employee Norman Gardner's statements to the FBI in 1987 that CIA cable traffic showed the operation was being directed on instructions from Poindexter. At Poindexter's trial, Gardner said he didn't recall telling that to the FBI. On Nov. 28, 1986, Poindexter had told the FBI ``he had no working knowledge'' of 1985 arms shipments to Iran, an FBI agent testified. Poindexter's lawyers countered by pointing out that the FBI agent had taken no notes during the 15-minute interview. She wrote down notes on her way back to the office. _Poindexter contacted the Pentagon to line up replacement Hawks for the ones Israel was preparing to send Iran on behalf of the United States. _Poindexter received a Nov. 26, 1985, note from CIA Director Casey telling him to keep an attached draft of a presidential document secret. The presidential document allowed the CIA to help with the missile shipment the day before. Such a document, known as a ``finding'' was signed by the president the next month. In a speech late the next year, Nov. 13, 1986, Reagan said the United States had not sold arms to win release of the hostages. On Nov. 21, 1986, Poindexter told Congress that he hadn't known until the previous day that some U.S. officials might have known before the delivery that Hawks were aboard an aircraft. Casey told Congress the same day he understood CIA officers didn't know Hawk missiles were aboard the aircraft ``until the Iranians told them some time in January'' 1986. The airplane's crew, Casey testified, had been told the cargo was spare parts for the oil drilling fields in Tehran. Hours after briefing Congress, Poindexter tore up the politically embarrassing presidential document. CIA aide Gardner said he sat in on Poindexter's briefings of congressmen after ``Casey told me to go to the White House.'' After Casey finished testifying before the Senate intelligence committee, Gardner reported Casey's testimony back to Poindexter at the White House. Was Gardner there ``to make sure Admiral Poindexter and Casey were saying the same things to Congress?'' inquired Iran-Contra prosecutor Christian Mixter. No, replied Gardner, who stiffly denied Casey and Poindexter were feeding Congress a cover story. ``Did you tell Admiral Poindexter that the cover story wasn't holding up very well?'' asked Mixter. ``No, I didn't,'' replied Gardner. Poindexter's defense is that at the time he briefed Congress, he had only a vague recollection of the year-earlier shipment to Iran. Poindexter offered to gather details and get back to the congressmen, his lawyers emphasized in questioning witnesses who attended the meetings.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Republicans have a hard time winning anything in Hawaii, even a cockroach race. Undaunted by two previous defeats, President Bush is hoping a kinder, gentler cockroach will reverse his fortunes in the Iolani School's annual roach race. The White House has lost in the past with entries named the ``Yellow Roach of Texas'' and ``Oval Office Roach,'' but Bush has high hopes for a bug named ``Kinder Gentleroach.'' Bush figures if the slogan was good enough to beat Michael Dukakis, it should be good enough to win the April 20 race. ``I know a lot of thoroughbred roach lovers were disappointed that Oval Office Roach did so badly back in 1988, but lots has happened since then,'' Bush wrote in a letter to roach race founder Kimo McVay. Bush challenged the other competitors to submit their roaches to tests for illegal chemicals, saying he would submit his roach ``to an anti-steroid test, saliva test, etc., and I challenge all other roach owners to do the same.'' The president also joked about the entry of race commissioner William Conrad, of TV's ``Jake and the Fatman'' fame, saying Conrad's roach would not win because it's overweight. Money from the event goes to help fight multiple sclerosis, a disease of the central nervous system that afflicts an estimated 250,000 Americans.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians, Estonians on Different Routes to Independence
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Flexing its military muscle, the Kremlin blusters at Lithuania's leaders for boldly declaring independence. Yet it hardly uttered a critical word when Estonia issued a cautious statement of similar intent. The two republics, forcibly annexed by Moscow in 1940 with the third Baltic state of Latvia, are treading very different paths in their quest for secession. Lithuanians demand recognition now and want to work out the details later. Estonians want to know exactly what they're getting into. Watching and waiting are Latvia, Georgia, Moldavia and other Soviet republics where yearnings to leave the Soviet Union are also strong. On Friday, when Soviet soldiers were seizing the Lithuanian prosecutor's office in an effort to impose Moscow's man, Estonia's legislature was declaring the Soviets occupiers and setting off on the road to restored sovereignty. The reaction of Moscow has been as different as the tactical divergence in the Baltic independence movement that surfaced in 1988. Soviet military officials accuse Lithuania's leaders of plotting to jail opponents of secession and of encouraging Lithuanians to desert the Red Army. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has accused them of pursuing a ``ruinous'' road. In contrast, the Soviet Communist Party daily Pravda on Saturday noted that ``even Estonian radicals say: first negotiations and then a political decision.'' The three Baltic states snatched independence from the ruins of the Russian Empire at the end of World War I, were forcibly absorbed back into the Soviet Union in 1940 and spent most of World War II under Nazi occupation. Thousands of Baltic people were then exiled to Siberia or killed by Stalin as alleged Nazi collaborators or enemies of Soviet power. Armed resistance to Soviet rule lasted well into the 1950s in Lithuanian forests. Latvia is moving more slowly than its neighbors because its population is only about half ethnic Latvian, but Lithuanian and Estonian leaders say they hope it also will make a first formal move toward independence. Despite tactical differences, activists from the three republics cooperate closely.
