Lithuania's premier, Kazimiera Prunskiene, called Estonia's move Friday a ``show of support'' for her republic but said she did not know whether it would help or hurt. President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania said: ``Estonia has chosen a different legal formula and a different path toward its independence, but the essence is the same.'' The March 11 declaration of independence by Lithuania's Parliament was a hasty move aimed at pre-empting Gorbachev from using newly expanded presidential powers to dissolve their Parliament or impose direct Kremlin rule. But immediately after the declaration, nothing really changed. Lithuanians still used Soviet money and still were working in factories tied by contract and supply to the Soviet economy. The legislature elected last month then began removing the trappings of Soviet rule, named Cabinet ministers and began developing its own body of laws. Moscow cracked down. Soviet troops raided hospitals to seize Lithuanians who, asserting their claim to be foreign citizens, deserted the Red Army. Kremlin forces also took over several Communist Party buildings. After failing Friday to get employees of the prosecutor's office in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius to accept a new chief appointed by Moscow, Soviet officials sent soldiers to occupy the office. Efforts to disarm the population and halt a Lithuanian campaign to sign up volunteers for duty as borders guards were less effective. It is just those kinds of disputes the Estonians say they want to avoid. In its declaration Friday, the Estonian Parliament said full independence would be established only after Estonia creates its own institutions and works out how to divide property between the republic and the Soviet Union. The length of the transition period is to be set this week. Compared with Lithuania's rush for political high ground, Estonia seems unconcerned about the possibility of Gorbachev slamming the door before it can escape the Soviet Union. The republic's leaders say there is no point in declaring independence because Estonia has been independent _ though occupied _ all along. Official Soviet communications about Estonia's future seem to carry an air of resignation. Tass, the official Soviet news agency, said the ``broad aspiration to restore Estonian statehood is in evidence'' and that political parties that want to pursue it appear to have the upper hand. Ethnic Lithuanians comprise about 80 percent of their republic's 3.8 million people. By contrast, ethnic Estonians make up just 60 percent of their republic's 1.6 million people and must thus move more cautiously. They lack the two-thirds majority needed for independence if it were put to a referendum. The population split also has given non-Estonians a greater share of the Supreme Soviet's 105 seats. But as Friday's 75-0 vote showed, they do not have enough to stop the legislature from moving toward independence. Pravda's commentary Saturday praised Estonian Communist Party leader Vaino Vyalyas, an old chum of Gorbachev's from the Komsomol Communist Youth League, for keeping Estonia under control. Vyalyas, it said, is a ``man with great political experience, a professional diplomat, who is familiar with the fine art of compromise, thanks to which in the last year and a half the republic has managed to smooth over many difficult problems.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Mark J. Porubcansky has covered the Soviet Union and Gorbachev's reform efforts for more than three years, traveling extensively throughout the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Man Wins Suit Against Track; Jammed Machine Doesn't Mean There Was No Bet
DOC.TEXT: Robert Palmisciano bet $2 at a greyhound track and won $39,319, but had to wait more than five years for the payoff. A state Superior Court jury ruled in his favor Friday in a lawsuit against Lincoln Greyhound Park. Palmisciano placed his bet on a twin trifecta, meaning he had to pick the win, place and show dogs in two races, at a meet on Dec. 10, 1984. After getting the 9th race right, he went to a teller to choose three more dogs for the 11th race. But after making his selection, he changed his mind and told the teller he wanted to bet on three other dogs. The teller started to give him another ticket, but the machine jammed. Before a maintenance man could fix it, the 11th race had started. The dogs again came in as Palmisciano predicted, but the racetrack refused to pay him a $39,319 jackpot because he didn't have a ticket. Palmisciano claimed Autotote Limited, which operates the tote machines at the track, was negligent for failing to have additional service personnel while the race program was under way. He also claimed that track officials did not comply with its obligation under an implied betting contract between him and Lincoln Greyhound Park. His attorney, John D. Archetto, said the jury award plus interest is expected to exceed $60,000.

DOC.HEAD: Germans Visit Mass Grave Near Former Soviet Camp
DOC.TEXT: Walter Weigel has no plans to visit the mass grave on the edge of town that has drawn the eerie fascination of so many of his neighbors. ``I am certain I knew some of the people buried there,'' said the native of Oranienburg, 20 miles north of Berlin. Weigel, 62, spent four years after World War II in a nearby Soviet-run internment camp. He said he believes the camp supplied the hundreds of bodies packed together in the nearby forest. ``There were youngsters in the camp here, not just soldiers. I was 17, a worker, not a soldier,'' he said Saturday. ``They gave us only bread to eat. Two hundred and fifty men in one barracks.'' Weigel said many of his fellow inmates were taken from the camp and never returned. ``We knew what happened to them,'' he said, staring down the road that leads to the forest. A steady stream of visitors filtered through the forest on the outskirts of town on Saturday, standing in the clearing and staring at the dozens of holes dug by authorities, then refilled with loose dirt. ``My parents told me this had happened. But nobody really talked about it. Now we can see it,'' said Luther Walz, an Oranienburg resident who trekked into the forest with his wife and son. Last week officials began digging in the woods after a resident said that as a young boy he watched Soviet troops gun down hundreds of German prisoners soon after the end of the war. The skeletal remains of between 200 and 1,000 people were unearthed during the excavations. Oranienburg authorities said they could not identify the dead, but presumed they were German inmates of the camp that they said was run by Stalin's fearsome secret police. West German officials have said about 70,000 Germans were executed by Stalin's occupation troops in the years following the war. Many of the Soviet internment camps were former Nazi death camps. The discovery of the remains has triggered considerable interest in both West Germany and East Germany, but little attention in other parts of the world, where the deaths of 6 million Jews at the hands of the Nazis dwarfs all other atrocities of the war. In this village, however, the grave site has provoked fascination. The 300-yard gravesite is blocked-off by a thin white rope draped with small red-and-white flags. ``Mass grave of unknown victims. Entry forbidden,'' says the widely ignored sign at the end of the clearing. Nearby, a new wooden cross with the name ``Adolf Lopoehn'' had been stuck in the ground. It identified Lopoehn as a singer from the nearby town of Sachsenhausen. ``There were children there,'' said Gertrude Erdmann, 76. ``They are Nazis,'' said an elderly man who refused to give his name.

DOC.HEAD: All Three Northwest Crewmen Drop Requests For Speedy Hearings on License Loss
DOC.TEXT: All three Northwest Airlines cockpit crew members whose licenses were revoked for allegedly flying under the influence of alcohol have dropped requests for expedited hearings to contest the revocations. The National Transportation Safety Board on Friday canceled hearings set to begin Tuesday in St. Paul on the March 8 Northwest flight from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis in which the three men were involved. The NTSB received letters from attorneys for copilot Robert Kirchner of Highland Ranch, Colo., and flight engineer Joseph Balzer of Antioch, Tenn., saying they waived rights to expedited hearings. The letters asked that the cases go to the board's non-emergency calendar, which means that the appeals will be heard within the year. A few days earlier, Capt. Norman Prouse of Conyers, Ga., waived his right to an expedited hearing. The Federal Aviation Administration revoked the licenses March 9 after the three were accused of flying a Northwest jet carrying 91 passengers while intoxicated. The three appealed. The crew members, who have been fired by Northwest, were charged last week by federal authorities with flying under the influence of alcohol. The case is to go before a grand jury. Mark McDermott, an attorney for Kirchner, said Friday that he wants to focus on the felony case. ``The criminal charges are quite serious and carry serious penalties,'' he said. ``The pilot's license cases have to take a back seat, temporarily.'' According to an FBI affidavit, Kirchner and Balzer shared about seven pitchers of beer at a bar in Moorhead the night before their flight, while Prouse allegedly had about 19 mixed drinks. Attorneys for Kirchner and Balzer have denied that their clients were drunk or impaired during the flight.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Urges Lithuania to Scrap Declaration of Independence
LaserPhotos MOSB1,2,3,5; LaserColor MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told Lithuanians on Saturday that Moscow would not negotiate with them until they annul their declaration of independence, warning of ``grave consequences'' if they refuse. In Vilnius, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis dismissed the appeal, telling reporters the Soviet leader was ``demanding impossible things.'' In a toughly worded, 18-line statement issued in Moscow and addressed to the republic's Parliament, Gorbachev charged Lithuanian leaders with ``openly challenging and insulting'' the Soviet Union. Gorbachev said Lithuania had chosen a ``ruinous'' path that ``will only lead to a dead end.'' It was his first formal statement on the issue since March 11, when the Baltic state's Parliament sparked open confrontation with the Kremlin by voting to secede from the Soviet Union. Gorbachev said he was proposing that Lithuania's Parliament ``immediately annul the illegal acts it has adopted. Such a step will open the possibility for discussing the entire range of problems on the solely acceptable basis: within the framework of the U.S.S.R. Constitution.'' In a separate three-page statement, also carried by the official Tass news agency and read by an announcer on national television news Saturday night, Gorbachev addressed the people of Lithuania directly. He warned that ``irresponsible and illegal actions'' by Lithuanian leaders could affect the republic's economic, scientific, technical and other links with Soviet republics, which supply the Baltic state with much of its oil, gas and other essential products. In Vilnius, uniformed men were reported patrolling the printing plant for republic's main newspapers and the chief prosecutor's office. Both buildings were seized during the night in Moscow's latest move to assert control. The Lithuanians have not budged and Landsbergis said they would press on with their independence drive: ``We have no sources for stopping this. We can work, live normally and wait. We must be tough and have tenacity. We have this in our character.'' In an attempt to pressure Lithuania to back down, Soviet troops have occupied Communist Party buildings, paraded tanks through the streets, demanded that residents hand over firearms and arrested Lithuanian deserters from the Red Army. Gorbachev said the Kremlin was receiving many letters and telegrams from citizens demanding that the Soviet government uphold the constitution in its showdown with Lithuania. ``The situation in the republic and around it has become dramatic. If you would not hear the voice of the reason now, the developments may have grave consequences for all of us. We must be united in our desire to prevent that.'' Lithuania's deputy premier Romualdas Ozolas said Gorbachev's appeal was ``strong. It's a step we must overcome.'' He suggested Lithuanians write to the Kremlin to express their desire for independence. Gorbachev acted after his newly created Cabinet directed him Friday to tell Lithuania that it must rescind unconstitutional laws before any talks on secession could begin. The constitution stipulates a republic's right to secede but offers no mechanism for secession. Gorbachev has promised Lithuania and other independence-minded republics that such a mechanism will be established, but the measure currently before the Soviet legislature gives the Kremlin final authority on such questions. On Friday, nearby Estonia pledged to join Lithuania in its drive to regain independence lost when the Soviet Union forcibly annexed them with Latvia, the third Baltic republic. Latvia is expected to pursue independence next month. In Moscow earlier Saturday, about 700 people rallied in Gorky Park in support of Lithuania, carrying signs that read: ``Hands off Lithuania,'' and ``Down with Red Fascism.'' Official Soviet sources estimate about 250 Lithuanians have deserted the Red Army since the republic declared independence, but Lithuanians say as many as 900 have left their units. The Soviet military's deputy commander in Lithuania, N. Rogachev, told Tass Saturday that Lithuanian deserters were beginning to trickle back to barracks. The military rounded up at least 23 deserters on Tuesday, beating some bloody, and promised to seek out others who do not turn themselves in. ``Sooner or later the law will be put into force,'' Rogachev warned. ``And the consequences for the fates of the young people may be most tragic.'' The Defense Ministry had said it would not punish Lithuanian deserters if they voluntarily returned. But Chief Military Prosecutor Alexander Katusev said in a later interview on Soviet TV that criminal proceedings had been started against all deserters and added that people encouraging desertions also would be prosecuted. Vilius Kavalauskas, a journalist for the Lithuanian newspaper Tiesa, said 30 soldiers were patrolling the prosecutor's office and another 15 armed with nightsticks were at the central newspaper printing plant. Lithuanian journalists said soldiers had not tried to interfere with printing of weekend papers. The prosecutor's office was seized Friday after staff members refused to work with a Moscow loyalist named by the Kremlin. A duty officer at the Lithuanian Interior Ministry said soldiers also had occupied another Communist Party building, the Institute of Party History. Communist Party Buildings already under military control include the Institute of Marxism-Leninism, the Higher Party School and Communist Party headquarters. Soviet authorities have said the troop actions were legitimate attempts to enforce law and order in a Soviet republic that has no right to unilaterally declare independence.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Willing To Let Bygones Be Bygones on Past Drug Use, Officials Say
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf pvs, bgng: One Banking, to UPDATE with Riegle comment
DOC.TEXT: Nomination of a onetime drug user as the nation's top savings and loan regulator demonstrates President Bush's unwillingness to adopt past drug usage as a litmus test for officials in his administration, officials said Saturday. ``These matters are always considered on a case by case basis,'' one White House official said Saturday when asked about nominee T. Timothy Ryan's admission that he had used cocaine and marijuana on occasion in the early 1970s. The president himself has said past indiscretions with drugs should not disqualify someone from government service. ``In my view, (if) somebody used marijuana sometime ago and is not into anything of that nature, why, no, I don't think that should be held against them,'' he said when asked in mid-March about campaign reports regarding Texas State Treasurer Ann Richards' refusal to say whether she had ever used illegal narcotics. The gubernatorial candidate has admitted to being a recovering alcoholic. Ryan, Bush's embattled nominee to be director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, won narrow endorsement Friday from the Senate Banking Committee despite the disclosure of drug use. The committee members had access to FBI background reports in which Ryan admitted the drug use, but the matter was never raised during the committee's hearings despite considerable opposition to his appointment. One Banking Committee member, Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla., knew about the drug use on the part of Ryan prior to the vote, said aide Ken Klein. But Klein said Graham's ``primary interest was qualifications,'' indicating that the senator didn't think Ryan had the necessary experience. Committee Chairman Donald Riegle, D-Mich., who also opposed Ryan, released a statement saying ``FBI files should be treated with the strictest confidentiality. I will not comment on any nominee's file. I consider any disclosures from such files to be highly improper.'' The drug information was disclosed in an NBC-TV report Friday night, and later confirmed by administration officials. Officials expressed support for Ryan after the disclosure, stressing the administration had known the information all along. ``We knew about it before hand. We felt it was not relevant. We felt he was the best candidate,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Saturday. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady emphasized in a statement Friday that Ryan had volunteered the information. ``The incidents were limited and a long time ago,'' Brady said. ``We believe Mr. Ryan is well qualified and his nomination deserves the Senate's full support.'' If confirmed by the Senate, the 44-year-old Ryan would not be alone as a former drug user in the Bush administration, said officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. One said it would be safe to say ``there are hundreds of officials throughout the administration who have admitted'' to drug use in their security clearance process. Another senior official said ``it would be impossible to conceive'' there are not numerous individuals who, like Ryan, experimented with drugs in the 1970s when many considered marijuana use and even cocaine more benign than in today's anti-drug climate. ``Everybody's off that stuff now,'' said a third official. ``But broadly speaking, everybody used the stuff in the 70s.'' The Bush administration is aware of that usage because ``nobody wants to lie to the FBI,'' the source added. The seriousness of the drug use, the type of drugs used and how long ago it occurred are factors to be considered when looking at how much to weigh past drug abuse against a potential nominee's record, officials said. Even some diehard conservatives in Washington political circles do not see drug use as a flat disqualifier for public office. Gary Bauer, who served as domestic policy adviser under President Reagan and now heads the conservative Family Research Council, said Saturday that ``there's a statute of limitations on every indiscretion. As serious as drug use is, I'd being willing to concede that 20 years is a good statute of limitations.'' However, he said Ryan, as a condition of his confirmation, should pledge to devote a specific number of hours a week ``to talk to young people about the foolishness of what he did and how it almost ruined his life.'' To do otherwise would send a message of hypocrisy to children, Bauer said. ``We are spending billions of dollars on this problem. We shouldn't be telling our kids `don't,' and then appointing officials to high government positions,'' unless they take on the anti-drug education task he suggests, Bauer said. In 1987, during the Reagan administration, Douglas Ginsburg withdrew as a nominee to the Supreme Court after admitting he had smoked marijuana while a law professor. William Bennett, then the education secretary and now Bush's drug policy director, helped persuade Ginsburg to withdraw. But politicians appear more willing to count on public understanding of their past drug use _ at least in cases that did not amount to a prolonged period of serious abuse. During the early days prior to the 1988 presidential campaign, Democratic contenders Bruce Babbitt, the former Arizona governor, and Sen. Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee, both admitted they had smoked marijuana while in college. Bush said he had never tried illegal drugs himself, but added at that time, ``but I'd hate to speak for my kids.'' Bush's five children range in age from 30 to 43.

DOC.HEAD: Andrus Sees Veto As Right Decision For Idaho
LaserPhoto BD2
DOC.TEXT: Abortion foes quickly targeted Democratic Gov. Cecil Andrus for defeat in his try for an unprecedented fourth term, saying he betrayed his own beliefs by vetoing what would have been the nation's most restrictive state abortion law. ``This veto will galvanize the pro-life majority in Idaho and nationwide,'' said National Right to Life President John Willke, maintaining Andrus has forfeited any claim to an anti-abortion stand. ``We will be heard at the polls,'' vowed Kerry Uhlenkott of Idaho Right to Life. ``This has been a long, hard fight, and it is by no means over.'' Andrus, acknowledging the political cost of his veto, said he acted in the best interests of his state. He denied being influenced by political considerations and threats of economic retaliation from outsiders. Instead, Andrus said, he rejected a bill that many legal experts said had little chance of being upheld. ``I know that of course there will be some fallout, but so be it,'' Andrus said. ``I can't do anything about that. I have to do what I think is right.'' While incurring the wrath of anti-abortion activists, Andrus did win over pro-choice forces who pledged to support him despite his belief that abortion should be allowed only in cases of rape, incest and to save the women's life. One of the main architects of the vetoed bill, Rep. Gary Montgomery, conceded the legislation ``could have been improved and strengthened.'' He and other abortion foes promised to refine and reintroduce the bill in 1991. The defeated version, based on a National Right to Life Committee model rejected as too restrictive by other states, called for outlawing abortion except in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is under 18, severe fetal deformity or a threat to the life or physical health of the woman. The Legislature adjourned its 1990 session a half hour before the governor's announcement on Friday, precluding the possibility of even considering an override of the veto. ``This is a time for reflection, to solicit the views of our constituents over the interim period,'' Montgomery said. Idaho was the fifth state this year to reject a form of the national model anti-abortion forces want to use to test the U.S. Supreme Court's commitment to legalized abortion. Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion Rights Action League, called the Andrus veto an ``outstanding victory.'' ``But we face the reality that for every Cecil Andrus, there stands a Bob Casey and a Joseph Ada ready to take away the right of women to choose so our work is not done,'' Michelman said. She referred to the Pennsylvania and Guam governors who signed restrictive abortion legislation. ``It only takes one piece of anti-choice legislation to be passed in one state somewhere in this country to threaten all women's rights,'' she said. ``Until we have pro-choice governors, pro-choice legislatures, a pro-choice Congress, a pro-choice president in washington, our job is not done.'' With some politicians believing the veto has complicated what would have been easy re-election, the three Republicans competing for the right to challenge Andrus this fall immediately accused the governor of waffling on abortion. Boise stockbroker Milton Erhart, the lone GOP contender on the pro-choice side, pointed out that 17 years ago Andrus was the governor who signed the so-called ``trigger law'' banning abortion except to save the woman's life and to imprison both women and doctors involved in illegal abortions if the Supreme Court reversed its 1973 decision. The Legislature repealed that law this year. ``Andrus has again demonstrated his expert finger-in-the-wind approach to politics,'' Erhart said. Former state Sen. Roger Fairchild said Andrus should win an Olympic gold medal in the flip-flop, and state Sen. Rachel Gilbert, considered the front-runner for the nomination, said Andrus ``went south on his principles.'' Andrus, insisting he remains opposed to abortion, maintained the majority of Idahoans would agree with his decision. ``Every political career has to come to an end sometime,'' he said. ``I'd hate for that to be the issue. But if it is, so be it.''

DOC.HEAD: Indiana Deals With Patchwork of Time Zones
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Seventy-six of...', to CORRECT that reference is to Union City, Ind., sted Ohio.
DOC.TEXT: In Indiana, where time zones can divide a town, many people keep two reckonings of the hour to cope with living in a ``time warp.'' Hoosiers say the state's three time zones wreak havoc on business and family life. At no time does the entire state follow the same clock, creating timekeeping headaches from urban centers to country hamlets. People live in one zone and work in another, children cross time lines to and from school, prime time programming for televison is complicated and meetings can be disrupted by delays, latecomers and no-shows. One of three states exempted from the national time change _ the others are Hawaii and Arizona _ Indiana is the only one with fragmented zones. A large portion is permanently on Eastern Standard Time, while the rest observes either Central time or Eastern time and changes twice a year like the other 47 states. ``Indiana has the most complex time observance of any place in the United States,'' said Joanne Petrie, an attorney for the U.S. Department of Transportation, the agency in charge of setting time zones. Mayor John Ford of Union City, which is divided down the middle by the Indiana-Ohio line, calls Sunday's change to daylight-saving time a ``time warp.'' He said most residents of the portion of Union City in Indiana will experience the anxiety of being an hour late for something as those on the Ohio side of the line spring ahead. ``But they'll make it up by being an hour early for something else,'' he said. ``The majority of people live the way it suits them, and in a lot of places that involves keeping two different times in the same househould,'' he said. Seventy-six of Indiana's 92 counties _ including Randolph County, in which Union City, Ind., is located _ remain on Eastern Standard Time as everyone else resets their clocks on Sunday. Eleven other counties observe Central time and, on schedule, switch from CST to CDT as of Sunday _ meaning that for the next five months, their clocks will look just like the EST counties' clocks. Five other counties that are close to Louisville or Cincinnati traditionally observe Eastern time to remain in step with those cities, switching as of Sunday to EDT. Indiana's time zones are a compromise following years of local and national debate. Officials say it's probably the best that can be expected, though far from perfect. Prior to 1961, the Indiana-Ohio line also divided the Central and Eastern time zones. The line was later shifted to bisect the state and then re-shifted to create current time boundaries. ``There's some sort of truce right now,'' said Chuck Coffee, a speechwriter for Lt. Gov. Frank O'Bannon. ``It was much different when the population was dependent on rail service and waited as trains came to town,'' he said. Indiana balks at joining with the rest of the Eastern time zone in observing daylight saving time, officials say, because it lies on the western edge of the zone and already has a relatively late sunrise. Daylight saving time would exacerbate that, much to the displeasure of farmers who relish the early daylight hours for field work. Simply going on Central time is opposed by many others who feel Indiana is more attuned to New York and eastern cities and changing would put it out of step the entire year. ``Why would someone think that they are traveling within the same state and the time's going to change?'' said Carolyn McClintock, Vanderburgh County commissioner.

DOC.HEAD: Children's Author Dead at 86
DOC.TEXT: Helen Hoke Watts, the author and publisher of children's books, has died at the age of 86. Mrs. Watts died of pneumonia at a nursing home near her residence in the Washington suburb of Chevy Chase, Md. Her works included ``The Horse That Took the Milk Around'' and ``Too Many Kittens,'' and the series ``Witches, Witches, Witches,'' ``Jokes, Jokes, Jokes'' and ``Nurses, Nurses, Nurses.'' She wrote a number of anthologies reflecting her interest in ghost stories, the supernatural and witchcraft. Born in California, Pa., Mrs. Watts worked as a journalist and teacher before moving to the state of California in 1929. In 1936, she moved to New York. In addition to writing, she managed children's books departments for New York publishers. She served as vice president and director of international projects for Franklin Watts Inc. publishers, a company formed by her second husband. She later lived in London and again in New York before moving to the Washington areas. Mrs. Watts, who died Monday, is survived by a son, John Hoke, of Bethesda, Md., four grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: NOW Head Praises Idaho Abortion Veto, Unsure If Potato Threat Had Effect
With AM-Idaho Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The head of the National Organization for Women on Saturday praised Idaho Gov. Cecil Andrus' veto of a restrictive abortion bill, but said she didn't know what influence a threatened boycott of Idaho potatoes had on him. ``How much effect the threat of a boycott had, I haven't the vaguest idea, but he certainly did, in my opinion, the right thing,'' NOW President Molly Yard told reporters. Ms. Yard, attending NOW's Northeast regional conference, said pleas from teen-agers, letters and telegrams from pro-choice forces and calls from other governors opposed to the Idaho legislation probably helped influence Andrus. ``I think that Gov. Andrus thought very, very carefully about what he was doing, and I think there are many reasons that went into his decision, which was obviously done with care,'' Ms. Yard said. ``He clearly did talk to the medical profession and the legal profession. He was advised by the latter that the bill was unconstitutional, and he was advised by the former that women would virtually be banned from having abortions,'' she said. ``I think that troubled him.'' Ms. Yard rejected the suggestion that NOW's threatened boycott would have been unfair to Idaho potato growers who had nothing to do with the abortion bill. Nine of the Idaho lawmakers who voted on the bill were potato growers, she said. ``The onus is on them,'' Ms. Yard said. ``They brought it on themselves.'' Ms. Yard went to the weekend conference prepared to make a pitch for Maine potatoes, but Andrus announced his veto Friday night of what would have become the most restrictive abortion law in the United States had he signed it. ``I listened to his statement last night,'' Ms. Yard said. ``It is the first time I've ever heard a man say exactly what I feel about expecting any woman to carry her pregnancy to term if she's been raped or she's pregnant because of incest, and he said it eloquently. ``I'm sure lots of men feel that way. It's the first time I've ever heard a man say it out loud.'' Despite Friday's victory for pro-choice groups, Ms. Yard said activists still face tough fights over abortion rights in Florida, Illinois amd other states.

DOC.HEAD: Group Claims Attack on Polish Diplomat
DOC.TEXT: A previously unknown group claimed responsibility Saturday for the shooting of a Polish diplomat and his wife, warning Poland not to help Soviet Jews travel to Israel. The shootings Friday night came less than a week after Poland offered to help Soviet Jews emigrate to Israel. Palestinian extremists have threatened attacks against countries that assist in the migration. The claim of responsibility came in a handwritten Arabic statement from ``the Revolutionary Action Organization, the Arab Resistance Front-The Martyr Suleiman al-Halabi unit'' published by the leftist Beirut newspaper As-Safir. ``Our group is behind the Polish diplomats operation. We warn the Polish government against providing any assistance in transporting Soviet Jews to our sacred land in Palestine,'' the statement said. The Pole, his country's commercial attache, and his Lebanese wife were wounded by assailants with automatic rifles who fired at them as they were parking their embassy car near the Bristol Hotel in Moslem west Beirut. They were rushed to the American University Hospital, where doctors said they were off the critical list. The Polish official was first identified by police as Bugdan Zbigniew, 47, and his wife as Eva Sarkis. The hospital said he was registered as Bogdan Sarkis. The official Polish news agency PAP identified the couple as Bogdan and Eva Sarka. A man who answered the phone in the wounded official's hospital room and identified himself only as a friend, refused to give the Pole's last name saying he was ``in danger.'' He said the name Zbigniew was not correct. A hospital medical bulletin said the Pole had a bullet wound in the chest and his wife suffered minor wounds in the left arm. The Polish government condemned the attack and said it was taking increased measures to protect diplomats and other overseas employees. In a dispatch from Warsaw, PAP said the Foreign Ministry ``strongly condemns this terrorist act. ... Poland will undertake all efforts to counteract terrorism abroad.'' Poland's prime minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, offered transport to Israel-bound Soviet Jews after Hungary's Malev airline stopped charters and some scheduled flights to Israel because of threats from Palestinian extremists. Malev later resumed scheduled flights but said it would not reinstate the charters. The airline also discontinued its flights to Beirut on Tuesday. Its officials had said Malev received a bomb threat from the Lebanon-based Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. Many Arabs fear the influx of Soviet Jews in Israel and the occupied territories will displace Palestinians and strengthen Israel's grip on the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Poland's Foreign Ministry had said it was aware that a decision to transport Soviet Jews to Israel in Polish airliners might have adverse effects for Poland. The Polish newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza reported this week the ministry feared attacks on the 10,000 Poles employed in Arab countries.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Panel Recommends AZT for Children With AIDS
DOC.TEXT: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee is urging the agency to recommend the use of the drug AZT in treating children suffering from acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The action came Friday at a meeting of the Antiviral Drugs Advisory Committee and now goes to the agency for a final decision. An FDA decision to approve labeling of AZT for use in treating children with AIDS would encourage more doctors to prescribe it for youngsters and enable patients to collect reimbursement from their insurance companies. The agency already has approved the use of the drug for adults and has permitted youngsters suffering from the disease to receive it. The manufacturer, Burroughs Wellcome Co., has been distributing the drug at no charge as part of an FDA program to accelerate the distribution of experimental drugs to patients who are seriously ill. The company began marketing the drug in a strawberry-flavored syrup in October.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Near on Satellite Sales
DOC.TEXT: U.S. trade negotiators said Saturday they were close to an agreement with the Japan over removing barriers to the sale of U.S.-made satellites in that country. The officials said the agreement could be completed as early as Monday. It would mark the second success in a 10-month negotiating effort being conducted under the threat of economic retaliation by the U.S. against Japan. A week ago, negotiators announced the first breakthrough in the talks, an agreement to expand sales of U.S. supercomputers in Japan. A U.S. trade official, who spoke on condition his name not be used, said Saturday that only one technical issue remained to be resolved in the satellite talks. He said that the Japanese had agreed to American demands to allow U.S. satellite manufacturers to compete on an equal footing with Japanese companies on satellite projects being sponsored by the Japanese government. Only two weeks ago, U.S. negotiators were expressing dismay with what they considered the unwillingness of the Japanese to make concessions on the satellite issue. However, when the Japanese team arrived Thursday to resume talks, there were reports they were bringing new proposals that would meet American demands. Satellites and supercomputers are two of the products singled out last May by the Bush administration as areas where the Japanese had erected unfair barriers to the sale of American goods. With the resolution of these two issues, only lumber products remain in dispute in the so-called Super 301 negotiations. While negotiators have reported some success at narrowing the differences, the American side is still not satisfied with the access being offered by the Japanese to their market for lumber products. Further talks in the lumber area are scheduled for later in April. The Japanese have been negotiating against a June 16 deadline. The Bush administration is empowered under the 1988 Trade Act to raise tariffs on Japanese products if Japan refuses to open markets.

DOC.HEAD: Government Announces New Clampdown On Exports
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union, in an effort to stop smuggling that has left store shelves bare throughout the country, has announced that Soviet tourists will be forbidden from taking most consumer goods abroad. The list of banned goods seems endless. Soviet tourists are now barred from leaving the country with everything ranging from car batteries to tires, mushrooms, caviar, electric wire, bicycles, cooking oil, fabrics and nearly all food products. Valery Draganov, deputy head of the Customs Authority, announced the clampdown on exports Friday evening and said it was made necessary by chronic shortages of consumer supplies throughout the Soviet Union. ``These are extraordinary, emergency measures needed to stabilize the consumer market,'' he said. He said the restrictions would not apply to purchases made in Soviet hard-currency stores, which do not accept rubles and generally cater to foreigners, or to companies authorized to conduct international trade. The move seems designed to appeal to Soviet shoppers who often spend hours standing in line outside stores with meager supplies. But for Soviets who travel abroad, the announcement was devastating. Soviets are only permitted to leave the country with the equivalent of $30 to $200 dollars, depending on the length and type of trip. To save money, many Soviets bring food with them, while others take along expensive consumer items to pick up spare cash. Soviet goods are generally cheaper than their Western counterparts, although they are usually of a lower quality. Draganov said the new restrictions will last throughout 1990. ``The consumer market is becoming more and more naked,'' he said. ``The situation is becoming even more complex since we witness an increased activity of mafia groups.'' He said underground groups have been known to purchase large shipments of consumer goods from factories and ship them out of the country before they reach Soviet stores. ``We had to stop this mass export of commodities immediately,'' Draganov said. At Chop, a border crossing station in the Western Ukraine, customs officials recently confiscated 200 sets of linens, 20 bicycles and six gasoline-powered saws from Soviet tourists. Dragonov said tourists were ``trying to bring out ... virtually everything one can think of.'' He said they also have been caught at border crossings smuggling cheeses, buckets, mousetraps, electric irons, toys, socks and metalwork equipment. ``Notice that these goods disappear very quickly from the shelves of our shops,'' he said. The smuggling tourists are not only Soviets. National television recently showed a huge warehouse filled with TV sets and other goods it said were confiscated from Polish tourists.

DOC.HEAD: Among Broadcasters, Cable-Bashing Is In
DOC.TEXT: Cable television's free ride is over, and consumer complaints and runaway rates will bring the ``pay TV'' industry under increased government regulation, the nation's broadcasters were told Satuday. ``We began the 1980s with cable an infant industry, crying for special privilege just to survive,'' Edward O. Fritts, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, said in his ``state of the industry'' address. ``Cable is multiplying faster than radio formats,'' Fritts said, calling for Congress and the Federal Communications Commission to ``restore enough balance to the competitive forces to let consumers decide how much programming they want for free.'' The NAB _ fighting cable's encroachment into the lucrative TV business, is backing moves to put cable-TV monopolies under increased regulatory control, Legislation cracking down on the cable companies should pass in this session of Congress, said Sen. Ernest ``Fritz'' Hollings, D-S.C., chairman of the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee. ``The service is sorry, and the rates are horrendous,'' Hollings said. ``We find that's the case all over the country.'' Legislative efforts are under way to allow price controls in areas where cable companies have monopolies, and to enable communities to better ride herd on the service the companies provide. Congress should not _ and will not _ regulate cable TV programming, but cracking down on service and prices is another matter, Hollings said. ``I think we'll get that passed this year,'' he said. Congress is likely to restore the ``must-carry'' provision, requiring cable companies to carry local TV broadcasting, Hollings predicted. Hollings said he personally is the victim of his local cable company, at his home on the Isle of Palms, where Hurricane Hugo slammed ashore last September. ``The hurricane hit us on Sept. 21,'' Hollings said. ``Someday, I hope to get back cable.'' Hollings said that by the turn of the century, more than half the TV watchers in America will be paying for the privilege. ``We call your industry mature,'' he told the broadcasters. ``That means you're not going to get much growth.'' But he discounted the notion the government might ever help people pay their TV bills, no matter how ubiquitous pay services become. ``I've heard we're going to have broadcast stamps like food stamps,'' he said. ``This country's gone crazy in a lot of respects, but not that crazy.'' The NAB is seeking government help in saving AM radio, whose audience has largely left for better-sounding FM. Fritts called for the government to clear up frequency and transmission questions, clearing the way for an AM stereo renaissance. ``It is clear,'' he said, ``that the AM band must have the improvement that NAB has requested.'' ``Free, over-the-air broadcasting'' is being repeated like a mantra this weekend, while some 50,000 broadcasters and exhibitors ponder the future of the industry. ``There are many prophets with a pitch who glibly assure us that broadcasting is in its twilight years,'' Fritts said. ``They are wrong.'' He hailed the powerful presence of the broadcast media in fueling democratic revolutions across Europe _ the equivalent of revolutionary-era printing in this country. Radio and TV, he said, are ``the modern manifestation of the free media that has served our people so well.''

DOC.HEAD: State Investigating its Handling of GDC
DOC.TEXT: The fraud indictment of Florida's biggest land developer has prompted state business regulators to investigate the state's hands-off handling of the troubled General Development Corp. The Miami-based land developer pleaded guilty in federal court last month to mail-fraud conspiracy for misleading customers and overpricing nearly 10,000 homes. Class-action lawsuits against the company involve 60,000 buyers. ``We need to do a better job of protecting the public,'' said Stephen MacNamara, secretary of the Department of Business Regulation. ``Clearly from what I've seen and read, we have not done the job we should have done.'' For its part, state regulators waived any tangible security requirement for General Development Corp. and big developers Deltona Corp. and Avatar Holdings that would have guaranteed construction of roads and other basic improvements. ``I was aware of the rule and unaware of the things being granted,'' said MacNamara, who has headed the department for one year. ``We definitely have to change the policy.'' The state investigation is to determine what action should have been taken against the developer during the 1980s; who was responsible for lax enforcement of state regulations; and, what charges are needed. Two recent resignations from the department involve the land sales division, but neither the state nor the employees are saying if the resignations are related to General Development Corp. E. James Kearney, director of the Division of Land Sales, Condominiums and Mobile Homes, finished work Friday. Samuel Griffis, bureau chief of Land Sales Registration, submitted his resignation March 15. Complaints filed at the Division of Land Sales between 1987 and 1989 charged that the developer was committing fraud and failing to complete road improvements for fully paid lot owners. A 1985 agreement between General Development Corp. and the division said that if the developer failed to meet its obligation to make road improvements for fully paid lot owners, the division could ``seek administrative or judicial remedy.'' Despite mounting complaints, Kearney said he saw no reason to take action against the developer and said it had never missed making improvements. ``They've been delayed because of environmental reasons,'' he said. ``Everybody gets delayed because of environmental reasons.'' Attorney Richard Bennett, who has been battling for General Developer Corp. home and lot owners for six years, complained that the Division of Land Sales ``was not consumer-oriented and not aggressive in solving the complaints.'' ``That's why we've brought these class-actions, because GDC breached its contract with its customers, and the customers were unable to persuade state or federal governmental regulators to assist them to resolve their complaints,'' he said. MacNamara says he may want to toughen division policies and give consumers more information about developers involved in lawsuits. If the Division of Land Sales is not already required to turn over information to the attorney general's office about a developer suspected of fraudulent dealings, the practice should become division policy, he said. General Development Corp. estimates it would cost about $400 million to finish developing its land, but only $102.1 million is budgeted for improvements, according to its latest annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

DOC.HEAD: 53 Dead, 133 Wounded in New Round of Intra-Christian Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2-3 to UPDATE number of casualties.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BEI1,2,3
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces pounded east Beirut with artillery barrages Saturday after a night of house-to-house fighting under parachute flares for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave. Police said at least 53 people were killed and 133 wounded since the new round of full-scale warfare erupted at dawn Friday between Gen. Michel Aoun's 19,000 army troops and Christian warlord Samir Geagea's 6,000 Lebanese Forces militiamen. The killings raised the overall death toll to 829 killed and 2,289 wounded since Jan. 30, when Aoun moved against Geagea in a bid to crush the only significant challenge to the general's authority in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. The new round of fighting shattered a March 3 cease-fire, which had been threatened by sporadic clashes for weeks. Police said Aoun's forces used 155mm howitzer batteries to pour shells onto Beirut's port and the adjacent seaside Karantina district, which houses Geagea's military command. Geagea's gunners returned the fire and blasted the army-held mountain resort towns of Bekfaya, Brummana and Ein Saadeh with multi-barreled rocket launchers. ``Why are these madmen raining death and destruction on us all over again?'' screamed Madeleine Tabet, a Christian housewife reached by telephone at the basement of her east Beirut home. The bombardment interrupted an exodus of east Beirut residents fleeing to the divided city's Moslem sector. Cars in long lines bumped into each other as motorists driving westward came under shellfire. Huge clouds of black smoke obscured east Beirut and the Christian hinterland as the shelling raged Saturday, setting dozens of buildings ablaze and touching off forest fires. Shells hit schools, churches, monasteries, apartments and bakeries in Beirut's Christian sector and several towns in Kesrouan province, 20 miles northeast of the capital. Police said gasoline storage tanks at several filling stations hit Friday burned out of control through Saturday. Scores of houses collapsed, some on their tenants. Parachute flares illuminated Kesrouan as the warring Christians battled at night for the key highway town of Kleiat and neighboring villages, police reported. ``They are fighting from house to house in Kleiat and trading hit-and-run grenade assaults in the streets of east Beirut. The dust hasn't settled yet but no side has made any territorial gains,'' said the police spokeman. He could not be named under standing regulations. Kleiat controls the only highway that can be used by tanks between Kesrouan, a major Geagea stronghold, and Aoun's main power bases in Metn Province. Tens of thousands of residents remained huddled in basements and bomb shelters in east Beirut for a second day while hundreds of familes sought refuge in the chilly pine forests of Kesrouan, the spokesman said. Aoun's failure to subdue Geagea appears to be undermining his political stature and Geagea's public appeals for a settlement based on a Christian allegiance to the Syrian-backed government of President Elias Hrawi have been gaining momentum. Aoun, Geagea and Hrawi are Maronites, a 900,000-strong Christian sect that has dominated Lebanon's politics since it gained independence from France in 1943. Antoine Beshara, a Maronite who heads Lebanon's 300,000-strong Federation of Labor Unions, has declared support for Hrawi, whose internationally recognized government is based in Moslem west Beirut. Geagea's militia on Friday cooperated with troops under Hrawi's army commander, Gen. Emille Lahoud, when they reopened the port crossing between Beirut's Moslem and Christian sectors after a year-long closure. Hrawi, 64, was elected by parliament Nov. 24 with a mandate to enforce an Arab League-brokered peace plan to resolve Lebanon's civil war. The peace plan gives Moslems an equal share of power with Christians. Hrawi fired Aoun as army commander and interim prime minister. But the general has held out in the presidential palace in a Christian enclave east of Beirut, claiming Hrawi's election was unconstitutional. Aoun has also rejected the Arab League peace plan because it did not guarantee a total withdrawal of Syria's 40,000 troops.

DOC.HEAD: Nepel Government Closes Schools to Put Down Democracy Movement
DOC.TEXT: The government closed all high schools in the capital and two suburbs Saturday to try to curb student demonstrations for multiparty politics, state-owned radio reported. The move came hours after police fired tear gas and rifles to disperse about 5,000 people who poured into the streets of Patan, a Katmandu suburb, to protest the killings of two demonstrators Friday, witnesses said. The demonstrations are part of a growing movement demanding restoration of a multiparty political system in this Himalayan kingdom, one of the oldest monarchies in the world. At least 14 people have been killed since Feb. 18, when King Birendra's government cracked down on the movement led by the Nepali Congress Party and a coalition of left-wing parties. In the lastest government response, the state-owned radio, quoting the Ministry of Education, said about 100 schools in Katmandu, Bhakatapur and Patan will remain closed indefinitely. ``Due to lack of educational atmosphere in some schools of Katmandu valley, the government has decided to close down all high schools,'' the radio said. Students have taken part in the nationwide demonstrations, which have often turned violent. Hundreds of people _ including doctors, lawyers and journalists in addition to students _ have been arrested. The government had already closed Tribhuvan University's five colleges around the country. Besides street protests, the political turmoil is also bringing criticism within the government. It suffered the latest blow Friday when Foreign Minister Shailendra Kumar Upadhyaya resigned over the government's handling of the issue. Upadhyaya said he had advised Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha to hold talks with the activists, but that his advice went unheeded. The government says Nepal already has a working democracy, even though a royal decree bans political parties. Officials accuse the demonstrators of trying to foist their brand of democracy on the country. Nepal once tried a Western-style democracy in 1959, when the Nepali Congress Party was overwhelmingly voted to power and formed the country's first parliamentary government. The experiment ended when King Mahendra, Birendra's father, dismissed the government in 1961, accusing it of corruption and mismanagement.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to correct cycle designator
Three-Time Mugging Victim Indicted After Saying She Fired on Robber
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Ysesnande in 2nd graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A three-time mugging victim, indicted on a weapons charge after saying she shot an armed man who was trying to rob her, has hired Bernhard Goetz's lawyer to defend her, the Daily News reported Saturday. Ysesnande Bureau, 20, said she was attacked Monday night with a girlfriend who died from gunshots fired from a car moments after the mugger fled. She was charged with possession of a deadly weapon and freed Friday on $500 bail. Her lawyer, Barry Slotnick, denounced prosecutors for pressing charges against his client. ``She is one of the many innocent victims in New York City,'' Slotnick said. Slotnick also represented Goetz, who was convicted on a weapons charge for shooting four youths he said were trying to rob him on a subway train. ``She is another decent, law-aiding citizen who was brutalized in several muggings and was forced to carry a gun to protect herself,'' Slotnick was quoted as saying. Slotnick gave the following account of the incident: Bureau and her friend, Theresa Jackson, 19, were in Jackson's car waiting for a green light in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. An armed man jerked open the driver's door and tried to snatch Jackson's purse, then tried to rip Jackson's earrings off. Bureau pulled out her gun, a .25 caliber pistol, and fired once, grazing the forehead of Clint Smith, 24. Smith fled and the women drove off. A few blocks later, a car pulled up next to them. Someone inside fired a shot that hit Jackson in the head. She died Wednesday at Kings County Hospital. Smith was arrested late Monday when he went to a hospital to be treated for his head wound. He was held on $100,000 bail on attempted robbery charges. Police have not made an arrest in Jackson's slaying.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Gorbachev's Message to the Lithuanian People
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's appeal Saturday to the Lithuanian people as carried by the Tass news agency. The statement was read by announcers on Radio Moscow and Soviet television. Dear citizens of the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic, I am addressing you at a difficult time for our country. The March 11 decisions of the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet have brought us to a critical point. The attempts being taken by the incumbent Lithuanian leadership to break the republic's ties with the Soviet Union and its tactics of unilateral and ultimate actions endanger the normal life and security of all people in the republic, Lithuanians and non-Lithuanians, and are a cause of grave concern in the country. Is it normal when amendments to the constitution, resolving the destiny of the republic and its people and concerning the interests of the entire country, are adopted in haste, without consultations and discussions, actually within one night? The third congress of U.S.S.R. People's Deputies urged the Supreme Soviet of the republic to renounce political recklessness. The Lithuanian leadership responded to this appeal for common sense with the escalation of irresponsible and illegitimate decisions. This juxtaposes Lithuania with other constituent republics and the whole of the Soviet Union and undermines the historically established ties and cooperation between our peoples. The actions being taken in Lithuania have no logical foundation. They are being taken at a time when we have begun to resolve vital issues of the Soviet federation on a really democratic basis. What is our position? It is the sincere adherence to the ideas of the free and original development of all peoples of our country, and respect for their legitimate rights to self-determination and sovereignty. This fully refers to the Lithuanian people, too. Now attempts are being made to convince you that genuine sovereignty within the Soviet Union, without breaking away from it, is impossible. Simultaneously, old grudges are being purposefully kindled and the dark sides of joint life are being emphasized. Indeed, our past includes many things that we are mutually rejecting. And this refers not only to the Lithuanian people. But no one can say that in the years of perestroika any people in our country has been deliberately elevated or purposefully humiliated. We have for years lived in one home. Does the past time deserve only bad words? Have the Lithuanian literature and poetry, theater and cinema, music and architecture, education and sports faded and got lost in the multicoloured Soviet culture? Was it not in the mutual work and with the fraternal aid from other republics that your industry and agriculture have been developing? Did Lithuania itself not extend a helping hand to other peoples in times of trouble? Did the Lithuanian citizens not support the U.S.S.R. constitution, by which Lithuania abided for years honestly and strictly as a fully-fledged republic? The incumbent Lithuanian leaders are trying to convince you that their separatist actions will not affect the economic, scientific, technical and other ties with the other republics of the U.S.S.R. But this is not so, because all these ties can develop normally and yield fruits only in a favourable atmosphere of confidence and mutual assistance and not in the situation of confrontation, ultimatums, disrespect for one another and ethnic strife. The pointed disrespect for the U.S.S.R. constitution, the challenge to Soviet laws and the non-implementation of union obligations give rise to just indignation all over the country. The president of the U.S.S.R., the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet and the U.S.S.R. government are receiving numerous letters and telegrams expressing utter concern and perplexity in connection with the developments in Lithuania. People demand that the U.S.S.R. constitution be defended and that the union be protected from the harm caused by the actions of separatists. They propose taking effective economic, political and administrative measures. People in Byelorussia and Kaliningrad region are raising the issue of returning territories transferred to Lithuania after it joined the U.S.S.R. In general, the situation in the republic and around it has become dramatic. If the voice of reason is not heeded now, developments can have grave consequences for all of us. We must be united in striving to prevent this. I have appealed to the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet, proposing that it immediately annul the illegal acts it has adopted. This will open a possibility for discussing the entire range of problems on the solely acceptable basis _ within the framework of the U.S.S.R. constitution. I am expressing hope that my appeal will be supported by the citizens of the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Overlooked Positive Test Until Arrest
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines took no action against a flight engineer who tested positive for cocaine use until managers learned he had been charged with buying crack seven months later, the airline said Saturday. The test results apparently went unnoticed because of a clerical error, said Eastern spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak. Dain Schneemilch, 36, of Key Largo, Fla., was fired March 20, but the Air Line Pilots Association has filed a grievance to appeal the dismissal, she said. Schneemilch returned to work for the strike-plagued carrier in the midst of a machinists' union strike that initially brought Eastern flights to a virtual halt. Under company policy, returning workers were required to submit to drug tests. Schneemilch tested positive for cocaine use last July 19, an offense that warrants firing under Eastern rules, the Miami-based airline said. But the results entered his personnel file without action. ``We were in the middle of a big buildup,'' Ceremsak said. ``There was a tremendous volume. At that time, somehow inadvertently the results of his tests were not picked up on. It was some sort of clerical error that his positive readout was not caught.'' Schneemilch went back to work as a second officer serving as flight engineer, the No. 3 position in the cockpit, on Boeing 727s. He bid to become a first officer, or co-pilot, and got the promotion on the basis of seniority Sept. 18, Ceremsak said. Schneemilch was still attending ground pilot school when he was arrested after allegedly buying a $20 crack cocaine rock from an undercover sheriff's officer, Ceremsak said. He flew no airline flights as a co-pilot, she said. Authorities have video and audio tapes of the arrest. Schneemilch, who tested negative for cocaine in an Eastern test four days before his arrest, has pleaded innocent and is awaiting disposition of the drug case. Defense attorney Timothy Thomes refused comment, saying, ``We're not trying to cover anything up, but by the same token while matters are pending we would have no comment.'' When it learned of the arrest, Eastern checked its drug test results, found the old records and confronted Schneemilch, Ceremsak said. He resigned but rescinded his resignation two weeks later, which led to his firing last month. The Federal Aviation Administration ``asked us to go back and review all of the drug tests that had been administered, and we went back through hundreds of files and that was the only error,'' she said. The FAA has ordered random drug testing of airline employees since last December. Eastern policy already called for testing of all new employees and testing of pilots during their annual physical. Christopher Witkowski, director of the Aviation Consumer Action Project, questioned Eastern's methods for assuring its pilots are drug-free and FAA monitoring when Eastern was hiring about 1,000 pilots from April to August last year. ``To say that it's an oversight shows that there's something wrong in how safe an airline they are,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fog Prevails in Central, Eastern States
DOC.TEXT: Fog prevailed in the central and eastern states Saturday, and dense fog in some areas dropped visibilities to near zero, while rains ranged from the upper Ohio Valley and the mid-Atlantic Coast to the Carolinas. Showers and thunderstorms dotted southern Florida, and light rain and drizzle wet parts of Kansas and the middle Mississippi Valley. Sunny skies prevailed across the western third of the country. Zero visibility was reported in parts of southeastern Minnesota, parts of southern and eastern Wisconsin, much of northern and central Illinois, central Missouri, southeastern Louisiana, and southern and east central Mississippi. In the Great Plains, dense fog sharply reduced visibility in north central Texas, the south plains of Texas, south central Kansas, and the central third of Oklahoma. In the upper Midwest, fog was prevalent in Ohio and Indiana, with dense fog reported in north central and southwestern lower Michigan. Dense fog was also reported in Maryland and Virginia, in southern Alabama, and in northern Arizona. A spring storm which brought up to 8 inches of snow to central Maine moved out to sea overnight. Light snow lingered in northern Maine in early afternoon. Temperatures were in the 40s Saturday afternoon in parts of the middle Mississippi Valley, the Great Lakes region and the northeastern states, with 30s reported in Michigan and New England. Readings were mostly in the 50s and 60s elsewhere east of the Rockies. Temperatures were in the 70s in the Gulf Coast region, with 80s in southern Florida. Temperatures were mostly in the 50s and 60s in the western states. The low for the nation Saturday morning was 16 degrees above zero at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Moves Up Launch Date for Space Telescope
DOC.TEXT: NASA, in a rare move, advanced the launch date Saturday for the shuttle Discovery and its prestigious payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. Discovery now is due to lift off April 10, two days earlier than planned. ``The shuttle team is ready to fly. Hubble is one of the most exciting payloads ever launched aboard the shuttle, and we're looking forward to the mission,'' said William Lenoir, associate administrator for space flight for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The space agency's Flight Readiness Review Board decided to move up the mission after meeting for two days at Kennedy Space Center. NASA said last week technicians needed little of the contingency time built into Discovery's prelaunch schedule. Once deployed by Discovery's astronauts, the Hubble will orbit 380 miles above Earth for 15 years. The telescope will be capable of looking seven times more deeply into space with greater clarity and detecting objects 50 times fainter than the best ground-based observatory. Astronomers expect to use it to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling toward Earth for 14 billion years. NASA occasionally has shifted shuttle launch dates because of scheduling changes in the months prior to liftoff. But it is the first time liftoff has been accelerated during orbiter processing. In February, Discovery's launch date was changed from April 18 to April 12 after the lower right segment of the shuttle's solid rocket booster was replaced more quickly than anticipated. The telescope's installation into the orbiter was delayed last week, however, after small mosquito-like insects called midges invaded a payload preparation room at the launch pad. Engineers feared the bugs might damage the sensitive instrument, the most expensive unmanned spacecraft ever built. Forty midges were trapped, and technicians loaded the 25,000-pound telescope into the shuttle's payload bay Thursday, two days later than planned. Mission specialist Bruce McCandless II, one of Discovery's five astronauts, helped link electrical connections between Discovery and Hubble on Friday. He also checked the telescope for sharp edges that might snag spacesuits in the event of a spacewalk. McCandless and mission specialist Kathryn Sullivan are prepared to step into space should the telescope need to be adjusted or repaired following deployment. It would be the first American spacewalk since 1985. Technicians planned to test the telescope's systems and scientific instruments Sunday. They want to ensure remote communications with the Space Telescope Operations Control Center at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., and other facilities. The telescope is named for the late American astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who discovered in the 1920s the universe is constantly expanding, a finding that is the basis for the current Big Bang theory of the formation of the universe.

DOC.HEAD: `Fish-Sicle' Brought to Court To Prove Piranha Death
DOC.TEXT: A pet store owner says he no longer owns a deadly pet piranha fish that could threaten Oklahoma wildlife, and just to prove it he brought the fish to court _ frozen in a dripping bag of ice. Bob Geary was cited in early January for violating a state law banning piranhas because they could pose a danger to wildlife if released into a lake. He said a supplier sent him the fish by mistake four years ago, and he asked a district judge Jan. 26 to give him a chance to keep it. Geary said he'd try to persuade the state Wildlife Conservation Department to let him keep the fish, and promised to send it to Kansas if he failed. But he returned to court Friday to say the deal is, well, dead. Geary said the fish died two weeks ago when someone mistakenly turned up the heat in its tank. Prosecutor Clayton Niemeyer had agreed to drop the case if Geary could prove the fish had died. ``He spent $4,000 defending his fish and the fish is no longer alive, so I saw no reason to pursue it further,'' Niemeyer said. Niemeyer called the evidence produced in court Friday a ``fish-sicle.'' The frozen piranha was turned over to state wildlife rangers, who said they would have it stuffed and use it for educational purposes.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Has One Twin Prematurely, Other Expected In July
DOC.TEXT: A 24-year-old woman who was expecting twins in July has delivered one baby, but will have to wait on the other. In a rare birth doctors say was one of just 14 cases reported nationally, Donna Krasenics delivered a 1-pound, 8-ounce baby girl, Shakoora, at Crawford Long Hospital on Thursday, 15 weeks prematurely. Shakoora was listed in critical condition in Crawford Long's intensive care unit Saturday. Her mother was in good condition. Doctors were able to stop Mrs. Krasenics' labor with the second baby, and hospital officials said she will remain in bed until her second child is delivered. ``Shakoora is my first child, and I wasn't paying much attention to anything except the birth when I heard somebody in the delivery room say something about there being only 13 known cases like mine,'' Mrs. Krasenics said. Officials said the baby was delivered as Dr. Camille Davis-Williams tried to stop the premature birth of Shakoora. The amniotic sac for the second baby did not break, so the doctor was able to halt further labor, Brown said. Dr. Paul Brown, an assistant professor at Emory University's department of obstetrics and gynecology, had planned to report his two-year case study of such births, but decided to hold off to include the Krasenics birth. Only 13 such births have been reported in medical literature, he said. ``The medical community does not know why a patient goes into premature labor in these cases,'' Brown said.

DOC.HEAD: Heart of London Becomes A Battleground
With AM-Tax Protest
DOC.TEXT: The heart of London became a battleground Saturday, and fashionable shopping and theater districts packed with locals and tourists suddenly found themselves at the mercy of roving gangs. It was a scene more reminiscent of street fighting in Beirut or Israel's occupied territories than London's favorite tourist haunts: Trafalgar Square, Regent Street, Piccadilly Circus and Leicester Square. Running battles between rock-throwing militants and riot police left a trail of injury and destruction, from overturned and burned-out cars to smashed windows and looted shops. The militants, who broke off from a protest by more than 40,000 people demonstrating against a new nationwide local tax, smashed plate-glass windows at some of the world's most famous stores, including Liberty's, Aquascutum, Wedgwood and Mappin and Webb. ``The mindless mob, although a small minority, has taken over,'' said a uniformed policeman at the intersection of Oxford and Regent streets. On Charing Cross Road, a mile away, looters carried away expensive musical instruments even as police with riot shields tried to clear the area. Two china shops on Regent Street also had their display windows pillaged. Many of the broken windows set off burglar alarms, which mixed with the constant wail of police sirens and fire engines. The rioting broke out in late afternoon as the stores prepared to close for the weekend. It spread into the evening and overtook theatergoers headed into London's West End for a Saturday night out. Several theaters kept their doors shut at the height of the rampage, leaving ticket-holders standing outside. Some of them got caught between the protesters and the police. Most shows went on, although some started late. One woman dressed in a silk dress and fur jacket walked up to a riot policeman holding a shield outside the Palace Theatre at the corner of Shaftesbury Avenue and Charing Cross Road. ``Excuse me,'' she said, ``have you got any idea how long this is going to last?'' At the Duke of York Theatre in St. Martin's Lane, 650 people were locked in as rioting flared outside during a performance of the play ``Shirley Valentine.'' ``It was like being under siege,'' said General Manager Andy Phipps. One target of the rioters was the Renault showroom on Charing Cross Road near the Leicester Square subway stop, one of five in central London that were sealed off by police. The showroom's floor-to-ceiling windows were smashed, and so were the windows of every car inside. Rocks, cans, bricks and bottles were thrown through the windows of banks, restaurants, shops, the royal jewelers Garrards, Tower Records and nightclubs, including the popular Stringfellows. Garbage cans heaved by the protesters ended up amidst spring fashions and floral displays in many showrooms along Regent Street. Charing Cross Road and St. Martin's Lane, which runs from Leicester Square to Trafalgar Square, were littered with rubble, broken glass and torched cars.

DOC.HEAD: Far Right Party, Capitalizating On Immigration Fears, Seeks Wider Power Base
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT that Rocard called for common strategy on racism sted immigration, SUB 15th graf, `Premier Michel...' Pickup 16th graf, `The mainstream...'
DOC.TEXT: Jean-Marie Le Pen whipped his followers into a frenzy of applause and singing Saturday, promising them that their extreme-right National Front party stands on the threshold of real political power. The 1,600 delegates to the Eighth Party Congress chose Le Pen by cheers and handclapping to lead the party from the sidelines of single-issue politics to what they hope will be victory in 1993 legislative elections. ``If I advance, follow me; if I die, avenge me; if I shirk, kill me,'' the former paratrooper told the delegates. ``We are no longer a tiny movement. We are today the leading political movement in France.'' Le Pen founded the anti-immigration party in 1972 and achieved global notoriety in 1987 when he called the Nazi Holocaust a ``detail of history.'' In a 90-minute speech punctuated by frequent applause and chants, Le Pen accused both the governing Socialists and traditional conservative parties of ``political AIDS.'' He hammered away at a favorite theme: that other politicians turn a blind eye to immigration, thereby stoking racial pressures that will soon be insoluble except through violence. After the speech and Le Pen's re-election in the vast, flag-draped amphitheater on the French Riviera, the crowd broke into the ``Ode to Joy'' from Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. Earlier, about 700 people prayed outside the Palace of Justice for the 6 million Jews killed during the Holocaust and to protest the attendance of Franz Schoenhuber, leader of West Germany's far-right Republican Party. Schoenhuber was a soldier in the Nazi SS during World War II. His party and the National Front form an alliance at the European Parliament in Strasbourg. The National Front won 12 pecent of the vote in presidential elections in 1988, based on its anti-immigration platform. Its support is strongest among white voters in areas where large numbers of North African and black immigrants live. About 4 million of the country's 55 million people are immigrants, the majority of them Moslems from North Africa. ``We are the expression of the French people who want to become once again their own masters,'' said Bruno Megret, the party's second in command. ``We will be in power before the end of the decade.'' The National Front hopes to broaden its platform to include ecological issues in an effort to woo rural voters. The party recently gained its first seat in the 577-seat National Assembly. It held 35 seats until electoral changes in 1988 left the party without representation. The congress came as leaders of France's mainstream conservative parties met near Paris to work out a common position on immigration ahead of talks with the Socialist government on racism next week. Premier Michel Rocard called for a conference with opposition leaders to develop a common strategy on racism following a series of racially motivated killings and beatings over past months. The National Front was not invited. The mainstream rightist parties say anti-racism measures must be accompanied by a revamped policy on immigration. Former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, leader of the Union for French Democracy coalition, urged deporting illegal immigrants, tightening political asylum rules, cutting social benefits to immigrants and curbing the entry of their family members. ``France is not a country of immigration,'' Giscard said. ``The most serious fault of the government is to have left this debate to the extremists. Foreigners can live in France, with respect for their human rights, but they cannot change France.'' A poll taken during a six-month government investigation into racism showed Monday that 75 percent of French citizens thought there were too many North Africans in France.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Says No TV Marti Broadcasts Saturday
DOC.TEXT: TV Marti, the U.S. television channel beamed to Cuba despite Havana's opposition, was not on the air Saturday, Cuba's official news agency reported. Prensa Latina, in a dispatch monitored in Mexico City, repeated its position that the TV Marti broadcasts are illegal. ``The Cuban government considers the action as a violation of the Caribbean country's sovereignty and of numerous international regulations to which the United States subscribes,'' Prensa Latina said. Cuba blocked the signal of what it calls ``channel worm'' when it began transmitting on Tuesday and continued to jam broadcasts throughout the week. The Cuban government has lodged protests with the U.S. Federal Communications Commission and international organizations.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
White House Says U.S. Soldiers Critically Injured in Attack in Honduras
