DOC.TEXT: A busload of U.S. soldiers stationed in Honduras was attacked when returning to their base from an outing and some of them were critically wounded, a White House spokesman said Saturday. The bus was fired upon with automatic gunfire about 1 p.m., EST said spokesman Sean Walsh. He said the number and nature of the injuries was not known, only that some were in serious and critical condition. ``We deplore any action against U.S. citizens. We'll be working closely with the Honduran government on the investigation,'' said Walsh. He said a leftist group in Honduras had claimed responsibility for the action. The United States keeps several thousand personnel stationed in Honduras, most of them based at Palmerola, a U.S.-built base several miles from Tegucigalpa.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
U.S. Soldiers Attacked in Honduras
DOC.TEXT: Three snipers fired automatic weapons at a bus carrying U.S. airmen Saturday, injuring six of them, a U.S. military officer said. The gunmen fired on the bus about 1 p.m. six miles north of Tegucigalpa, the capital, said Maj. Bruce Jessup, a spokesman for U.S. troops based in the Central American nation. He said two Americans were seriously wounded. They were taken to a civilian hospital in Tegucigalpa and underwent surgery. There were 28 U.S. airmen on the bus, and they did not return fire, Jessup said. ``The Americans did not have time to return fire, although there were some security personnel on the bus,'' he said. He said a group called the Frente Moranzano Liberation Nacional had claimed responsibility for the attack. He said the attackers fled. At the time of the attack, the soldiers were returning to the Soto Cano military base from a recreational tour, Jessup said.

DOC.HEAD: An Explanation of Britain's New Poll Tax
With AM-Tax Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS new grafs 14-18 with background on tax revolt in 1381; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The new local tax system that has angered many Britons and prompted protests and riots across the country goes into effect Sunday in England and Wales. Scotland has had the tax for a year. Anger over the tax has contributed to a record 28-point lead by the main opposition Labor Party over Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's governing Conservatives, according to a Harris poll last weekend. The community charge is levied by local governments on every adult in a household. It replaces a single tax paid by each household and based on the value of the property. That means that now a family with four members over age 18 living in a small apartment will pay four times as much as a single person living in a large house. A duke in a 100-room mansion would pay as much as a street sweeper in a cottage if they live in the same borough. The amount each person will pay is the same throughout a community, but it varies widely from borough to borough depending on the budget needs of the area. Critics of the new tax have dubbed it the ``poll tax'' after a per-capita tax that set off a peasants' revolt in 1381. Low-income and disabled people can receive rebates of up to 80 percent on the new tax. But critics say it is unfair because unlike the income tax, which is used to pay for national government expenditures, it does not take into account an individual's ability to pay. Legislation written by Mrs. Thatcher's government created the tax with the aim of reducing central government subsidies to local government. But members of local councils determine how much to charge. The government expected the Labor Party to suffer in elections because high-spending councils with a wide range of public services are mostly run by Labor members who would have to set a high poll tax to pay for them. But many of the highest increases have been set by Conservative councils to maintain their services. The public was initially assured by civil servants and Conservative lawmakers that the increases would be quite small. Scotland has had the tax for a year. The Peasants' Revolt of 1381 followed the imposition of the last poll tax in England, when every person over the age of 15 was ordered to pay. Crying ``Hang all the lawyers,'' 100,000 peasants marched on London. They pillaged manor houses, burnt the court rolls containing their names to destroy the evidence for taxation and murdered lawyers, magistrates and other officials. Archbishop of Canterbury Simon of Sudbury, a lawyer, was also chancellor of England and regarded by the rebels as one of those responsible for imposing the tax. The rebels dragged him from the Tower of London and beheaded him on Tower Hill. King Richard II rode to meet the rebels at Smithfield _ site of London's present-day wholesale meat market _ and peasant leader Wat Tyler was slain. The insurgents dispersed on the king's promise of reforms but Richard sent an army of 40,000 men through the most rebellious counties of Kent and Essex, and hundreds of peasants were put to death.

DOC.HEAD: Failed Latch Caused Helicopter Damage When Parts Rained Down on Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `The helicopter...,' to ADD model of aircraft.
DOC.TEXT: Investigators said Saturday that a medical helicopter's engine cover came loose and was chopped up by the rotor blades, scattering metal and fiberglass fragments on a street where youths were playing. No one was injured in Thursday's incident in this Pittsburgh suburb. The helicopter, flying to Washington Hospital to pick up a patient, returned safely to its base at Allegheny General Hospital in Pittsburgh. Originally, the accident had been blamed on a bird. Tom Mahony, a safety inspector with the Federal Aviation Administration, said the most critical of the six latches holding a fiberglass cowling in place over the engine apparently failed. An investigation on Friday found the latch ``shows some wear, more than is normal,'' Mahony said. ``It's apparent that the latch had failed and the airstream got underneath the cowling until it separated from the airframe.'' The 2-by-4-foot section got caught in the helicopter's main rotors and was torn apart, Mahony said. One of the four rotors, which are made of fiberglass with a metal leading edge, had what he termed very minor damage. Mahony said the investigation ruled out the possibility the helicopter had collided with a bird, as hospital officials initially suspected. About a dozen metal and fiberglass fragments, one measuring more than a foot square, showered down near where six children were playing street hockey. ``It's a miracle none of us were hit,'' said one of the boys, Michael Rosenberger, 17. The helicopter, a Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm BK-117, will return to service as soon as repairs are completed, Mahony said. No action will be taken against the pilot, John Johnston, or the hospital. The FAA probably will carry out informal checks to determine whether similar incidents have occurred, he said. The hospital made a thorough inspection of its other two Life Flight helicopters and found nothing wrong, said spokesman Tom Chakurda.

DOC.HEAD: Former FDA Official Pleads Guilty in Generic Drug Scandal
DOC.TEXT: A former U.S. Food and Drug Administration official pleaded guilty to accepting a $20,000 bribe to expedite a generic drug maker's application in a scandal that has snared several other FDA employees. Jan T. Sturm, 35, of Columbia, Md., pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court on Friday to accepting the bribe from Raju Vegesna, former president of American Therapeutics Inc. in Bohemia, N.Y., prosecutors said. Sturm, a former consumer safety officer in the FDA's generic drug division, pleaded guilty to involvement in unlawful gratuities, U.S. Attorney Breckinridge Willcox said in a statement. Sturm faces a maximum penalty of two years in prison and a $250,000 fine, Willcox said. He is to be sentenced June 12. The former FDA official accepted the $20,000 to buy a new car in exchange for expediting Vegesna's application to produce generic drugs, Willcox said. American Therapeutics pleaded guilty Friday to one count of using interstate facilities in aid of racketeering. The company faces a maximum fine of $500,000, Willcox said. Sturm, American Therapeutics, Vegesna and former drug consultant Mohammed Azeem were charged March 2 in a bribery scandal dating to 1988 that also involves Charles Y. Chang, former branch chief of the generic drug division. Azeem pleaded guilty March 16 to interstate travel in aid of racketeering and offering an illegal gratuity. Vegesna has not yet entered a plea. American Therapeutics, Vegesna and Azeem allegedly provided Chang with a trip to Hong Kong, Thailand, and London in 1987; furniture; cash and a computer in return for his favor on generic drug applications, Willcox said. The generic drug division approves applications of pharmaceutical companies that seek to market generic drugs, which are less expensive equivalents to brand-name drugs. Sturm was responsible for tracking the progress of drug applications submitted by pharmaceutical companies. Chang pleaded guilty in May 1989 to two counts of interstate travel in aid of racketeering. Last October, he was fined $10,000 and ordered to spend a year in a federal work-release program and to perform 1,000 hours of community service. Since the investigation began in 1988, three former FDA employees, including Chang but not Sturm; three generic drug company executives; and two generic drug companies in addition to American therapeutics have been convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Ann Arbor Votes on $5 Abortion Fine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE that fine would be imposed on both woman and doctor. Pick up 3rd graf: ``What it says...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Idaho Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Residents in this liberal college town vote Monday on whether to impose a token $5 fine for abortions if the procedure ever is banned by state or federal law. Abortion rights advocates say the small fine would create a ``zone of reproductive freedom'' in the event of a state or federal ban, but the mayor, who favors abortion rights, says it would hurt the city's reputation. The fine would be imposed on both the doctor performing an abortion and the woman who underwent the operation. ``What it says to police is, `Don't go looking for abortion criminals; go look for murderers and rapists,''' said Sabra Briere, who put the proposal on the ballot with a 4,127-signature petition drive. The ballot issue is yet another front in the lengthy, emotional war over abortion. On Friday, Idaho Gov. Cecil Andrus vetoed a bill that would have created the nation's most restrictive state abortion law. Proponents of the initiative say that if it were passed, and if abortion were someday outlawed, city police would enforce the token fine while state police would enforce whatever measure was approved statewide. Ann Arbor, a city of nearly 108,000 people that is home to the University of Michigan, bucked the Michigan trend on a 1988 ballot by supporting the use of state funds for poor women's abortions. Briere, a student services coordinator at the university, said Friday: ``I don't want to see abortion under attack any longer. It shouldn't even be an issue at all.'' The charter provision to make abortion an infraction similar to a parking ticket would go into effect in the event of a state or federal ban. About 22,000 of Ann Arbor's 60,000 registered voters are expected to cast ballots Monday. About 15 percent of those voting are expected to be students, said Republican Mayor Jerry Jernigan. Jernigan said the city council is pro-choice, but said he doesn't believe the city should have jurisdiction over an issue such as abortion. ``There's no question that this is hurting Ann Arbor's reputation,'' Jernigan said, explaining that if the proposal passes, it would make the city known as a place to get an abortion. He said the issue should have been been aired in public hearings, which are not required for city ballot measures. Under city law, the council could also enact such a fine. City Councilman Tom Richardson, a Republican facing re-election Monday, agreed that the proposal doesn't belong on the city charter. ``I think it's absolutely abhorrent to take such a serious issue as abortion and treat it in such a flippant way,'' he said. Local anti-abortion activists have remained relatively silent about the proposal, concentrating instead on a petition drive to require parental consent for anyone under 18 to have an abortion. ``We're putting our energies where they're more needed and more effective,'' said Barbara Listing, president of Right to Life of Michigan, Also on Monday's ballot in the city 38 miles west of Detroit is a symbolic proposal to increase the fine for possessing or selling marijuanan from $5 to $25. The fine has been in place since 1974, enabling the city to prosecute offenders for ordinance violations instead of misdemeanors under state law. Listing said Saturday she was basically ignoring the abortion vote. ``Ann Arbor is a rather unique community,'' she said. ``Even if it does pass, it's really not going to have any effect. Abortion is still legal.''

DOC.HEAD: Church Leaders Applaud Growth of Freedom In Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 5th graf pvs, `They hope...,' to UPDATE with appointment of church's highest-ranking black. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Haight, speaking...' Ringger cq in 14th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Dramatic changes in Eastern Europe are as much spiritual as political, and were brought about by divine intervention in the affairs of men, a Mormon Church leader said Saturday. ``This only could have happened in such a miraculous way by the intervening hand of the Almighty,'' Elder David B. Haight told the 160th Annual General Conference of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The 7.3 million-member church has acted quickly to take advantage of democratic political reforms in Eastern Europe. On July 1, church officials will establish the first Mormon missions in Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary since 1950. The plan was announced previously. They hope eventually to gain recognition in the Soviet Union, the People's Republic of China and many Islamic countries where the Utah-based church has no official presence. Also Saturday, church leaders announced that a Brazilian lay minister had been appointed to the highest church post ever held by a black. Helvecio Martins, of Rio de Janeiro, was named to the second Quorum of the Seventy, the lowest tier in the administrative hierarchy of the 106-year-old church. He will have regional authority. Martins, 59, joined the church in 1972, six years before Benson's predecessor, Spencer W. Kimball, announced a revelation lifting of a ban against blacks holding the church's priesthood. The appointment is for five years. Haight, speaking in the Tabernacle on Temple Square, challenged church members to serve their fellow men by teaching the gospel of Jesus Christ. ``We declare in all solemnity that the Lord is now preparing the nations of the earth to receive the truth he desires them to have,'' said Haight, a member of the faith's Quorum of the Twelve Apostles, which advises the governing First Presidency. Haight said the news media have portrayed events in Eastern Europe as a purely political revolution, when most of the inhabitants of those countries see the upheaval as religious and ``have acknowledged the influence of divine revelation.'' The church founded by Joseph Smith in upstate New York in 1830 has more than 40,000 full-time missionaries and 228 missions. Mormons believe their church was formed for the purpose of teaching the true gospel before Christ's return. Establishment of democracy and religious freedom followed exposure, in a variety of ways, to those ideals, Haight said, sounding a theme touched on by other members of the church hierarchy opening the two-day conference. The church's ``prophet, seer and revelator,'' former U.S. agriculture secretary Ezra Taft Benson, is feeble and, for the second straight conference, did not address the gathering. The 90-year-old Mormon president attended the morning and afternoon conference sessions, however, helped to and from his chair by his two counselors in the First Presidency, Gordon B. Hinckley and Thomas S. Monson. Monson opened the conference with a brief message in Benson's behalf, saying Mormons have ``a responsibility to extend help as well as hope to the hungry, to the homeless and to the downtrodden both at home and abroad.'' Elder Hans B. Ringger urged church members, who sometimes are seen by their neighbors as standoffish, to move beyond their own social and cultural circles. ``The needy are all around us. Too often, however, we are blind to those needs or fear those people whose company makes us feel uncomfortable,'' Ringger said. ``We have to rid ourselves of religious, racial or social prejudices and expand the boundaries of our service.''

DOC.HEAD: Mugabe Wins in Zimbabwe Vote, But Opposition Gains Seats
DOC.TEXT: President Robert Mugabe failed to realize his dream of a one-party state when three opposition members captured seats in parliamentary elections, according to partial returns Saturday. ``It's a bitter blow,'' said a spokesman for Mugabe's governing Marxist-Leninist Zimbabwe African National Union. ``Yet it could have been worse.'' Officials said 80 of 120 contested seats for the 150-member parliament had been counted at the end of the day, and final results were expected to be announced Sunday. However, Mugabe clearly emerged as the presidential victor. His first challenger ever, Edgar Tekere, gained only 365,149 votes, or 17.3 percent, with returns counted in 106 districts. Tekere's fledgling opposition party, campaigning for similar political reforms to those in Eastern Europe, captured more votes than most analysts expected. In the voting, held Wednesday through Friday, Tekere's Zimbabwe Unity Movement won a third of the ballots, capturing two parliamentary seats, according to election officials. The candidate of the Zimbabwe African National Union, or Ndonga, gained a third seat. The union represents the founder of the governing party, the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole. A Methodist minister, Sithole has been living in exile in the United States for several years, accused by security agents at home of plotting to topple Mugabe's government. Tekere and an independent businessman represent the only oppositon in the current body. Mugabe, 66, led the white-ruled British colony of Rhodesia to independence as black-governed Zimbabwe after a seven-year guerrilla war. But he has repeatedly said he wants a Marxist one-party system in what is now one of Africa's few democracies, arguing that feuds between rival movements in the infancy of independence hamper development. Tekere, 52, was a ounder of Mugabe's party in 1963 when its aim was to end 90 years of white minority rule. The past two years, however, he has argued against a one-party state. Tekere was fired from the governing party in 1988 after accusing politicians of widespread corruption. Tekere, pointing to Eastern Europe, has contended that Zimbabwe should broaden democracy and liberalize its economy. During the bitter campaign, Mugabe accused Tekere of plotting a coup if he lost the election. Tekere claimed Mugabe was bent on establishing a Marxist dictatorship. A weakness for Tekere is that many Zimbabweans remember that shortly after independence he was acquitted, on a legal technicality, of murdering an elderly white farmer. A Western African diplomat said the parliamentary districts held by the opposition in the past ``were always marginal seats'' that did not present a real challenge to the governing party. ``Mugabe's going to win, but he might find himself with an opposition,'' the diplomat said on condition of anonymity. During the campaign, Mugabe told voters his administration had provided cheap health care and education. Fewer than half of the 4.8 million registered voters bothered to go to the polls, even though they were extended from two days to three.

DOC.HEAD: Contras Preparing for War, Sandinista Paper Says
DOC.TEXT: The Sandinista party newspaper said Saturday that at least 1,000 armed Contra rebels have slipped back into Nicaragua from Honduras, and it claimed they were preparing to wage full-scale war. The military said nine Contras had been killed and 13 government soldiers wounded in a series of new clashes. Contra representatives signed an agreement with Nicaragua's incoming government to disband by April 20, five days before the new administration of the United National Opposition takes over from the leftist Sandinistas. Despite that March 23 pact, rebel leaders have said their forces were taking their weapons as they moved from jungle camps in neighboring Honduras back into Nicaragua. Contra leaders said last week that nearly all 12,000 of the rebels in the camps had returned home. In its report Saturday, the Sandinista newspaper Barricada said at least 1,000 Contras have moved back to Jinotega province, a border area 120 miles north of Managua. Quoting an unidentified high Sandinista military leader, Barricada said ``all indications are that (the Contras) are preparing for an offensive.'' The rebels are ``united and ready to develop a conventional war, with sufficient munitions and supplies for two months,'' the newspaper said. The Defense Ministry said the Contras attacked a Sandinista military post Thursday night in Jinotega province, killing five rebels and wounding five government soldiers. In other clashes, the Defense Ministry said four rebels died and eight government soldiers were wounded in two Contra attacks in northern Nicaragua. It gave no details. Barricada said the Contras have been demanding food from peasants, stealing cattle and attacking civilians. Contra rebels interviewed by The Associated Press earlier in the week said they would not turn over their arms until they are convinced the government of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is in control of the nation's security forces. She defeated Sandinista President Daniel Ortega in Feb. 25 elections. The demobilization agreement calls for the rebels to be repatriated to ``safety zones'' in Nicaragua that will be supervised by international observers. No dates have been set for disarming. The Contras have waged war against the Sandinistas, claiming they betrayed the goals of the 1979 revolution that toppled the Somoza family dynasty. Also Saturday, the National Assembly, still controlled by the Sandinistas, passed a law protecting property titles to land owned by 120,000 peasant farmers. Under the new law, the owners will be able to sell the land if they choose. Officials for the incoming government have said they plan to return some confiscated land to the people who owned it prior to 1979.

DOC.HEAD: State Appeals Stay Of Execution To U.S. Supreme Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with state officials saying U.S. Supreme Court agreed to consider appeal of stay of execution, quotes from attorney general's news conference. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `The U.S. Supreme...
DOC.TEXT: Officials fighting to carry out California's first execution in 23 years said Saturday the U.S. Supreme Court had agreed to consider an appeal of a ruling blocking the death sentence. The high court will take up the case of convicted double murderer Robert Alton Harris on Monday, said state Attorney General John Van de Kamp. After years of appeals, Harris, 37, was scheduled to die in the gas chamber Tuesday for the kidnapping and murders of two San Diego teen-agers in July 1978. But a federal appeals court on Friday stayed the execution. Judge John Noonan of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that a lower court improperly refused to hold a fact-finding hearing on Harris' claim he didn't get adequate psychiatric evaluation at the time of his original trial in 1979. The state immediately appealed the ruling. ``If Robert Harris had been deprived of his constitutional rights in some way ... then I would agree that further delay would be fair and reasonable,'' Van de Kamp told a news conference Saturday. ``But Harris has received a fair trial and the most painstaking federal review.'' ``The Supreme Court has told us that they will take the case,'' Van de Kamp added. A spokesman for the high court confirmed the appeal had been filed but declined to comment on whether or when the justices would consider it. ``There is no legal or moral reason why the execution ... should not proceed as scheduled,'' state Van de Kamp said in the emergency appeal. Van de Kamp wrote that Harris' ``last-ditch, strained attempt to attack the competency of his trial psychiatrists 11 years after the fact ... demonstrates unjustified delay and an unconscionable abuse'' of the appeals process.'' The U.S. Supreme Court has turned down four of Harris' earlier appeals and never ruled in his favor. Harris' arguments about inadequate psychiatric evaluation were rejected Wednesday by a U.S. District Court in San Diego. If the appeals court decision Friday were allowed to stand, the case would go to a three-judge appeals court panel. That panel would decide if the federal court in San Diego should be ordered to hold an evidentiary hearing on the defense contention on psychiatric evaluation. Harris was convicted of kidnapping John Mayeski and Michael Baker, both 16, from a fast food restaurant and shooting them to death so could use their car in a bank robbery. Noonan's ruling angered and saddened the families of the victims. ``Where the hell is justice, quick and swift?'' said Bill Stalder, the uncle of John Mayeski. ``This is tomfoolery. It's playing a game, and it's shouldn't be. It's disgusting.'' But death penalty opponents, some of whom have been fasting and taking part in a vigil outside the gates of San Quentin prison, were heartened. ``I'm glad that there is one good mind, heart and soul within the 9th Circuit Court that said we need to think about this a little more before we execute a human being in the state of California,'' said Stephen Souza, a member of Amnesty International and Death Penalty Focus. ``Surely we can think of something other than killing somebody'' for his crimes, said singer Joan Baez shortly before 300 death penalty foes marched across the Golden Gate Bridge Saturday morning.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Says She's Not Retiring
With AM-Tax Protest
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher quashed speculation she might retire and told cheering supporters of her Conservative Party Saturday that she still has ``the stomach'' for the fight ahead. Despite a dramatic slump in popularity and the prospect of a battle to succeed her, Mrs. Thatcher announced there was ``no vacancy'' at 10 Downing St., the prime minister's official residence in London. She spoke at a Conservative Central Council meeting in the Gloucestershire town of Cheltenham about 100 miles northwest of London. Protesters angry over a new local tax championed by the Conservatives tore through central London Saturday afternoon, hurling rocks at police, looting stores and terrifying tourists and local residents alike. More than 130 people were injured. Mrs. Thatcher's speech came three days after the Conservatives' former chairman, Norman Tebbit, announced he would run for the leadership post if Mrs. Thatcher quit before the next election. The vote must be held by mid-1992. Right-winger Tebbit's surprise announcement raised the possibility of a leadership battle with former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine. He represents the party's center-left, and he is the front-runner in opinion polls to succeed the prime minister. But on Saturday, Mrs. Thatcher made it clear she planned to lead the Conservatives into the next election. ``To avoid any possible misunderstanding and at the risk of disappointing a few gallant colonels, let me make one thing absolutely clear: I haven't come to Cheltenham to retire,'' she said. ``You may have noticed that I seem lately to have been subjected to a certain amount of criticism _ not by the way for the first time, nor I dare say for the last,'' she said. Criticism is ``one of the perks'' of the job, she said. She told the party faithful to keep fighting to win ``a shining future'' and assured them she was prepared to lead the battle. ``I have the stomach for that fight. So do you _ and so I believe does Britain.'' Mrs. Thatcher's popularity has been eroded by rising inflation, high mortgage rates and the new local tax being imposed across the country. The opposition Labor Party had a record 28-point lead over the Tories in the latest Harris poll last weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Blockade of Indian Land Remains After Helicopter Shooting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with police saying negotiations will resume Sunday on allowing investigators onto Indian land; pick up 8th graf pvs, `People aboard...' SUBS grafs 15-17 to CORRECT spelling to Alford sted Alfrod.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XLPD1
DOC.TEXT: State police tried to negotiate their way onto a Mohawk Indian settlement where they believe shots were fired at a military helicopter, but Indian leaders insisted Saturday no outsiders would set foot on their land. Both sides patrolled blockades on the four roads leading into the Ganienkeh Mohawk Territory near the Canadian border. State police set up the roadblocks Friday after a Vermont National Guard helicopter on an emergency medical flight was hit by three bullets, forcing it to land in a field on Indian land. A civilian doctor suffered a gunshot wound in the right arm, and was listed in good condition. Authorities failed Saturday to persuade Indian leaders to allow state troopers onto Indian territory to investigate the attack. But both sides agreed to resume talks Sunday morning, said state police Maj. Robert Leu. ``I don't think this will be long and drawn out,'' said Leu. ``We are very close to what we want to achieve, which is to complete our investigation in the next couple of days.'' Police have yet to identify a suspect. The Ganienkeh Indians, like other Mohawks in northern New York, claim their land is sovereign territory and that federal or state authorities lack jurisdiction there. Busloads of people normally travel on weekends to the territory to play high-stakes bingo, but the games were canceled this weekend. The helicopter was flying at about 200 feet when it was fired on at noon Friday, said state trooper Richard Garcia. Dr. James Van Kirk, 27, was recovering Saturday at Vermont Medical Center in Burlington, where he works. People aboard the chopper told authorities they believed the shots came from the sparsely populated 700-acre Indian territory, but police aren't yet certain that was the case, Garcia said. ``The determination is not clear yet,'' Garcia said. Daryl Martin, a spokesman for the Indians, insisted the shots did not come from the encampment. Three military crew members and a civilian doctor and nurse were aboard the UH-1 chopper, which because of weather had aborted a mission to pick up a patient. The Mohawk roadblocks were set up beside police blockades to keep authorities from coming onto the settlement, he said, adding, ``as long as their roadblocks stay up, we're going to keep ours up.'' A meeting Friday night between state police and Mohawk leaders ``turned out to be a total farce,'' Martin said. ``They just seem to be very hard-line, very hard-nosed and insistent on violating our treaty rights,'' he said. ``We're afraid of any type of invasion.'' In Albany, FBI agent Wayne Alford said top priority was being given to investigating ``the attempted murder of those on board the aircraft.'' Any federal violations would be secondary to the state police investigation of those charges, he said. FBI agents were at the scene but were not involved in the negotiations, he said. ``The state police will do everything they can to resolve this peacefully,'' Alford said. ``If it takes a long time to do that, then we'll take a long time.'' Indian leaders have been talking informally with state police at the roadblocks, but some meetings have ``turned into yelling matches,'' Martin said. The Indians made a few concessions Saturday. The allowed state police to fly a helicopter over the area where the shooting occurred, Martin said. The also admitted a crew to work on the crippled craft, and said they would allow it to be flown away once repairs were finished, Garcia said. Gov. Mario Cuomo said Saturday that ``people in the (Altona) area have resisted Ganienkeh'' _ a suggestion that someone outside the encampment may have fired the shots to discredit the Mohawks. When Cuomo was New York's secretary of state in 1977, he helped negotiate an end to a three-year occupation by Mohawks of land at Moss Lake, about 100 miles southwest of Altona. That agreement led to the creation of the Ganienkeh encampment, where about 40 Mohawks live on 700 acres. The Mohawks claimed the camp was among 9 million acres in New York and Vermont wrongfully taken from them in the 18th century. Fifteen years ago, a 22-year-old man and a 9-year-old girl were shot and wounded while riding in cars near another Ganienkeh encampment, and the Indians also refused to cooperate. No one was ever charged. The Mohawks at Ganienkeh, which means ``land of the flint,'' say they are trying to protect ancient Mohawk traditions and culture by living in a community that does not accept aid from federal, state or county governments. Whites are not allowed onto the core of the settlement, though Ganienkeh spokesmen said the bingo hall was opened in 1988 as a means of raising money to build roads, a clinic and make other community improvements. Mohawks have ignored restraining orders secured by New York state authorities to close the 1,400-seat bingo hall. One leader said Ganienkeh residents will defend their encampment. ``If they are attacked or invaded, they will readily stand up to the defense of their territory,'' said Kakwirakeron. ``They do not allow New York state to exercise any jurisdiction whatsoever within their territory.'' Kakwirakeron, also known as Art Montour, is on trial in federal court in Syracuse on a charge of impeding FBI agents and New York State Police during a 1989 casino raid on the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation along the New York-Canadian border.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Riot During Tax Protest in Central London
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD that rioting was worst violence in Britain since 1985, SUB 2nd graf pvs and ADD 2 grafs at end; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON8
DOC.TEXT: An anti-tax demonstration by 40,000 people turned into a riot Saturday when militants pelted police with rocks and bottles, set fires to cars and smashed shop windows in a rampage through central London. It was the worst violence in Britain since 1985. At least 341 people were arrested, 58 police were hurt and at least 75 civilians were taken to hospitals, police said. Many of the injured were released after treatment. The worst of the trouble was over four hours after it began, but sporadic vandalism and looting continued into the night. Some areas of the West End shopping and theater district looked like battlegrounds, and sirens and burglar alarms of vandalized stores blared up and down the streets. For most of the afternoon protesters waved their placards peacefully in marches and at a rally in Trafalgar Square, denouncing the unpopular new so-called poll tax, which takes effect Sunday. It will be levied by local governments on every adult in a household and replaces a single household tax based on property values. Under the new system, a duke in a 100-room mansion will pay as much as a street sweeper in a cottage if they live in the same borough. The tax has aroused anger throughout Britain and generated widespread hostility toward Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. But she said Saturday she had no intention of retiring and that she still had ``the stomach'' for the fight ahead. Clashes with police, on foot and horseback, began at about 3 p.m. near Mrs. Thatcher's residence on Downing Street, off Whitehall, one of half a dozen streets that lead off Trafalgar Square. The large plaza is in the heart of London, near Parliament, the Thames River and the theater district. Mrs. Thatcher was not at Downing Street. The trouble started when a breakaway group of several hundred militants began a protest on Whitehall, south of the square. Police in riot gear joined 40 mounted officers to stem the violence, but at least one officer was knocked unconscious as protesters hit police lines with rocks from a nearby building site. Other police officers and people in the crowd were hurt. Police on horseback sealed off Whitehall so it could not be entered from the square, and demonstration organizers appealed to thousands of people watching the tense situation to disperse via the other side of the square. They refused, however, and continued to chant and wave anti-poll tax banners. As the trouble grew, a fire broke out at a seven-story building on Trafalgar Square, and police and a witness said it apparently was started by a protester. Smoke poured out above the building, undergoing reconstruction, before firefighters put it out at about 7:30 p.m. A group of about 60 young men ran along Regent Street, north of the square, hurling trash cans and newspaper racks through the windows of shops and arcades. Shop employees reported looting. Other rioters moved along St. Martin's Lane, which leads north from the square, overturning cars near the English National Opera, burning several and breaking windows of restaurants and shops. On Charing Cross Road, which also leads north out of the square, more cars were overturned and set afire, and big garbage containers outside restaurants were pushed over, spilling the contents into the street. The trouble continued north to Leicester Square, the film, entertainment and theater center of the city _ the busiest place in London on a Saturday evening. Subway stations in the area were closed. At Trafalgar Square, mounted police, pelted with rocks and bottles, moved in to try to clear out demonstrators. At one point about 1,000 protesters, chanting ``no poll tax!'' gathered in front of The National Gallery on the north side, surrounded by mounted police in riot gear and police on foot. ``The police tried to crush us from both sides from Whitehall. People were in a panic. There were young children there and old people, but the horses were stepping on anybody,'' said a student who gave only her first name, Lara. But Iain McCallum of Surrey said: ``There is no doubt that the police were being provoked. There were guys throwing bottles and cans at them, shouting abuse. They just wanted to cause trouble.'' When police forced the demonstrators out of the square by its northwest exit, the mob surged up Haymarket, kicking in shop windows. A McDonald's was badly damaged. Theatergoers and tourists ran for cover as the mob used anything they could to smash windows. David Meynell, police deputy assistant commisioner at Scotland Yard, said the march by 40,000 was ``completely overshadowed'' by the violent actions of about 3,000 to 3,500 militants. He said he couldn't name the groups but that there were black flags flying, which indicated anarchists among the crowd. Legislator George Galloway of the socialist opposition Labor Party, sitting sadly at the base of Nelson's Column in Trafalgar Square, condemned the violence. ``To see sections of the crowd cheering on the rioters. It shows the depth of hatred of this poll tax, and the extent of the alienation in the country, and that disturbs me,'' said Galloway, whose party opposes the tax. He said police actions were clearly retaliatory and frankly necessary to save their own lives.'' ``It was a well-organized demonstration, but these lunatics, anarchists and other extremists, principally from the Socialist Workers' Party, were out for a rumble the whole time, and now they've got it, and if they didn't exist, the Tories would need to invent them.'' The Socialist Workers' Party denied it was responsible for the violence and blamed police. Mrs. Thatcher Saturday told cheering supporters in Cheltenham, about 100 miles northwest of London, that she had no intention of retiring despite growing criticism and her dramatic slump in popularity. She told the Conservative Party faithful to keep fighting to win ``a shining future'' and said she was prepared to lead the battle. ``I have the stomach for that fight. So do you _ and so I believe does Britain.'' Mrs. Thatcher's 11-year premiership has seen severe rioting, mostly by young blacks protesting at unemployment, alleged discrimination and police raids on drinking clubs and suspected drug users. Saturday's London violence was the worst since September 1985, when crowds of young blacks and some whites clashed with police in the northern industrial city of Birmingham. Two Ugandan-born brothers died there when their post office was burnt out.

DOC.HEAD: Bodies of 50 Victims Returned to Honduras
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Honduran president's plans to meet plane Sunday morning. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Police said...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SJ1, TEG1
With AM-Honduran Dreams, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of 50 of the 87 people killed in a fire at an illegal Bronx social club were loaded onto a cargo plane at Kennedy Airport on Saturday for a late-night flight to Honduras, a nation in mourning. At a brief memorial service in the huge hangar to which the caskets had come, some in hearses, others stacked on flatbed trucks, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch said New York City would ``do all possible to make sure this will never happen again.'' ``These young people came to this great city of ours seeking hope and opportunity, and now they leave like this,'' Lynch said, gesturing toward the long row of caskets. ``The bodies lying here before us say we've got to do more. We've got to do more to make sure this doesn't happen again.'' Honduran President Rafael Leonardo Callejas planned to head a government delegation receiving the bodies when the plane arrived Sunday morning. After an airport Mass, Honduran air force planes and helicopters will take the remains to 12 locations in the country, said Nahum Valladares, Honduran information minister. In New York, police continued their crackdown on the hundreds of unlicensed social clubs, or bars, which dot the city's poorer neighborhoods. Police said they visited 261 locations late Friday and early Saturday and found only 65 clubs open. They issued 29 orders to vacate the premises, 57 summonses and 80 violation notices. On Thursday night, they visited 89 club sites and found 74 closed. Most club operators closed down before they were shut down, according to a neighborhood liquor store owner who has supplied liquor to social clubs. He spoke to The Associated Press on the condition of anonymity. The retailer said that by Friday afternoon he had not heard from any of the clubs that normally contact him during the day to place orders. Because they are not licensed, social clubs cannot obtain liquor from wholesalers and must buy from retailers. Such sales often violate state rules limiting the amount of liquor any one person can buy retail at one time. Their defenders say the clubs fill a need. Julio Medina, who was at a Brooklyn club that was raided Thursday night, admitted that the Bronx fire had worried him. ``But this is all there is,'' he said. ``People cannot afford anything else.'' A Bronx grand jury has charged Julio Gonzalez with murder for allegedly etting the fire that devastated the Happy Land club a week ago. Police say Gonzalez, enraged by a former girlfriend's rejection, spilled a dollar's worth of gasoline in the entrance to the club and set it ablaze. Conviction on a murder charge carries a maximum penalty of 25 years to life. Gonzalez is being held in Bellevue Hospital, in isolation and under 24-hour watch. The former girlfriend, an employee at the club, was one of the few to escape. Six victims were buried Friday at St. Raymond's Cemetery in the Bronx, and dozens of mourners attended a wake Friday evening for three others. Other funerals were held Saturday before the airlift to Honduras. The DC-8 scheduled to take the 50 bodies to Honduras was chartered by the American Red Cross. Ed Hardy, a Red Cross spokesman, said about 100 relatives of fire victims also were being flown to Honduras at Red Cross expense on regular commercial flights. Hardy said an exact time for the cargo plane to leave Kennedy had not been set. The flight takes about five hours, and the plane was not slated to reach Honduras until after dawn Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: West German Bank Pitches 2-1 Rate for East German Marks
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's central bank Saturday recommended a 2-to-1 conversion rate for East German currency as part of a plan to form an economic union between the two states. However, some members of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's governing coalition immediately attacked the proposal, and heavy criticism was reported in East Germany as well. Critics said a 2-1 rate _ exchanging two East German marks for every one West German mark _ would erode the life savings of elderly East Germans and deny workers a chance to earn decent wages. A 2-to-1 rate would mean that the salaries of East German workers would be sliced in half. Bundesbank chairman Karl Otto Poehl announced the proposal in Galway, Ireland, where he was attending a meeting of Economic Community finance ministers. He told reporters he had outlined the plan in a letter to Kohl on Thursday. The monetary union is considered a crucial early step in the move toward German reunification. Some officials have predicted an economic merger by the summer. The central bank proposal made an exception for small savers, however. It specifies that East German accounts up to 2,000 marks per person, the equivalent of about $1,175, should be converted at a 1-1 rate. The concession was made because of promises by Kohl during the March 18 election campaign in East Germany, Poehl said. Poehl argued that a 1-2 rate would in fact raise the value of the East German mark, which currently is exchanged at the official East German rate of one West mark for three East marks. However, the currency is officially non-convertible and in reality has little value outside the East bloc. There had been speculation that too favorable a rate would fuel West German inflation. But Poehl predicted that East Germans, even with West German marks, would be moderate in buying consumer goods. West German Finance Theodor Waigel, who attended the meeting in Ireland, said he agreed with the Bundesbank proposal. Kohl was asked about it while attending a meeting of his Christian Democratic Union in Neuss, near Duesseldorf. He said only that he ``did not want to add to speculation'' about the exchange rate. But the party's Social Committee chief, Ulf Fink, predicted that limiting the 1-1 exhange rate to 2,000 marks would cause a new exodus of East Germans to West Germany. ``Another exodus would be more costly than a general 1-1 rate for all savings,'' he was quoted by the Neue Osnabruecker Zeitung newspaper as saying. The flood of thousands of East Germans westward played a big part in prompting reforms that ended Communist rule in East Germany. However, it put tremendous strains on West Germany. East Germany's economy is a shambles, and experts have predicted that billions of dollars must be invested annually for the next five to 10 years to modernize its industry, transportation and other areas of the country's infrastructure. West Germany's economy, based on a free-market system, is the most powerful in the 12-nation European Community. Many of the West European currencies are closely tied to its mark. In East Berlin, the official news agency ADN said Saturday that news of the central bank proposal had generated numerous complaint calls to the Christian Democratic Union, the West German union's sister party that won the March parliamentary elections. The party campaigned for a quick monetary union to shore up East Germany's economy. However, those calling the party offices Saturday said they felt ``cheated'' after voting for the party on expectations of a 1-1 exchange rate under monetary union, ADN said. In Bonn, Otto Lambsdorff, chairman of the junior governing coalition partner, the Free Democratic Party, said that accepting the Bundesbank proposal would be like ``breaking a promise'' made to the East Germans. In an interview with the weekly Welt am Sonntag newspaper in Bonn, Lambsdorff said that because of very low retirement pay in East Germany, most elderly people there relied heavily on savings accumulated over the years. Lambsdorff was quoted by the newspaper as saying he also rejected an overall 1-1 exchange rate. However, he acknowledged that the Free Democrats and the Christian Democratic Union favored that rate for most savings during the East German election campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Damaged Pipe Spills Fuel Into Allegheny River, Threatens Water Supplies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: EDITS throughout to UPDATE with more than 100,000 affected, water intake in Oakmont closed, other details; ADD details on landslide and cleanup; CORRECT that people advised not to drink tap water in Freeport, sted other cities. No pickup. CORRECTS byline to `Bair,' sted `Blair.'
DOC.TEXT: A landslide-damaged petroleum pipeline sent an 8-mile-long slick down the Allegheny River on Saturday, threatening water supplies for more than 100,000 people, authorities said. Fumes from the spill forced the evacuation of 100 people. Heavy rain Friday apparently caused the landslide that cracked the pipeline the same day, said Ray Haase Jr. of Buckeye Pipeline Co. About 75,000 gallons of a 50-50 mixture of diesel and heating oil leaked into Knapp Run Creek, then flowed into the Allegheny about five miles north of Freeport, said Haase. The creek joins the Allegheny about 30 miles north of Pittsburgh. Monitors at Buckeye Pipeline's Allentown headquarters detected the leak around 11 p.m. Friday when they noticed a loss of pressure in the 10-inch-wide pipe, which runs from Linden, N.J., to the Pittsburgh suburb of Coraopolis, Haase said. They cut off the flow of fuel about 20 minutes later. It was unknown what time the leak began, Haase said. ``There may have been delays,'' he told an afternoon news conference. ``It's not always an instantaneous decision to shut a valve when the pressure drops.'' Water intakes in Freeport were closed and residents were advised not to drink tap water, said state Department of Environmental Resources spokeswoman Betsy Mallison. Three tanker trucks brought potable water to the city of 3,000 people Saturday night. Water intake valves also were closed in South Buffalo Township, Harrison Township, Brackenridge, New Kensington, Tarentum and Oakmont. The 101,360 customers in those communities were being advised to conserve water, Ms. Mallison said. ``I wouldn't do my laundry today,'' she said. A few miles southwest of Oakmont, the Pittsburgh Water Department planned to close its intakes early Sunday and rely on reserves for water for its 500,000 customers, said spokeswoman Donna Sagmeister. She said the intakes could be reopened as early as Sunday night, and said no conservation order would be issued. ``It's not as serious as it could have been,'' she said, explaining that the fuel would have to pass over three locks and dams before reaching the city treatment plant. ``That mixes it up.'' Thirty people from two cleanup companies hired by Buckeye began cleaning up the spill at 4 a.m. Saturday, state police said. They set up booms along the Allegheny, where an oily film covered the shore at Freeport on Saturday night. Crews on docks in the city used absorbent pads to collect fuel, but workers at the creek were hindered by mud from the landslide, Haase said. ``It's a nightmare up there,'' he said. ``There's about 200 yards of road gone. The landslide area is so unstable and saturated with oil, it's not physically possible for anyone to get in there.'' Fumes from the pads during the afternoon forced the evacuation of about 100 residents of a riverside apartment building for the elderly in Freeport to a nearby elementary school, Mayor Bob Ravotti said. At a news conference, state Fish Commission officer Jerry Greiner displayed minnows and crayfish killed in the creek, a popular fishing spot. Conservation officers were counting dead fish and trying to determine if birds were affected, Greiner said.

DOC.HEAD: President Callejas To Receive Bodies Of Burning Victims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with plane loaded in New York; UPDATES with 50 bodies sted 42 as expected earlier; CORRECTS that relatives taking other flights; ADDS detail; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Rafael Leonardo Callejas will head a government delegation receiving the bodies of Hondurans killed in a New York City social club fire, the government said Saturday. The bodies of 50 of the 87 people killed in the fire were loaded onto a cargo plane in New York on Saturday for the midnight flight to Honduras. The government said the bodies were to arrive Sunday morning in San Pedro Sula, 120 miles north of Tegucigalpa. It has said 79 of the people who died in last Sunday's fire at the Happy Land social club were Hondurans. On Friday, Julio Gonzalez was indicted by a New York state grand jury on 178 counts of murder, arson and other charges connected with fire. Gonzalez, a 36-year-old Cuban immigrant, spilled gasoline in the entrance of the illegal club and torched it after being rejected by a girlfriend employed there, authorities said. Nahum Valladares, Honduran information minister, said in a telephone interview that the bodies returned to Honduras will be transported on a DC-8. The plane was chartered by the American Red Cross. Ed Hardy, a Red Cross spokesman, said about 100 relatives of fire victims also were flown to Honduras at Red Cross expense on regular commercial flights. None was aboard the cargo plane, and none attended a memorial service at the airport in New York. The Honduran official said New York officials had also helped arrange the special flight. ``The government this week has held intense conversations with New York officials, who offered their facilities to repatriate the dead and their families,'' Valladares said. Monsignor Jaime Brufau, the Roman Catholic archbishop of San Pedro Sula, will officiate a Mass at the airport, and Callejas and his Cabinet will attend, officials said. Valladares said Honduran air force planes and helicopters will take the remains to 12 locations in Honduras. He said the bodies of some other victims would be brought back to Honduras through private arrangements by their families. Six victims were been buried in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Infant Found, Mother of Two Arrested
DOC.TEXT: A woman who recently suffered a miscarriage killed a woman who'd just given birth and kidnapped her baby, authorities alleged Saturday after arresting the woman and recovering the infant. Betty Kirk, the 35-year-old mother of two pre-teens, pretended the 10-day-old baby was her own, said Lee County Sheriff's Capt. David Bonsall. Kirk was held without bond at the county jail in Fort Myers on a charge of first-degree murder. The baby was taken to Lee Memorial Hospital. Her head had been shaved, but she was healthy. The heavy-set Kirk had told friends she was pregnant, but apparently suffered a miscarriage two months ago, authorities said. On Thursday, Sharon Parker, 33, was found dead in her Lehigh Acres home by three of her four children when they returned from school, sheriff's investigators said. Ten-day-old Julie Lynn Parker was gone. Mrs. Parker, a casual acquaintaince of Kirk, had been shot once in the back of the head, said Bonsall. Bonsall said it appeared that Kirk killed Mrs. Parker ``and the only inference is that she wanted the child.'' Kirk ``said she had given birth that morning, then showed her family and other people the baby as being hers,'' Bonsall said. Friends found it odd she claimed to have given birth the day of the slaying and abduction, then suddenly produced a baby who, although small, didn't appear to be a newborn, said sheriff's spokeswoman Sheri Peterson. Deputies found the infant at Kirk's North Fort Myers home late Friday, along with baby clothes and other personal items belonging to the Parkers, Bonsall said. Authorities had launched a ground and air search earlier in the day for the baby.

DOC.HEAD: Humane Center Fire Kills 74 Animals
DOC.TEXT: A fire at the Western Pennsylvania Humane Society on Saturday killed 74 cats and dogs, authorities said. The fire began about 7 a.m. in the 1{-story brick building on the city's North Side. Fire Chief Charles Dickinson said 35 cats and 39 dogs died, probably from smoke and shock. Damage to the building was estimated at $250,000. The cause wasn't immediately determined.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with Szladits. Separate on Watts moved as a0557.
DOC.TEXT: Lola L. Szladits, curator of the New York Public Library's Berg Collection of English and American Literature for 20 years, died Friday of cancer. She was 67. As curator, Szladits scoured England to bargain for diaries and first editions and beseeched American authors to think first of the Berg Collection when parting with their papers. A show on diarists Szladits mounted last year included 50 of her famous authors like James Boswell, Elizabeth Barrett Browning and Herman Melville. Szladits considered the Berg a working collection used by biographers from around the world, and expanded it to include original manuscripts ranging from W.B. Yeats to S.J. Perelman and Saul Bellow. Among her most significant acquisitions were Auden's handwritten notebooks. ``I am buying in eternity,'' she once said.
DOC.HEAD: Helen Watts
DOC.TEXT: Helen Hoke Watts, the author and publisher of children's books, died of pneumonia Monday at age 86. Mrs. Watts' works included ``The Horse That Took the Milk Around'' and ``Too Many Kittens,'' and the series ``Witches, Witches, Witches,'' ``Jokes, Jokes, Jokes'' and ``Nurses, Nurses, Nurses.'' She wrote a number of anthologies reflecting her interest in ghost stories, the supernatural and witchcraft. In addition to writing, she managed children's books departments for New York publishers. She served as vice president and director of international projects for Franklin Watts Inc. publishers, a company formed by her second husband.

DOC.HEAD: Four Crew Members Unhurt After Freighter Sinks
DOC.TEXT: A 118-foot wooden-hulled Haitian freighter sank in the Atlantic after its bow split open Saturday morning, and four crew members spent six hours in a life raft before they were rescued, the Coast Guard said. The freighter Artibonite sank about 12 miles southeast of Fowey Rocks, which are near the southern tip of Key Biscayne, at about 10 a.m., according to Petty Officer Luis Diaz. The captain and owner, Charles Coreus of Haiti, along with another Haitian and two Nicaraguan crew members, escaped in a lifeboat and suffered only bumps and bruises when the Coast Guard cutter Manatu picked them up at about 4 p.m., Diaz said. Diaz wasn't sure if the ship was coming or going from docks along the Miami River.

DOC.HEAD: Executed Journalist is Buried
DOC.TEXT: A British journalist executed in Iraq for alleged spying was buried Saturday in London. Iranian-born Farzad Bazoft was hanged March 15 in Baghdad. The 32-year-old had lived in London and worked for the London weekly The Observer. The Iraqi government said he spied for Israel after he visited a military site where an explosion took place in 1989. Iraqi leaders ignored international pleas for a reprieve. His body was returned to Britain. His brother, Afshan Bazoft, told mourners at the funeral Saturday: ``Remember him as a happy man. Let him rest in peace.'' The mourners at Highgate Cemetery included Donald Trelford, editor of The Observer. He has said Bazoft was not a spy but simply a journalist doing his job. The burial followed an Islamic service at London's Central Mosque in Regent's Park.

DOC.HEAD: 2,000 Students, Angered Over Fee Hikes, March on Legislature
DOC.TEXT: About 2,000 Laval University students, angered by steep tuition hikes, marched on the provincial legislature Friday and tried to force their way into the building before being rebuffed by Quebec riot police. Two students were arrested after they struck officers over the head with their placards following protests over the proposed hike in tuition beginning next September from an average of $540 a year to $890 per year. The hike, agreed to by the provincial government, would be the first in Quebec in 20 years. Quebec university fees are currently the lowest in Canada. The demonstration was the latest in a series that has seen students occupy the Montreal Exchange and interrupt a live newscast on the French service of the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. Besides the September increase, the following year university tuition in the province is slated to rise by about the same amount, making a total increase of about 140 percent. The students marched about three miles from Laval University on the outskirts of Quebec City to the downtown building, chanting ``We want Ryan,'' referring to Education Minister Claude Ryan. Several of the students broke through police lines and tried to enter the front doors of the legislative building. They were met by club-wielding riot-squad officers who forced them back and arrested the two. Later, the protesters threw snowballs at police before dispersing. About 215 students have so far been arrested at fee-hike protests, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Surprises Marines to Play Golf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 11th graf, bgng ``On the,'' to include later Bush comment on Gorbachev letter and apology for saying ``Oh, God.'' ^By DAVID BRISCOE
DOC.TEXT: President Bush dropped in unexpectedly on a Marine Corps officer-training class Friday and quickly assured his audience as it snapped to attention that he mainly wanted to play golf. No matter that it was cold and blustery out and had just stopped raining. The commander-in-chief briefly toured part of the base before leading a caravan of 11 golf carts that roamed over the base golf course. ``I'm not pretending this is anything other than R & R (rest and recuperation),'' the president joked to about 180 attendees of the Marine Corps Command and Staff College. ``I wanted to at least pop in.'' The audience, which included mid-level officers from the Marine Corps and other services, had jumped to attention when the president entered the room. He praised the military for its role in December's Panama invasion and said, ``We never have been blessed with finer students in all of our services than we are today.'' ``Keep it up; the country is grateful,'' Bush said. The Marine base at Quantico sprawls along the Potomac River about 30 miles south of the nation's capital. At one point, Bush, a World War II Navy torpedo-bomber pilot, referred to himself as ``an aging, somewhat out-of-touch naval aviator.'' Bush said that ``respect for our armed forces around the world has never been higher.'' On the golf course, Bush was asked by reporters if he had received a response to Thursday's letter to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on the Lithuanian controversy. Bush raised his golf club in the air and said, ``R & R.'' Later, on the 18th hole, he told reporters, ``What I said doesn't, I don't think requires any answer.'' After overshooting the 9th hole, Bush muttered, ``Oh, God,'' and then said to the other players, ``I'd like to apologize for using profanity on the last hole. I feel very badly about it and I don't know what came over me.'' Joining Bush for golf were his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft; his chief of staff, John Sununu; the Marine Corps commandant, Gen. Alfred M. Gray Jr., and the base commander, Lt. Gen. William Etnyre.

DOC.HEAD: American Loses Fight in England on College Cheating Charge
DOC.TEXT: American Francis Foecke on Friday lost his latest bid to clear his name in a four-year fight against charges that he cheated in his final student examination at Bristol University. But Foecke, 33, who comes originally from South Bend, Ind., said he intends to keep fighting. ``If they think they are going to get away with it, they've got it wrong,'' he said after the university's governing council rejected his appeal. Foecke, who pronounces his name Faykey, said he will consult his lawyers about taking the case to the Law Lords of the House of Lords, the highest court in the land. The American reportedly has spent close to $200,000 in legal fees and other costs contesting the university's refusal to give him a degree in mathematics and computer science. He lives with his British schoolteacher wife Priscilla at Clifton near the port city of Bristol, western England. ``I will never throw in the towel even if I have to carry on the battle for the rest of my life. I want my integrity back. They have not a shred of real proof against me,'' he said. ``The university has destroyed my whole life professionally. I want a huge amount of compensation as well as an apology and a degree.'' The university refused to give him the degree in 1986, saying he must have cheated. It said then that although he did first-class work in the examination, he had been a poor student up to that time. It said his answers in two exam papers bore a remarkable resemblance to the examiner's model answers, including some of the mistakes. University Secretary Michael Parry said the council met for two hours and resolved to dismiss Foecke's appeal after studying a 100-page report by an investigatory panel consisting of two professors. The panel spent 16 days this year hearing Foecke, lawyers, and staff at the university, which has 7,500 students. Foecke on Friday dismissed the panel's report as ``a load of garbage.'' ``There were similarities to some of the model solutions in my answers. That is because the university is too lazy to rewrite the exam papers. Sometimes the same questions crop up five years in a row,'' he told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Mother of Girl Rescued from Well Sues For Divorce
DOC.TEXT: The parents of Jessica McClure, the toddler rescued from an abandoned well in 1987, are getting a divorce, court records show. Reba ``Cissy'' McClure sued her husband, Lewis ``Chip'' McClure, for divorce earlier this month, according to papers filed in a Midland County civil court. The McClures could not be reached for comment Friday. A former publicist for the family, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the couple filed for a no-fault divorce. The publicist said he had no other details of the divorce filing, including the issue of custody of Jessica, who turned 4 on Monday. Jessica was 18 months old when she tumbled into an abandoned well in her aunt's backyard in October 1987. She was trapped 22 feet underground for nearly 59 hours while rescuers drilled a side tunnel through solid rock to reach her. Her ordeal drew international attention and her rescue was televised live by U.S. networks. A TV movie of the rescue aired last May.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Inflation Soars to Record 84 Percent in March
DOC.TEXT: Brazil's cost of living rose 84 percent in March, its highest monthly increase ever, the government said Friday. March inflation easily topped February's rate of 73 percent, according to the official Brazilian Geography and Statistics Institute. Inflation has increased 397 percent since January and 4,853 percent over the last 12 months, the institute reported. The March rate, calculated from mid-February to mid-March, reflected the wild surge in prices preceding the inauguration of President Fernando Collor de Mello, sworn in March 15 for a five-year term in this country of 150 million residents. Transportation and communications pushed up the cost of living more than any other item, jumping 94.83 percent during the 30-day period. Personal items soared 92.37 percent and food 84.15 percent, the institute reported. Collor, Brazil's first popularly elected leader since 1960, announced the country's fifth and most radical anti-inflation package a day after taking office. Price controls, a new currency, a de facto devaluation and a crackdown on financial speculators were included in the plan. But the backbone of the package _ a severe tightening of the money supply, hikes in taxes and utilities and a freeze on bank deposits that totaled $115 billion _ have prompted mass layoffs and fears of recession. Workers unions estimate more than 200,000 Brazilians have already lost their jobs. In Rio alone, 11,000 people have been laid off the last 13 days. Retailers have been offering easy credit and discounts as high as 80 percent to entice cash-strapped Brazilians to buy goods. Some clothing stores are selling merchandise by the pound, car dealers are bartering vehicules for rice and coffee and supermarkets are now accepting credit cards.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Army Chief Joins Cabinet in Controversial Move
DOC.TEXT: Retired army chief Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh became deputy prime minister and defense minister Friday in a controversial move that students and critics called a setback for Thai democracy. Chavalit took up the new posts under a command issued by the country's constitutional monarch, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, said state Radio Thailand, monitored in Bangkok. Chavalit retired Tuesday as army commander in chief. He was offered the Cabinet posts by Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan, who hopes Chavalit will help shore up a government destablized by allegations of corruption, inefficiency and labor disputes. Chatichai yielded his defense ministry portfolio to Chavalit, who also is now one of four deputy prime ministers. Radio Thailand said the deputy army chief, Gen. Suchinda Kraprayoon, is the new army chief while the armed forces chief of staff, Gen. Sunthorn Kongsompong, takes on the post of acting supreme commander. Thailand has a long tradition of generals dominating politics, but hopes for a new course were raised after Chatichai in August 1988 became the first prime minister in 12 years to also be an elected official. Chavalit's moves to join the Cabinet prompted the Students Federation of Thailand to renew calls for a constitutional amendment requiring all ministers to be elected members of the Parliament. Members of the federation staged a protest outside Government House Thursday, holding up banners that called Chavalit a ``destroyer of democratic culture'' and chastized him for ``jumping the queue'' to political power. The Thai media usually is timid in criticizing the military, but The Nation, an independent English-language newspaper, stated its views in a hard-hitting open letter to Chavalit published Thursday. It said: ``Many people are suspicious of your motives. Is this your short cut to political power? ... ``Your going straight into the government will imply that either a top army commander can always demand a seat of political power almost at will, or that an elected civilian government cannot survive without the support of the military, or both. Neither of these bodes well for the political future of Thailand.'' Chavalit was appointed army chief in 1986 when the then-prime minister, Prem Tinsulanonda, fired Gen. Arthit Kamlang-ek for publicly challenging the government.

DOC.HEAD: Target the Weak, Memo Told Lincoln Bond Sellers
With AM-American Continental
DOC.TEXT: Lincoln Savings & Loan workers selling ``junk bonds'' were told, ``Remember the weak, meek and ignorant are always good targets,'' according to papers in a court case over the thrift's collapse. The advice was contained in a company memo that was among stacks of paperwork filed Thursday by lawyers for holders of 23,000 uninsured bonds. The bondholders are suing to recover their estimated $200 million loss on the bonds, which are worthless because of the collapse of Lincoln Savings & Loan Association and its parent company, American Continental Corp. The failure of the Irvine-based S&L is expected to cost U.S. taxpayers $2.5 billion. American Continental filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code last April 13, and the government seized Lincoln the next day. Lawyers for the investors argued Thursday that seven civil lawsuits stemming from the bond sale should be consolidated. County Superior Court Judge David G. Sills didn't say when he would rule on the request for class-action certification. Many of the investors were elderly people who lost their life savings. They contend they were steered into buying the uninsured bonds by Lincoln and American Continental employees who led them to believe the securities were as safe as a federally insured savings account. The memo, headlined ``Capitalize on This,'' was attached as an exhibit to the paperwork arguing that the lawsuits should be combined. It was unsigned. In addition to the advice about the ``weak, meek and ignorant,'' which was the last item listed, the memo also outlined other ways employees were to make sales pitches: _``Hand out the brochure, track records and annual reports, but do not hand out the prospectus or supplements.'' (Prospectuses contain warnings about potential dangers of investments.) _``Use interest calculation ... on your computer. People are blown away at how much more interest they earn in a bond.'' According to court records, branch employees were told to stress that the bonds were safer than stocks. One instruction said to mention ``Black Monday,'' when the market dropped more than 500 points on Oct. 19, 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Two Drivers Saved in First Crash Involving Two Air Bags
DOC.TEXT: Two drivers escaped with minor injuries in what is believed to be the first crash involving two cars equipped with air bags, and Chrysler Corp. plans to film a commercial at the site, an official said Friday. Two 1989 Chrysler LeBarons driven by Ron Woody and Priscilla Van Steelant, both of Culpeper, crashed head-on March 12 on Virginia Route 640. Both cars were totaled, but Woody and Ms. Van Steelant suffered only minor injuries. ``There's no doubt in my mind the air bags saved them both,'' said State Police Trooper G.W. Dawson, who investigated the accident. The cars were traveling at between 35 and 45 mph, according to the accident report. Ms. Van Steelant was cited for failure to drive to the right of center. Tim Hurd, a spokesman for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said the crash is believed to be the first accident involving two cars equipped with air bags. Beginning with the 1990 model year, all cars are required by federal law to be equipped with either air bags or automatic seat belts. All Chrysler domestic models are equipped with air bags. Jim Witherspoon, Culpeper County Chamber of Commerce executive director, said Friday he has been contacted by IWS Productions, a California firm commissioned by Chrysler to make a television commercial about the air bag crash. Igor Stalew of IWS Productions said the company is waiting for approvals to film the commercial at the site of the crash and will have definite plans on Monday. ``It's an amazing demonstration of the way air bags can protect,'' said Chuck Hurley, vice president of communications for the Insurance Institiute for Highway Safety. ``It's proof of a lot of work over the last 20 years.'' The institute is holding both crumpled cars in Fredericksburg, where a crash investigation team will examine the speed of the cars, the change in velocity, and other clues as to how the air bags performed during the crash. Hurley said the institute plans to interview the drivers as part of its investigation. When Woody and his wife, Kimberly, purchased their car last November, the air bag feature did not enter into their decision, they said.

A conservative federal appeals judge has blocked a murderer's execution in the California gas chamber, leaving relatives of the killer's teen-age victims stunned and disappointed. Tuesday's scheduled execution of Robert Alton Harris, which would have been the state's first in 23 years, was stayed Friday by Judge John Noonan of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The judge said more study of Harris' mental state may be needed. State Attorney General John Van de Kamp said he would ask the U.S. Supreme Court today to lift Noonan's order. Harris was convicted of abducting two San Diego boys from a drive-in restaurant in 1978 and fatally shooting them so he could use their car in a bank holdup. Both victims, John Mayeski and Michael Baker, were 16. Their bodies were found on a hillside several hours after the bank robbery.

President Bush says he doesn't expect Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev to reply to his confidental message on Lithuania, but just wanted ``to be sure the Soviets understand our position'' on the rebellious republic. Bush said Friday that he had sent the message to Gorbachev on the crisis to be ``sure there's no disconnect because of misinformation.'' ``Our views on the question of self-determination ... are well-known around the world, but I do not want to risk misunderstanding by failing to communicate,'' he told reporters during a picture-taking session at the White House. Later, while playing golf at the Marine Corps base in nearby Quantico, Va., the president was asked if he had heard anything back from Gorbachev. ``What I said doesn't, I don't think, require any answer,'' he replied.

Idaho's anti-abortion governor says he vetoed legislation that would have become the most restrictive abortion law in the nation because it was flawed by outside forces meddling in state affairs. ``We Idahoans are a fiercely independent group who will call it as we see it,'' Gov. Cecil Andrus said. ``I have done that.'' To out-of-state opponents of his Friday veto, he said: ``I would respectfully suggest you return to your own states and try and do it there.'' In the past three weeks, more than 21,000 telephone calls, letters and petitions have flowed into the governor's office. Calls from out of state outnumbered those from Idaho residents by 3-to-1.

The Bush administration, firing a new salvo in a stepped-up campaign to reduce America's huge trade deficit, is accusing 35 nations of erecting unfair barriers that block sales of U.S. exports. A list released Friday focused on countries running large trade surpluses with the United States, led by Japan, whose $49 billion surplus accounted for nearly half of the $109 billion trade imbalance last year. The Japanese took up 19 pages in the 214-page report, with the alleged infractions running the gamut from prohibitions against the sale of American rice to barriers against U.S.-made semiconductors. Other countries with a long list of alleged barriers were Taiwan, Canada, West Germany, South Korea and China. All have large trade surpluses with the United States.

A jury will begin deliberating next week whether John Poindexter did his best to give Congress the facts in the Iran-Contra affair or engaged in what the prosecution called ``a rampage of destruction'' to cover up the scandal. In closing arguments Friday that followed three weeks of testimony, prosecutor Dan Webb ridiculed the defense case and criticized former President Reagan's bias in favor of his one-time national security adviser. Poindexter destroyed a presidential document because it would have exposed his alleged lies to Congress, said Webb. In November 1986, he said, the document was the one piece of paper that ``puts the lie'' to Reagan's assertion then that there had been no trade of weapons to Iran for American hostages in Lebanon. ``You don't lie to the American public,'' Webb said of Reagan's speech.
